Praefatio.	Preamble.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have completed to you my son this book, which is the last of the science of medicine with its supplement, and having come to an end in it from its expositions and declarations, it has seemed good to me to complete it for you with this treatise which is part of surgery, that is, with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgery with the hand is lying in our region and is private only at our time: until perhaps science has perished, and the trace of it has been lost: and there remain from it only a few descriptions in ancient books, which hands have altered: and it happened to them that they made an error and had hesitation, until their intentions were closed and his vision was prolonged. It seemed good to me that I should uiuify it with this arrangement of this treatise according to the second meaning of exposition and declaration and abbreviation: and that I may make it with the forms of instruments, and the rest of the tools of the operation: for so is it from its addition and its propering that it is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	Because for this reason an excellent craftsman with his own hand cannot find good surgery in our present time, it is: because the art of medicine is long, and the author of it must be exercised before it in the science of anatomy which Galen told, until he knows the movements of the limbs, and their forms, and their connection, and separation, and has knowledge of the bones, and nerves, and ligaments, and numbers of them, and their egression, and pulsatile beatings, and quietures, and places of their exit.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because of that Hippocrates said, for a name with a name is much, and with work it is little, especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already spoken about it at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since who does not know that we have spoken about anatomy, will not be cleared up, unless he falls into error, in which humans fall into, as I saw many of them who form themselves out of this science, and boast themselves from it without knowledge and without experiment.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	A doctor was sawing off an apostema scrofulous wart on the neck of a woman, and he cut some blood vessels in her throat. Why did the blood flow from the woman until she died between her own hands?
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	I also saw another doctor who thought he would pull out a large stone from the urinary bladder that had been present for some time; but the stone was big.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	So he approached it, and removed it with a twig of bamboo.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Why did the man die on the third day?
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I had already been summoned to remove it; and I saw from the great size of the stone and the care taken by the nurse that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	I also saw another doctor who was taking a fee from the Duke of our land for medicine; and a black eunuch, who was with him, broke his thigh near the heel; but the doctor went away without knowledge of the matter, and he bound the fracture together with thin bands and strong nails, and did not let the wound heal.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he released it according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Then after a few days he sent him away with instructions not to loosen the bands; but he stayed as he was until his leg became rotten, and it came to ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	So I was called to him; and I relieved him of the bands; and so it was quiet, and he was free from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the corruption had already become established in the limb; and I could not prevent it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Then the corruption ceased to spread in the member, until he died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	I also saw another doctor who was piercing a cancerous pustule; and it got worse day by day, until the malignancy of it appeared to its lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	That is, because when it is cancer pure from the melancholic humor, then it should not be approached with iron at all unless it is in a member that can bear it so as to be cut off completely.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	For this reason, my sons, it is necessary for you to know that surgery is divided into two parts: namely, the operation which is associated with health and the operation with which there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already begun to explain in all the places of this book where surgery occurred, where there was terror and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Why is it necessary for you to be careful about that, and to avoid it? So that we do not find stupid people talking, and disgracing themselves.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore, receive with caution and protection, and guide our sick with ease and strength, and use a better path led by the grace of God to health and the admirable succession: and remove the terrible illnesses that cause difficulty in recovery: and take away our souls from there, since it makes you fear, so that it may come upon you a hesitation in our faith and comfort.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For there remains more to remain for our glory, and higher in the world this is, and finally for the quantities of ours.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Because Galen has already said in some of his advices:
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat diseases that are bad: do not call yourself a doctor of evil.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have already divided this treatise into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter one:
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Chapter one:
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter two:
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Chapter two:
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter three:
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	and the cure of twists, and similar cases: a treatise, ordered from the head down to the feet, and forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone be glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Surgery Book of Al-Bāṣīs.
Pars I.	Part I:
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Regarding the Preparation of the Surgeon and the Wound: with which complexions he should be, and at what time: and if with iron, or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before that, as soon as I remember the operation with him, it is necessary for me to say the quality of his incisions and wounds: and in which complexion he presents himself.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I will therefore say that the speech about the quality of cauterization's incision and wound is a lengthy, subtle, learned, and secret speech.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Even many wise men spoke in it, and disagreed with each other: and for me alone a little of their speeches is enough, fearing extension.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I will therefore say that cauterization is universal to all complexions, whether with substance or without: excepting two complexions, which are a warm complexions without substance, and a dry complexions without substance.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	In complexion, however, the warm and the dry, with substance, disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some have said that cauterization is in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite of it, that cauterization is not fitting for a sickness, which is from heat and dryness: because the nature of fire is hot; and does not suit, that it should heal a sickness from hot and dry, with hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite of it said: That through cauterization is made a healing in all sicknesses hot and dry, which happens in human bodies: for when you compare the human body, and its moistures, to the complexion of fire, you cool down the human body.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I myself also say through his speech: because from experiment I have already discovered that sometimes.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	But it is not necessary that you make it about that, unless he has already been tried, and exercised in the exercise of the chapter on cauterization, and has known the diversity of human complexions, and the disposition of sicknesses to themselves, and the causes of them, and the accidents of them, and the space of their times.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Do not fear also the residue of the poultices; and above all in cold and damp diseases.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For indeed all doctors have come together on them, and they do not disagree with cautery in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And you sons, know that from the secret cure by cautery with fire, and its goodness over cautery with medicine burning is simple: because the action of fire does not reach, unless to the member that is cauterized; and it does not hurt another member joined with it, except with small damage.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	But of medicine burning action reaches to that which is elongated out of the member; and perhaps makes happen in the member difficult disease of cure, and perhaps kills it.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	But fire because of its subtleness and goodness of its substance does not do that, unless it overflows.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Indeed I have already made it known to you that by experience, because of the length of practice and study with skill, and station on verity of things: and because of it I excuse from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not, for it is not allowed to my book, I would bring to you the secret and hidden thing in fire, and quality of its action in the bodies of its expulsion, which expels diseases by philosophical demonstration of speech, which was added from the minds of your men.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And you sons, know that they disagree in the time, in which it is to be made cauterium, and put better time of the wound.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	But I say that cauterium is to be made at all times: for the damage that happens because of time is hidden in the healing, which is attracted with cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And above all if the cauterium is because of the pains from necessary pains, strong, feasts, which do not tolerate tardiness: for they fear them, that happens mischief which is greater, than small damage is intrans because of time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And may not fall in the minds of your sons that son, who does not hold back, unless you are common and stupid doctors, namely, that he who has a sickness which is healed by cauterization, is not always returned: and they put down this consequence, and the thing is not as they think: because cauterization is not, except in medicine, which changes the complexion, and dries up the humidities which are the causes, why pains occur.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, cauterization surpasses medicine in the speed of its healing power, and the excellence of its operation, and the swiftness of its lordship: and it is possible that it may bring back a sickness at some time of the day according to the complexion of the patient, and the location of his sickness, and the excellence of its cure; and because it is prepared in his body from an excess of gathering in him: and it comes to itself in acquisition from food, and similar things from causes, unless it be a sickness, in which cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A sickness of the body is less likely to be healed by cauterization than an excess of little members and humors, such as a toothache, because of the pain, and similar ones; for it is possible that this pain may not be healed in him.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this happens in a few.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But the word of the common people again, that cauterization is the last medicine, is a straight word: it does not refer to what they intend in him; for they believe that there is no cure which is brought about by medicine, and by nothing else after the occasion of cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the opposite of this is true, and the intent, that cauterization is the last medicine, is not, unless when we administer methods of cure in some illnesses, and they do not confer these medicines: then we administer at the end of the thing cauterization, and it confers; then it falls, that cauterization is the last medicine, not according to the intent which the common people and many stupid doctors understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	But the ancients say that it is better to apply cautery with gold than with iron; and they did not say this except for the reason that gold is equal in strength to flesh and yet does not corrode it; and they say that there is no need of a place for cauterization.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But this is not absolutely true; for I have tried it myself and found that it does not work in certain parts of the body without other means.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cautery with gold is good, and better than with iron, as they say.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	But when you ignite the cautery from gold in fire, it is not revealed to you, when it burns according to the quantity that you use, because of the redness of gold: and when it comes to itself, and if you add ignition on it, it melts in fire and becomes thin sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Why does the artisan fall from that in business; and because of that do we prefer cautery with iron among us more quickly and closer, from its rightness towards the work?
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I too have already arranged this chapter on cautery according to chapters; and I have arranged it from the head to the feet, that you may easily find what you want from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	About the way of cauterizing the top of the nose.
Caput II.	The second top.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Confirm here cauterization towards the domain of humidity and coldness over the brain: which are two causes of blood, and multitude of flow of humors from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and multitude of sleep, and pain in the teeth, and pain in the throat: and universally all sickness, which happens from coldness, such as paralysis, and soya, and epilepsies, and apoplexies, and similar ones from those illnesses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The way of cauterizing is, that you draw out with a soluble medicine the head three nights or four, according to the need of the sickness, and its age, and custom of it.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then tell him to cut his head with a scalpel.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then have him sit between your hands and face the fourth side, so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Whatever way your middle finger goes, mark that spot with a bit of pepper.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then put olive oil on the cautery, which has this shape.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place the specimen at the marked spot with the oil, and compress your hand slowly, and you turn it around.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly lift your hand up, and look at the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that he has already removed a quantity of skull, or a quantity of hair, then quickly lift your hand up.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat the motion of your hand with the iron, or with another one if it is cold: until you see the bones, which I told you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and drink it with the bag, and place it on the spot: and release him after three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the soaked bag on top of the specimen and release it on the spot, until the fire goes out.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of that with the four-part ointment, until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have already said that as long as there is a wound open, it will discharge pus: why is this better and more beneficial?
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And one of them said: 'The skin should be cauterized all the way down to the bone': and the cautery should be held, until some ossification appears.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then scrape after that which is burnt from the bone, then cauterize again.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that it should be scraped with the cautery up to the last part, until it makes an impression on the bone like a stamp, so that the bone is made as in the shape of a crown: or an instrument that women put in a little cup and pour out, which they call alpha, and measure it, since from this place vapours of the head are exhaled, and the wound is closed after a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then treat, until it has healed.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	Which, however, are not evident to me at all these two kinds of cauterization unless they are present in some people according to the first fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And let go of him, with me it is better when he is healthy.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened by the continuation of its natural solution: as we have testified in the other members; and especially when the head is weak with sickness: and the species of cauterization is first more healthy and better to me, and I use it: then let's operate while he is healthy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	The mode of cauterizing the head when it is whole (in one piece).
Caput III.	Head III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When there is a chronic pain in the whole head and it is prolonged in the sick, and he uses ointments, and poultices, and washings, and oils, and employments (such as).
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized by one kind of cauterization, which we have described, and does not benefit from any of them: then examine.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head is sick with the strength of nature, and is not weak, and there is a sharp coldness: then cauterize it with another kind of cauterization under it little by little.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize him on all the horns of his head with his own cauterization, and don't let it pass through the skin, and disclose a quantity from the bone, which we have described.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize him with one kind of cauterization on the back of his head in the place which is called the "wind" and this is a place where there is a breeze; and dip your finger in water in this place, and do not disclose the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the sick is troubled by that sharp pain, and is far from the pain of all the other heads' cauterization.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will call this cauterization in its place; and it must be a cauterization by which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of his head is cauterized with a smaller kind of cauterization, by which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is his form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	In case of a headache, whether with or without medicine, as with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When it hurts in one part of the head and soapes, or extends the pain to the eye, and the head is washed with cleaning medicines, and the rest of the treatment is administered as I have mentioned in the division of illnesses, and does not give all of that: then cauterization is according to two ways: either cauterization with burning medicine: or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	But if cauterization is with burning medicine, it is as if you take one of the teeth of a cow, and you cut it into two sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the area of pain at the time with a blade on one side, until a place appears under the skin where the pain is caught.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then introduce it into that under the skin, until it is hidden: then tie it tightly with a thread of constricting knot, and let it go for fifteen hours, then unravel it, and remove it on the second day or third: then put a covered thing over the spot immersed in butter, until a pus place appears: then heal the spot with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you want to do that with certain medicines that burn, which I have written in the 12th book, on Medicinal Incantations.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	But if cauterization is with iron, it is according to this way.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Fire cauterization, whose form is this:
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called a Klis; because the form of the head is like the form of a kleis, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle of it there is a small eminence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then put the iron on that place, and hold your hand: and you turn the iron little by little with speed: and let the amount that burns be according to the thickness of the skin, such as half of it.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And pray that your hand does not hurt, so that the artery below does not rupture and blood flow occurs.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then dip the bandage in salt water and place it on the spot, and leave it for three days: then dip it with butter: afterwards apply ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if there is a headache, cauterize this headache with the point of a scalpel, second time with cauterization.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And do not cut the artery in this headache, but use the old one's own.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	The mode of cauterizing in a headache:
Caput V.	Head 5.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you are healing a headache, with the method we have mentioned before in connection with cures for diseases, and as we have mentioned in respect of divisions of illnesses, and when there is no effect from this treatment: then you will see from the illness that it does not suffice to apply the cautery at first with medicine, or with the cautery with fire; then you must apply the fire of the cauterization until it turns white after the signs on the spot of pain with a line whose length is half a finger, or almost like that: and place your hand in a grip and squeeze it until you hit the artery, and reach as far as the mouth.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, you must cauterize the jaw which moves during chewing, so that it does not hurt on one side or the nerve which moves it, from which spasm occurs.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be on guard, and take care with regard to the flow of blood from the artery which has been cut off.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For there is a danger in cutting it off, and especially for one who does not know what he is doing, and is not learned or experienced: and he dismisses the operation with that.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I come with a reminder about the treatment of blood flow from an artery according to its way, and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see from illness that this cautery does not suffice, and you see the body bearing up the cauterization in the middle of the head as we have told, take care of a wound, until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you see it, administer cauterization, which we have said in the chapter on arteriotomy with a cautery instrument having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For cauterization is better and more beneficial than this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	(On the method of cauterizing in ear pain.)
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear from cold, and the cure is with solutions, and the remainder of the treatment as we have said in the division, and the pain does not disappear, then fire cauterization: and that is what is called a point, whose form is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then the points with it after its ignition around the whole ear, as it resolves itself: or in the circumcision of both, if at the same time pain is in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And lengthen it with the cautery from the root of the ear slightly, after you have marked the places with the caustic: and let the amount of the cautery be ten points all over the ear, and almost the same.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then cure the place, until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	(On the method of cauterizing in torture.)
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.Et si uis, administra Cauterium
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	And if you want to administer cauterization in torture, it is not except for the species that occur from phlegm, according to which we have said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And distant cauterization of a species that occurs from dryness, and spasm of a nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you cure this species of torture with hipirrhea, and caputpurgia, and gargarisms, and your treatment does not bring about a cure, then you should cauterize the sick person with three cauteries: one near the root of the ear, and a second a little below its edge, and a third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery on the opposite side of the weak part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not occur unless in the part that appears to be healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of the cautery is that it cauterizes itself at the very tip of the upper ear by the corner of the head slightly: and another in the timpan: whose length should be according to the length of a thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And lay your hand with the cautery, until a quantity of half-thickness of skin has burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of cautery, and its shape is from a scalpel, whose shape is as follows: indeed it is not more subtle by a little, as you see: and it should be that the blade is in it slightly too thick.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the place, with what preceded it: until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	§ On the way of cauterizing in ancient apoplexia.
Caput VIII.	CHAPTER VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When an ancient apoplexia is established, and care for it has been as we have said, and your medicine does not help, and the patient has no fever, then cauterize him with four cauterizations on all the horns of his head, and a cautery in the middle of his head, as we have said, and a cautery in his occiput, according to what preceded: and the mode of cauterization should be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Also cauterize with the cautery above the throat of the stomach: and it is more final.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for it, with what preceded it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	§ On the way of cauterizing in obliteration.
Caput IX.	CHAPTER IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It should be that he is placed in a strong wine in the first sick person of a great day, and a pill that purifies the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then wash his head entirely with milk, and put over his occiput a plaster of myrrh described in the treatise on plasters: and put him on occasion.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	But this is the mode of cauterization: and make it according to the order given there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If then he heals by that, it is good. Sed si non sanatur, iterum curetur, et iterum, usque ad qu
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	But if not: then care for him again, and again, until he is healed: then put between every cautery slightly the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the cauterization, with what preceded it.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If however you wish to add a stitch, and he is a weak one who accepts it: then make him a cautery in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	That if you wish to add a stitch: then cauterize him himself on two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then take care of the wound, until it is healed: and let the cautery be greased after the form, which has been mentioned above.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	The mode of cauterizing in paralysis, and softening.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you should proceed in the purification of the head with hyssop, and with that which I have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then wash the head with milk: then cauterize him with a cautery in the middle of the head, and a cautery on all the horns of the head, and a cautery on the posterior part, and three on the spine of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If however you are indigent in the softening of the body with many of these, and he is a weak one who accepts it, and the disease is strong: then cauterize him with four cauteries on the spine of the back, and the last with a cautery, until it is burned out from his skin by fire, and wash your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then take care of the wound, until it is healed: and let the cautery be greased.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	The mode of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	The epileptic should not be cauterized, unless the epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	It is necessary that you should first purify his brain with hyssop, and with the other purification which I have said in the division: when he is a great weakling, or accepts medical treatment.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If however he is a youth who does not tolerate medicine, then administer a gargle, and chewing which purifies the brain, before those days with many good foods.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then wash his head with milk, then cauterize him with a cautery in the middle of his head, and another on the occiput, and on all the horns of his head.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If he should be weak and yet bear it patiently, then cauterize him with the cauterums which I have spoken of in the case of paralysis, and with the softening of the body over the vertebrae of the neck and back: and let there be oil cauterium according to the manner which has preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if the boy is sick, then put on a fine cautery, according to this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	§ On the way of cauterizing in melancholy.
Caput XII.	CHAPTER XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupt湿度 and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with the cautery which we have spoken of in the case of paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is a superabundance of release into melancholy, and his body is wet with humidity, then give him in a drink what will mend his brain, according to that which has preceded in division: and then shave his head, and afterwards make a tortious thread made of linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then put it in the midst of his head: and the sick one, sitting, should hold himself at a distance from all parts.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is worthy of old butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat him on a fire with moderate heat, which he can bear, when he enters into him.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then let him vaccinate himself in the midst of his head in a circle, and let him go until he is cooled down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this sick one once a week, with the rest of his regular treatment, until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you want to, cauterize him by making small spots all over his body, except that you hold the hand with the cautery: but smell it first.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	This kind of cautery humidifies the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then put on him a coat imbibed in butter, or in fat of chicken.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	§ On the way of cauterizing in descending water to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When you observe the beginning of water in the eye through the signs which I have mentioned in the division, then begin to drink and pour out the medicine with it, when he washes his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep him away from all moisture, and let him sit in a bath, on a few days of fast.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command him to shave his head, and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize him over two temples with two cauterizations, if the beginning of water is present in both eyes simultaneously: or from one side, if it is present in one eye only: and cut off all the veins and arteries which are under the skin: and let there be cauterizations in her long in length.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	What if you see anything of it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and in their dissection, and in caution to stop the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when he is cauterized in the hair, under two bones, with two cauterizations finally produced.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	The way to cauterize in ancient tears.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are old and persistent, and they stand on the veins and arteries that are on the outside of the head, it is known that this is from cold and phlegmatic humours: then cauterize with the same cautery which I have mentioned in the beginning of descending water, cautery in the middle of the head, and two cauterizations over two bones, and two cauterizations in the hair under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if he can stand to add a little, then cauterize him in every side of the eye, at the end of the brow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	The way to cauterize in the nostrils' discharge.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat this, as we said in the division, and the medicine does not benefit: then approach it, and give it three nights of weak broths: afterwards shave its head, and cauterize it with middle cautery, with olive cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with two cauteries, one above the eyebrows, a little below the hairline.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against injury to the artery, so that you do not hurt it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	This is the form of cauterization with a clauw.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	The way to cauterize for softening the eyelids.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye is softened by sickness or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, with this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if there is a need, cauterize it above the two eyelids with two cauteries on the whole part: and let them extend by two hands: and let the length of each cautery be according to the length of the lid: and do not put your hand near the cautery, but according to the quantity that burns, let there be a third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	This is the form of cauterization according to this way of lunar cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	The way to cauterize the eyelid with hair that pierce the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery is in two ways: with fire, or with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	But in the cautery with fire, instruct the patient beforehand to stop shedding his hair, if he is one who cleans it, until it grows and becomes even.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	But if it pierces him at the root: then tighten the eyes with poultice, so that they do not move until they are healed.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are healed and even, then place the head of the patient in your lap: and afterwards mark the eyelids of his eyes with encaustum, a mark that is according to the shape of the leaf of myrrh: and let the beginning of the mark be near the hair.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place the poultice wet with albumin on the eye or in silk mucus.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then the fire cautery, whose form is this:
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize on the shape, which you have marked little by little in many places, until it is burned through the surface of the skin, which is as if the figure of a palm leaf, all apparent by itself.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the work of your health is: if you close the eyelids of the eye already and remove the hair at the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	So then raise your hand: and send it away for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place on the spot a poultice with butter until the sore is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for the spot with ointment until it heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	That if any of the hairs return after an hour, and the eyelid becomes soft: then repeat the cautery on that spot, as you did in the first place.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	But if the hairs are in the lower part: then cauterize the spot until it returns to its natural place: and adjust so that the hairs do not sting the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	The way of cauterizing with burning medicine at the same time.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is as you instruct the sick person to let the hair grow on, until it grows long and even.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make in the shape of a palm leaf form out of a sheet of cloth.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take out of known soap and not imbibed in water from each pound of a pound or almost like that: then dry it all at the same time with good wringing, and make it with urgency, so as not to grow cold.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then out of the cloth from that which you made in the form of a palm leaf, and place the spot on one eyelid or both.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye poultice wet with albumen: and let the head of the patient be in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your finger tip on the medicine, and press the spot a little.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And thou shall move him when he feels sick to the touch of medicine: for his touch is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	But while this was so that he found out about the touch, then dismiss medicine, and move it with your finger yourself.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	But when the touch of the medicine has ceased, then remove medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then, if you see the eyelid go up, as it were removed from contraction with fire, or with incision, is good: and if not, then repeat on him out of medicine on the spot where medicine does not print, and does not deteriorate, until your operation is adequate, and the eye closes.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then put on top of it the poultice with butter, until the skin of the injury is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with the ointment diaphanum, or other, until he is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you near the operation, to keep the last guard, so that nothing falls into the eye from medicine.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	That if the eyelid softens after a few days, and fights from hair something into the eye, then repeat medicine on that place, which softens from the eyelid of itself, as you did in the beginning.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for him, until he is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the ointment of myrtle.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you should know that the eyes of men differ in size, and fineness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	So second to this your consideration: and does not obscure the way of its straightness, which is the study of this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the mode of cauterizing in the lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you care for the fistula, with what we have said about the divisions of illnesses, and your cure is not effective: then it should be cauterized in this way.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Prescribe to the sick person, that he puts his head in your lap, and holds it with his hands so that it does not move or shake with its head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then put the cotton wisp soaked in the infusion on his eyeball, or in the slippery elution of psillium; then apply fire cautery, whose shape is thus.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Then put the cotton wisp soaked in the infusion on his eyeball, or in the slippery elution of psillium; then apply fire cautery, whose shape is thus: and if the wisp sits penetrating all the way to one end, with which it makes the cauterium; and if the wisp sits up high like this.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this cotton wisp is better for your task.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then take the syringe if it is open, and extract the pus from it, and dry it out; and if it is not open, then open it, and extract the pus from it.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then put the fire cautery on it, which has been made hot.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold it gently near the fire cautery from the eye, toward the nose side, so that your hand doesn't wander or shake; and place the fire cautery into the fat of the eye, and dissolve it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If then you hold the fire cautery near the eye as described above, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the cauterization once or twice, if you can put up with it; and discharge it after three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then put the cotton wisp soaked in butter, and treat it with the dry ointment, until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	That if, after forty days, it is not healed: then put on the eye a sharp corrosive medicine, until you see the tooth; and cut it out according to what comes next in his book.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another way of fire cautery with a tube, which some first said about.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Then find the place of the tube, and locate it; then put a small hole in it, that is, a small cane, whose shape is thus.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it a small amount of liquid lead, and hold your hand so that the sick person doesn't move at all, so that it doesn't run away, or get the liquid lead near his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	It is necessary that you put on over the eye an ointment infused with albumin, or water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	 Lead, however, burns the place of the fistula, and heals it by a wonderful healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed, with what we have said from the Cautery and Cure, is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer a hole of the nose, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to which he will come to his own place of himself.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	The way of cauterizing in fistulas of the lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX:
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Often there happen to be on the lip a fistula, which are called hairs, and especially on the lips of boys.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you have to deal with these fistulas, with what we have said about the division of ailments, and when the cure is not effective, then a small fire should be cauterized with a knife, according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let it rest in the shape of a knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then put quickly the lit fire on the fistulas, until it reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with a clean wound, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	The way of cauterizing in the fistula of the mouth:
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI:
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When it happens that a pimple is on the root of the gingival, or on the palate, or on the roots of the teeth: then pus is made, and it bursts: then it becomes hardened, and pus runs, and a fistula forms: then care for it, and the cure is not effective in it, then fire should be cauterized with fire according to the quantity, which enters into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then introduce the lit fire into the hole of the fistula, and hold your hand, until it reaches the depth of its, and the last one: do this once, or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for him after that, with what we have said about the cure until it is healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If then a wound is cut away and heals, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to detect the place, and take away the corrupt bone according to what comes into its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	§ On the mode of cauterizing in gingival diseases and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	Head XX.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum softens through moisture, and the teeth move, and does not yield to medicines, then put the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then place the fire cautery, of which the shape comes into his head after these things, so that you put on a cannula over the tooth: and insert the lit cautery quickly: and hold your hand a little, until the sick one feels the heat of the fire having already reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And dry your hand: then repeat the cautery a few times, according to what you want.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then fill the sick mouth with salt water, and hold it for an hour: and has it expelled.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth moves stiffer, and the softened gum is tightened, and thus the corrupt moisture dries up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	§ On the mode of cauterizing in dental pain.
Caput XXIII.	Head XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the dental pain is through coldness or cold or itchiness, and does not yield to medicines: then the fire cautery is in himself according to two ways: either with butter: or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	But the cautery of his own is with butter, so that you take butter that is very hot, and heat him up in an iron tube or in a mold.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a stick, and turn it over on the tip of the tongue.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then dip him in the hot butter: and place him on the painful tooth quickly, and hold him until he feels cold: then repeat him a few times, until the power of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, dip the thread, or wrap it in cold butter, and place it on the tooth that is hurting; and place iron which has been heated on top of it, until the fire reaches the depth of the cavities of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	But cauterize it with fire, so that you may direct it towards the hole of air, or the hole of iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be some grossness in his body, so that the keenness of the fire does not reach his gaping mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then hold the cauterizing fire, of which form you wish; and place it on the tooth; and hold your hand, until the cauterizing fire cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this sometimes, because the pain is relieved, or do it on the same day, or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary to press the cauterizing substance into his impression, so that he may fill his gaping mouth with good balm, and hold it for an hour: then let him spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the cauterizing.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whatever extremity you can: and this is the form of the cane.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	The mode of cauterizing in strophulas.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When strophulas are swollen with phlegm, and from cold humidities, and do not submit to digestion by medicines, and wish to have a quick digestion: then hold the cauterizing fire, of which form is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	It has two open extremities, that smoke may flow from the cauterizing fire's one extremity: and place the heated iron on the abscess once, and again, if you can bear it, until it reaches the depth of the abscess.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the abscess is small: then place the cauterizing fire according to the quantity of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then discharge him after three days, and place on the tooth cold soap immersed in butter, until what was burned is relieved by coolness.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then take care of the tooth with dental ointment, until it is healed in the form of a cane.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	To cauterize in a sore throat and constriction of the air passages.
Caput XXV.	De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uoc
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When there is an excess of moisture above the canal of the lung, and especially when it is accompanied by a cold complexion, then it is necessary that the sick be evacuated at first with soluble medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it yourself at the root of the cough in a depressed place; and be careful not to go too far with cautery on the throat or skin unless you have some of its substance.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another cautery at the joint of the neck at the last of the spine of the last; and let the cautery be a small one after that which has preceded.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then take care for this patient with what has preceded until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	The method of cauterizing in lung diseases and coughs:
Caput XXVI.	De modo curando malum in Pulmonis, et
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When the illness of the lung and the cough are caused by cold humidities, and the sick person does not have a fever, nor tuberculosis, and the illness is old: then cauterize it with two cauteries above the rib in depressed places, lightly, and slowly.
