Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between two breasts; and let the cautery be a small one after that which has preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish to apply your cautery by pricking with the cautery which is called a "Punctum", of the same form as that which has preceded in pricking the pain of the ears: and let there be punctures from thirty to nearly fifty.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then take care for this patient with what has preceded until he is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let there be a cautery with three branches: in this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Why is it alleviated by this cautery, when you make the three cauteries into one?
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	The method of cauterizing in itching and dislocation of the shoulder:
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the dislocation of the head has been caused by moisture, and there is no return to his normal state at the time of dislocation, until it has become accustomed to reducing, then dislocates with little movement, which we have already testified that it happens, then it is necessary that you reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then he should lie down on his back or on his side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then massage with oil, which is inside the little finger toward the top with your left hand: and if the dislocation has occurred inwardly.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then he should have a caustic fire with two handles.
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then he should burn the oil, until it penetrates to the side of another, and the shape of the cauterization is with four cauters.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And when it is made cauterization with a caustic having three handles, why the shape of the cauterization then is six smaller ones: and the handles are according to the subtlety of the touch.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the form of the caustic with three handles.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And when one is added to this mode, why are there eight cauters.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then he should place on the caustic crushed peppers with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then he should make the member calm, so that it does not move at all during a certain time, until it is comforted.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation has occurred upwardly, and rarely happens, then burn him on the shoulder with a small caustic, or with multiple cauters by poking it.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the dislocation is firm, and the moisture is removed: and the sick person recovers.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	The mode of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When there are cold and great moisture in the stomach, until they have extracted it from its skin, and multiply the catarrhs to it, and frequent methods of curing, and does not confer: then the sick person should lie down on his back, and extend his legs, and his hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then he cauterizes with three cauteries, one cautery under the cochleary breast in the quantity of a finger with cautery clauilis, and two cauteries below from the two sides one cautery, until the figure of the cauteries is triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And he lengthens between each other so that they do not join together, when they make pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And there is the depth of cautery in the quantity of two thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of the cautery be second to this form without addition; and if you want to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this form: and let there be a cautery by which this cautery is made, one according to the form of a circle.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And let the stomach be cauterized by touching it which shudders at this cautery; and it is, so that the signs on the stomach are according to the quantity, which you want with the caustice: then he cauterizes itself with the cautery of touch: then he cares for itself with the cure, which preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	The way of cauterizing the cold part.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When it happens in the Epate that there is pain from cold and wet, or from a thick wind, until it goes out from his skin by natural discharge of the excess, and the sick person is treated, with what we have said, and does not profit in him: then it should lie down sick on his own cerement, and signs with the caustice three cauteries according to this form, and this quantity the same over the espar below from the hypocondriis, where it reaches the bed of the man: and there is a space which is between each cautery according to the thickness of the finger: and there is a cautery according to the length of the body straight: and do not compress your hand with the caustice much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And there is the quantity of him which is dried out from the thickness of the skin, half the quantity added to it: and let the sick person stand on his own feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If he is not standing, then lie down, for he has already stretched his legs and raised his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the operation.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And you too can perform this operation with a knife as a cautery, when subtlety and prudence are with you in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And guard yourself, so that you do not proceed too far in the cauterization, and let the skin there become thicker, for it is thick throughout the body, and may reach the intestines: since the skin is thin there, know that one.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	Regarding the method of cauterizing the liver pustules.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When the problem has developed and you need to know, if that pustule is in the liver or in its membrane: then, if it is in the liver, you will see a dull pain, and there will be no sharpness: and if it is in its membrane, the pain will be sharp; and you will see that the treatment of doctors is tiring.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore, let the sick person lie on his back.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then determine the position of the pustule with respect to the surface of the body. Then set fire to the cautery so that it radiates.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize it with one cautery, until the skin is completely burned over and reaches the syphac, until all the pus has come out: then care for the person who is treating the pustules, until they heal.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not necessary that the appearance of this cautery be used, unless the study of medicine is prolonged in someone: and because, from time to time, some disease can be brought about by experiment: then one should dare to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But, if you want to stop it, it is better with me.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in the pleura.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that they used to cauterize with radices of arista lochaea on the pleura in this way.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is as you should receive from the roots of dry aristea long, a root which is found in it, and sit like the thickness of the finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil: and light it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one cautery in that which is between the continuation of the fork with the neck, and two small cauteries under guidices somewhat declining to the side, which is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And two cauteries also in it, which is between the fifth and sixth rib declining somewhat to the rear: and one cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cauteries from the rear: one in it which is between two spatulas: and two cauteries from the sides of the chest, lower cautery which is between two spatulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And it is not necessary that you should squeeze your hand with the cautery, but let it be in the open skin smelling.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancient ones said that from men who use a cautery of similar iron rod: and they light it, and put it inside him which is between the ribs until it reaches with it to the apostema of the liver, and comes out pus: as we have said in the aposteme of the liver.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this piercing with the cautery there is a fear that either the weak man dies immediately, or happens to the place a fistula, which has no cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	§ On the mode of cauterizing the Spleen [Kaput XXIII].
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you cure the disease of the spleen, with it which we have said from the curing of diseases in a division of diseases, and your curing does not bring about a cure, then cauterize in it according to three modes, which are all correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	Of which one is that you make three cauteries, or four lined according to the length of the spleen according to the figure of cauterias of the liver, of which preceded the figure.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let there be between every cautery quantity of thickness of the finger, or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the mode of the incision, which we have said in the liver is equal.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not compress your hand with the incision; and let the patient be laid down on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another mode of incision is that the patient has two hands with fire to incise, which we have said in the chapter on shoulder dislocation: and wipe clean the skin that extends from the direct side of the spine where it reaches the bed of the sick man to his left: and raise up your hand so as to wipe clean the skin according to the length of the body, so that the incision falls according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then introduce two hot hands until they penetrate the skin on both sides: and then remove the incision; so that four incisions are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you want to cut with a different incision having three hands.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then take care of the incision after you have removed it, to emit pus for many days: because it is more healing as much remains that preceded from the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	The mode of incising in the Hydropsis.
Caput XXXIII.	CHAPTER XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The incision does not fall in Hydropsis unless it is raised properly.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you cure Hydropsis with the modes of cure which we have said in the division, and there is no improvement in the patient, then let four incisions be made around the navel, and one incision on the stomach, and one incision on the liver, and one incision on the spleen behind, and two incisions at the back between the vertebrae, and one on the right side of the chest, and one on the left side of the stomach: and let the depth of the incision approach the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then remove the incision open, so that it emits pus after a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not make the patient sweat after the incision with it; because two purposes should be gathered to him, and he will hurry to heal himself with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The form of the incision when the stomach is cut should be a slit: according to which it precedes in form; and its back, when cut, should be ovoid, according to which it precedes in form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	To cauterize the feet and the legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter IIII.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When they are submerged in water, and become yellow: you should cauterize on the back of the foot, between the auricular and the ring fingers: and wash your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then wash your hand: and do not repeat the operation at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For the water turns them yellow, and sits the cautery in this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make two cauteriums on the two legs, and let the cautery go with the edge of the knife-edge of the cautery: and let the cautery go along the length of the leg, one under the knee, and the other lower down by that, about halfway down the leg: and make two cauteriums on all the back: and do not close the cauterium for a long time: so that it is healed from it some water: then care for the rest as we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	The way to cauterize in the solution of the belly.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the solution of the belly is weakened by cold and moisture, until it loses its holding power and digestive power, which are in the stomach and intestines: and cure that with the ways of curing, and does not heal: and you will see a bearing tolerating the violence of the cure, then cauterize him with a large cautery on his stomach, following what preceded in the cauterization of the stomach with a circle-shaped cautery, and four small cauteriums around the navel, with a fine knife-edge: and a large cautery over the palate above the molars, or two small cauteriums.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see exuberant moisture, and a weak bearing of that thing, then cauterize him with a cautery on his chest, and a cautery on all his loins: and perhaps you will add two small cauteriums on the stomach near the large one.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	For the cure is perfect, whose sign is not mistaken.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	To cauterize hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old hemorrhoids, or one, and they are of gross humor, cold, or corrupt humors, and treat them with the same means as we have said in the division, and there is no cure: then cauterize three cauterizations on the lower back of the trunk under an egg-shaped triangle, and a cauterization under the navel almost like two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is cold, and his food is not digested, and you see that his face is pale, then cauterize him on the stomach with a large cautery, according to what preceded it: and cauterize on his spine, and another on his spleen, with a cautery of the claw: and leave the cautery open at some time: and then take care of him, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	Chapter 37. The method for cauterizing the arterioles after cutting them off.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37. The method for cauterizing the arteri
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut off the arterioles, then set fire to the cautery that is radiated.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the fire into the arterioles that you have cut off: and with your last hand, until the cautery reaches the opening of the anus, from which runs the blood: do it once, or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many arterioles, then cauterize each one with a separate cautery, as we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then take care of them, with the ointment that is used for them, until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cautery on his back, it is more final in the procedure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	Chapter 38. The method for cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38. The method for cauterizing a fistula
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the sick person does not obey the section and operation that we have described in its place, and shudders because of it, perhaps he will be healed with a cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	So when a fistula occurs in someone, and it is old, pus runs out of it, and corrupted humors.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	It is fitting that you should examine it with care when you attempt it gently.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then recognize the depth of its extent when you attempt it.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then apply the cautery of fire, which is like a ray.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert yourself into it with an ignited rod and measure how far it enters.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeatedly apply the cautery to her until all corrupt bodies are burned up, once, twice, or three times, according to the amount of your need.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And guard yourself against the burning of the nerve, if it is there, or a large vein: or if the fistula opens into the woman's body, or into the body of the intestine, then guard all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not make it unless when the fistula is in a muscular place: and consider that it is not penetrating.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	But if the place is sealed and tissues are removed from it, and remains so for a long time: then know that it has now been completely healed.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if they do not remove the tissues from it, then know that it is penetrating, or its bottom is corrupted, or something like that among them: whose remembrance will remain in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	As for the way of cauterizing the perineum.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39. The Head.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When a pain arises in the kidneys from cold or coarse wind and is soothed by sleeping, then you should cauterize that part on top of the perineum, cauterizing each kidney with a cautery, preceded by the remembrance.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we will have cauterized that part second in the same place.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Why are there three lines drawn?
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	So they will be more effective in the process of cauterization.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	As for the way of cauterizing the vagina.
Caput XL.	Chapter X.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When weakness and relaxation occur in the bladder, and there is a softening due to cold and moisture, until the sick person no longer retains urine, then cauterize him in the lower part of the scrotum above the bladder, where the hairs begin to grow, and cauterize with fire on the right side, and with another on the left: and let the length of the cautery on the side correspond to the length of the nail of the thumb: and cauterize him with two cauteries, if you can bear it: and let the second cautery be made according to what came before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	With respect to the mode of cauterizing the womb:
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLI.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and moisture occur in the womb, and pregnancy is prevented by it, and her menstrual periods are delayed, and pain occurs with her menses, then three cauteries should be applied around the navel, as we have said in the cauterization of the bladder, and one cautery on the back below, or two cauteries: and let the length of the cautery on the side correspond to the length of the nail of the thumb.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	With respect to the mode of cauterizing the vagina in a case of dislocation:
Caput XLII.	Chapter XLI.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When the mucous membrane of the vagina flows with moisture towards the anus, and there is a cause for its exit from its place: the sign of this is that the skin protrudes over the other when they are placed face to face: and the site of dislocation is found in that which is hollow.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore, let the sick person be cauterized on his own vagina with a similar circle of fire: after you have marked the signs with caustics around the vagina, as it recedes: and let her fall into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the shape of that which came before be applied to the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If you do not have this kind of cautery, then cauterize him with three cauteries, with a large oil-filled cautery: and let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin of all.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Afterwards, take care of himself, until he gets well.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	The mode of cauterizing in sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter LIII. On the treatment of sciatica.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the sciatic nerve, and there is cause for this pain, coldness, and moisture: the sick person should be cared for with the remedy we mentioned in the division, and if there is no benefit from it, and it becomes worse: then one should remove the sick person from thick humors with fetid pills, or with artificial pills, and others.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the method of cauterization with it is according to two ways: either with cautery with burning medicines, or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	With fire, there are many ways.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	Of which one is that he cauterizes over the sciatic nerve of his own body with three triangular cautery wicks, according to this form:
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make them a good depth, or a bad one.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And there should be space that is between each cautery of the quantity of the thickness of the finger: and let there be oil cautery.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	When, however, cautery is made in the middle on top of the sciatic nerve of his own head.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Why are there four cauteries?
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you want to cauterize with a circle, whose form precedes the cauterization of sciatica, one: so that the circle contains all the sciatica.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn away the thickness of the skin of all.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cauterization in sciatica, when pain is attached to the sciatic nerve itself, and does not extend as far as the hip and thigh.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If, however, it extends as far as the hip and thigh: then cauterize him with two cautery wicks on top of the hip, in the place where the pain is, and a little to the left: and let there be a knife cautery.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let there be depth of cauterization according to the depth of thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the sick one signals that the pain extends up to almost the toes, then cauterize him there where he signals it with the cautery of a point, three, four or more, if he needs it.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if he signals pain being under the knee towards the leg, then cauterize him there with one scalpel.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And let your cauterization be such that you do not hurt with the cautery towards this thing so as to burn nerves, or a large artery, and do not attract it by that means on top of a bad wound on the sick person, or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I have already seen one and the other who cauterized above the knee and finished off in the cauterization, and the leg was inflamed until the tumor followed the foot, and it was completely perforated and completely corroded: then the solution of the wound came out, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If the pain is on both sides at the same time, cauterize each one according to this mode.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men have said in cauterization of the anus, whose cauterizing is this mode.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a similar punch from iron, whose diameter is half of the palm: and let it be at the opening of its third finger according to the thickness of the finger nail, or less; and inside that third hole there is another third.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let there be a space between each punch according to the quantity of the nail of the thumb: and let the punches open on both sides; and let their height be almost like a knot, or two knots: and make them handles from iron that are unevenly fitted in the punches.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is his form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then let it be lit in fire, until it turns red, and let it throw sparks off: then let it be placed on a plate of the anus lying down on the healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Then cauterize him with three round cauteries in one line.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then let go of him after three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Then bind with butter: and let the broken bone remain open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then heal him with ointment, until he is well.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Says Albucasis, with this kind of surgery on the son, we are not very fond, because of the fearsome appearance: and therefore, because there are few who wait for him.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	However, from good surgery he who endures, and remains with him at his place.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	The cauterizing should be done with the doctors present, so that you make two knots on either side of the arm, which is pierced with the pin of his door frame, made of iron or brass, with its length at the height of their backs: whose ends are almost like themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let there be a space what is between either quantity of the thickness of the finger, and let them be open above and below: and let it hold itself toward the one and the other, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it on a wooden tray, the sick man lying on the sound side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And squeeze your hand much on the wooden tray.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles of hot water, which is heated with fire a little, and hold it for a time: and let the sick man feel the prickling, and his burning, for he feels the prickling like fire, until he is at rest from the burning.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then wash your hand with an instrument, and wipe off all with sweet water: then let it be for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And place on it the butter, until it moves away from the burning; and let it be for some days, and let the pus run out from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	For this is final in healing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then heal that with ointment, until he is well.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends to the hip or leg, make him a sitting place in it that holds water, according to what you have made in the width is equal.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the way to make warm water: and I have already written about it in the book on the rectifying of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali and burned lime, each a part of one; separate them, and put them into a new crucible, the lower part of which is bored with a small hole; add to it the quantity of substance to be treated; and put another crucible, full of water, below; and pour on the alkali and lime from above by way of a stream: then compress them well in your hand; and let the crucible go until the sharp water has run out at the bottom of the hole.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then pour all the water together, and pour it on to another lime; and filter it, until it runs clear again.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	This will then be very sharp, which is used in many surgical procedures and in cauterizing the remaining parts of the body.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it effectually performs the operation by the fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from among medicines there are those which, when mixed with each other, cauterize widely, like caraway, and also myrrh, and lime mixed with soap, so that both are mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen himself related the story of a certain man from ancient times who was cured of pain in his hip and sciatic pain: and he said that it was very effective.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said, "I do not like another cure, and I was cured from one hip, until he related that perhaps he had entered a warm bath, and came out healthy.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is taken from the oil of the gopher-lark; and if gopher-lark oil is not found, it is made up like this: a little is mixed with fat, and put on the hip where the pain is, or in the groin, or in the thigh: it is bound, and left for a certain time, three hours or more, so that the sick person feels a sedating pain from the heat.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then introduce it into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When the body then becomes wrinkled, introduce it into the bed.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain has subsided, and he is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you should know that these medicines should not be applied to the body without first evacuating it.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides who said that when sheep dung is applied as a poultice to the sciatic pain, it will benefit him: and it becomes a second-degree burn in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	The wool is to be soaked in old oil and laid on a deep place, which is between the thumb of the foot and the heel, and is closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take sheep dung that has been gathered up, and set it on fire in a fire until it becomes a coal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place the coal on the wool and leave it there until the fire is put out.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat this.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Do not then cease to do this until the sensation has become accustomed to the stimulation up to the ankle, and the pain rests.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of poultice is called Vaccine Burn.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	The cauterization for sciatic pain.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When pain occurs in the back due to various causes, or from injury, or from excessive evaporation, and similar causes, and does not respond to cold infusion alone: then the burn should not be applied unless it is done in this one way only, that is, with a cold infusion.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	Then after the evacuation with pillules of the bitter herb, and similar ones, let them be applied to the back where there is pain, three lines according to its width, having marked the lines with encaustum in each line; then five cauterizations, or more according to the quantity that comes from the tolerance of the healing power: and it should be done by cauterizing with the cautery needle.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, apply three cauterizations, or four, with the middle clava of the cauterizing tool, in this way:
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	To cauterize in case of gangrene.
Caput XLV.	Chapter LXV. On cauterization in the case of
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	Many times this disease has occurred in infants.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of the onset of this disease in children is: that which occurs on him stricture during defecation, and movement: and inflammation in the last spine of the back and knots of it, which has already begun to emerge over the remaining spines.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you therefore see that, and wish to do that, then cauterize it with a cautery which is in the form of a circle.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And he takes the cautery over the entire spine evenly: and if you wish to cauterize around the spine with a needle-point cautery two lines, or three: and let the points be close together side by side.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place, until it heals with him which we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And be careful, do not administer the cautery to gangrene, which is made in a spasm of a nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	The way to cauterize in podagra, and pains of joints.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter LXVI. On cauterization in podagra, and pains
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of joints are from cold humors which flow to any part of the body's limb, then when pains occur in the feet, it is the custom of doctors to name that properly as podagra.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When therefore podagra of cold cause is cured by means of the cure, and do not remove the pains, then remove the cautery to remove those.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is so, that he is cauterized after evacuation around the joint of the feet with many cauteries: and let the cautery be of olive oil.
Cuius haec est forma.	Whose this form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you are able to bear it that you touch the tip of the foot with a needle: then do so with a needle-point cautery.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	That if they ascend pains as far as the knees, or other joints, and many times this happens: then cauterize it over all the knee with three cauteries, or four from all sides, with this same cautery of cloves.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If, however, you need many more of this antidote, then cauterize yourself.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not submerge your hand in the antidote, but instead dip it only in the skin's thickness.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If, however, the pains rise to the knees and back: then administer what we have said about the antidote in our chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	That if the pains are only in the hands, then pierce around a flame, as the two lines resolve.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If, however, some pain remains in the fingers, then pierce them, over every knuckle a point, and over the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If, however, the pains rise after days to the elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both completely.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not leave the sick person without treatment, from the taking in of medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good regime is established and the phlegm is expelled, it will be healed with the help of God and this antidote.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	On the Method of Causing a Burns to Heal.
Caput XLVII.	Head 57.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a Rupture has occurred in the groin, and the intestine has descended, or has touched the testicle, and it is beginning to be close to the scrotum: then you should order the sick person to cease from his food on that day only.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And he should use laxatives so that the stool falls from his bowels.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and order him, that he hold his breath, until he has gone out, or until the testicle appears, or the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then let him reduce the person with your fingers, and mark with the causticum at the edge of the Rupture above the pelvis, with a mark whose extreme is equal to a half-circle to the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then light the fire of the causticum, which has this shape, until it becomes white, and throw off sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then let him reduce the intestine, or the testicle to its opening.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then let the attendant place his hand on the wound, so that it does not come out of the intestine: and you have already opened between the legs of the patient, and placed under him the pulley, and serving as another over his legs, and another over his chest which holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the cautery on the wound, your hand standing straight with the cautery.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold him, until you succeed in getting to the teeth: or else try again with another force, if you do not succeed in getting to them with the first one all the way to the teeth.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe that the intestine does not come out in the hour of your cauterization, so that you do not burn it, and let it go through it into the sick or death, or great evil.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not succeed in getting to the teeth with the cautery, your operation is not effective.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery of infants be fine, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care with the other unguents until he is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the sick person lie on his back for forty days, until the wound has closed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you provide for him food according to the length of his healing time, which softens his stomach: so that he does not lose the intestine by effort and defecation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he should rise after forty days, then administer loose ligaments that have been made, and hold him for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And let him stay away from work, and with full food and drink, and with loud speaking.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he uses this regimen, so does he heal with whole healing.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will speak about the healing of ruptures with an incision in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When, however, ruptures happen in the rest of the flesh, and are beginning, and do not add to them, then cauterize his rupture with round cautery according to its quantity: and let it be as dry from then on as the third part of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then care for himself, since we have said: and do not be drawn away.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some had said first: that he be cauterized with a triangular cautery, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	Afterwards it is signed with encaustrum and put on the line which lies across the back of the rupture, and another line down below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with the cautery.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But first the cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	The way to cauterize in pain because of a fall, or because of percussion.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 58.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When it happens to some member by a fall, or because of percussion: and this pain persists for a long time, and does not yield to treatment: then it should be cauterized with the Pointed Cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery be to any member according to its size, and its health, and weakness, and its strength, and its twist, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If then he is healed by first cauterization, it is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	But if not: then repeat over him the cautery.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	Because of the custom of these pains is that they should change from one member to that which approaches it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Why it should be that those members should be cauterized until the sick one is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	The way to cauterize in Leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	But the lepers are often cauterized with a hot iron.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the species of leprosy, which is produced by putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: so that you carefully consider the way to cauterize it.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If then Leprosy is resistant and you have treated it with the same cautery that we have said and it has not fallen, and does not stick: and if you wait for the disease to include a corruption on the whole complexion of it: then cauterize it over the head five cauteries: one in the middle of the hairline, and the second below it towards the front at the end of the hair, and two above two horns, and one behind the cheekbone.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And lastly bandage your hand slightly with cautery, until it impresses a rough impression on the throat, and the membranes are dislocated from it; so that the exhalation of large vapors is eased from it, and the cauterization is also applied above the spleen, according to what preceded.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if the leprosy has already spread on the sick person and appears manifestly: then it is necessary that you should apply the above-mentioned cauterizations, which we have mentioned in the head, and cauterize also on the tip of the nose, and two cauterizations on the two cheeks, and two cauterizations on the two ears, and two cauterizations on the two shoulders, and six on the back, and one great one on the loins near the tail end, and one above it, in the middle: and two on the breasts: namely, one on each breast, and two on the knees: one on each knee, and two on the arms, and two on the cubits of the arms, and two on the tender parts of the chest: and cauterize also on all the joints, from the joints of the fingers of his hands and feet: and cauterize also on all the heel of his feet and knuckles of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And let you be careful of the nerves that are above the heel of the foot, so that you do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And when one is cauterized with the cautery on the bone of the jaw, and with another on the bone of the stomach, and with another on the spine.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And you should know that the more you add cautery, the greater the benefit is, and the more it cures.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And you should know that a sick person does not feel pain in the cauterization, as they do when they are healthy: for this reason, his body is already stupified.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that the cauterizations should be of a certain size and thinness according to the limbs and joints: for what has preceded from the appearance of the instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the cauterizations with a paste of herb flour mixed with honey, and with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	To cauterize while stupor persists.
Caput L.	The Head.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When a limb is numb and does not respond to medication, oils, plasters, or poultices; then, the limb that is numbed should be cauterized according to the degree of its numbness or the extent of its pallor.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And place your caustic where it will penetrate slightly into the depth of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for the limb with ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And at times when cauterization occurs due to some numbness that happens in the hand or foot, in the vertebrae of the back near the exit of nerves that move that limb: and the numbness is relieved.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But do not be hasty about it, unless you are knowledgeable in the anatomy of limbs, and the exit of nerves that move the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	The mode of cauterization by Albucasis.
Caput LI.	The Head.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albucasis is applied and does not produce any effect with medical techniques; then, apply a deep caustic slightly to the area, according to the thickness of the skin, until the color changes and the tone is relieved.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for the limb with wheat flour, and with rose oil, and with leaves of arglosh (a type of herb), and with pigeon blood, and with hen blood; let one part be used; all these things are to be mixed together, and spread on a cloth, and adhered to the area until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	The mode of cauterization for cancer.Dei quoque discentia, si non potest sanari cum medicinis, n
Caput LII.	The Head.And from the teaching of others, if it cannot be
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning, and the limb needs to be held still; then, cauterize the limb with a caustic that forms a circle around it, as it turns.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	But the wise have said that it should be cauterized with the last caustic in the middle.Et si forte uoluitur, et non potest sanari cum medicinis, noli u
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	But I do not consider this suitable: for I fear it will ulcerate: and I myself have seen it happen a few times.Et si forte uoluitur, et non potest sanari cum medicinis, noli u
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better that it be cauterized around its circumference with a circle, as we have said: or with many cauterizations.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	On the mode of cauterizing on the abdomen.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When anyone has an abdication, and is delayed in maturity, or is doing it for no reason, or because of old age, so that it is little blood, or because of time, and the pulse does not hasten in the maturation of abdication, then cauterize around its circumference with a few cauterizations by puncturing.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then let go of it.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will hurry up with the maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	But if you want to pierce it with a knife and then cauterize it, then this is the form of the cautery.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of abdication until it penetrates the skin; and let the cautery be behind it so that it does not get weak, so that the course of blood is eased.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then take care of the patient until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	On the mode of cauterizing on a sore corroding.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIIII.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A sore does not corrode unless it is a member that walks and corrodes the member itself; as fire devours dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	But if you see a sore that tolerates cautery with fire, then let the many cauteries be small and large, and suit them to the place where the sore is;
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize the member from all parts until you eradicate the whole corruption, and do not leave anything hidden in it.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then let go of the member for three days, and put sulfur mixed with oil on the places that have been cauterized; until all the escarments are eradicated, and all corruption.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then take care of the patient with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	But if you see that after three days the flesh is born healthy and there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then apply again cautery to that which remains in corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And when the corrosion is healed, it is sometimes cured with acute medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For it itself rises up at the place of cauterization.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	However, cauterization with fire is faster in action: and indeed I have already said that cauterization with acute medicine is division: so take it there when it is digested.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	On the mode of cauterizing in clefts, and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter 50.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	This affliction of the lower parts of the feet often occurs; and it is a gross disease, which affects the foot after filtration.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And there are two ways of applying cauterization: with fire, and with warm water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	How much, then, is it with fire, as the fire of a brand is like the feather of a fowl: which let be from iron, according to the quantity that contains the cleft from all parts: and let the edge be slight.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then deposit the burned thing on the cleft.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then, with the thumb, rotate the thumb with cautery around the cleft, until the cauterization reaches the depth of the cleft: and let it be for three days, until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then bind the thing with soft silk threads, crushed with salt: and let it be for the night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For he will himself be removed from his roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with a soothing ointment of flesh, until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not converted, and often happen on the surface of the body, especially in the hands and feet: then apply to them cauterization with warm water: and it is, as you may get a tube from iron, or steel, or from a fowl's feather: and deposit it on the cleft, or on a hard thing.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then throw into the tube a little quantity of warm water: hold your hand, and rotate it with your thumb, so that the edge of the tube is pressed into the root of the cleft, and let the warm water find its way into the depth of the cleft: and expect for a while on the tingling of the warm water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then let go of him, for the clamp should be removed with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	So do it with them one by one, until you have done all of them in the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then take care of them after they are cut off, with that which generates flesh from the scar.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	The way to cauterize during a tremor.
Caput LVI.	Chapter LVI.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When it happens to someone that there is a tremor due to cold in the nerve, or from a quartan fever, or some other thing: then one should cauterize the person with four cauterizations, or five on the back of the spine, and between each vertebra with a cauterization, and in his pit with a cauterization, and over his stomach with a cauterization.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For a tremor ceases with an olive oil cauterization, and a feverish condition speeds up with health from cold.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	The way to cauterize according to Albatar.
Caput LVII.	Chapter LVII.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	When certain aliments are expelled from the body, that is, pustules which arise from corrupt dry matter.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Then, when they first appear, they should be cauterized with a fine wood cautery on the whole head of the pustule, whose tip is lit with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of aristochnoke long.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lenticular cauterizer.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And when they are cauterized with iron, at first their expulsion follows this mode: and they do not increase: and they break up their excess, healing from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However, it should be done after evacuation with phlebotomy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	The way to cauterize during a blood flow from an artery in the ulnar.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	This often happens with a blood flow from an artery which is cut at the ulnar, either from outside, or at the incision of a pimple, or from cauterizing a member, and similar to them: and it is difficult to remove it away.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	So then, when this happens to someone, then grasp the artery with your hand and place your finger on top of it: and tie it tightly until the blood is blocked beneath your finger and nothing comes out of it.
