Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put on a small amount of olive oil fire, and a great deal more: and blow over them until they are very hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from them one, or small, or large, second knuckle and the place where the artery is broken, and place the fire on top of it; then remove your finger quickly: and hold the fire, until the blood comes off.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	That if it is expelled when you remove your finger from the artery's opening, and extinguish the fire, then take another fire quickly, from those that are prepared on fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	So then do not stop doing this with one after the other, until the blood comes off.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And be careful, so that you do not burn the fire that is there, and misfortune happens to another illness.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know, that when blood flows from an artery, it is then impossible to stop it: especially when the artery is large, unless with four measures.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with fire, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it is not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its ends contract, and the blood comes off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or is bound with a strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or are placed on top of medicine by virtue, which stops the flow of blood, and is tied with a decreasing constrictive pull.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever performs this dissection with a ligature, and constriction with a cloth, or position of burning things, and like things, does not give it a complete cut, unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if this happens to someone, and there is no present doctor, nor medicine: then begin with the position of the index finger on top of the wound's opening, as we have described, and constriction of it very much, until the blood is blocked from the upper part of the wound, and over the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And do not move the finger, above it with cold water always cold, until the blood is congeleth, and groweth, and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And while you are considering this, what does it need from the poultice or medicine?
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	First part end.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	The Book of Surgery of Albucasis Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Incision, Puncture, and Bleedings on Wounds and Similar Matters.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have said in the first chapter, all disease can be cured with fire as a cautery and medicine to burn together, and the causes of it, its causes, and instruments for doing it, and forms of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I set out those chapters from the top to the bottom.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I shall proceed in this chapter in the same way: that is, to allay the curiosity of the quester as to what it seeks.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, you should learn, O sons, that fear which is in the first chapter regarding cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for that, you should be more cautious regarding the matter, since in the operation described in this chapter, often drops of blood fall with which life is lost at opening the wound, or incision on a pustule, or opening an exit, or curing a wound, or extracting an arrow, or incision on a stone, and those similar matters: from all of which trembling and fear arise, and death falls in many of them.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, do not let that concern you, for when it falls on you in this art of surgery with the modes of human weakness, in various diseases.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For from them is one who becomes irritated with his illness, and is less concerned about death: because of the severity which he finds in his illness and the length of his disease.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when illness is accompanied by fear, which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And from these he gives you his scalpel, and tells you to use it in hope of healing, but his sickness is harmful.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore it should not be that you agree to him who comes to you from these, whose way is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And be your caution much greater than your desire and your avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presumptively claim anything from him unless after certain knowledge which confirms among you that which he attains to the success of praise.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And so you may heal all your sick patients, by prognosis and indication concerning that where there is healing.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in him is the aid of you to gain fame and glory and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O son, with his understanding, and may he not take away from you his guidance and inspiration: for it is in his hands.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I have arranged this Chapter distinguishing it by Chapters, after what preceded in the Chapter of Cautery from the hair to the feet: that you may be relieved in your request which you wish from him, and where you need it.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Of the Cure of Water which is added to the heads of boys.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You should know that this illness often occurs in boys at the time of circumcision: or when the midwife tightens the head of the boy without lightness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it also happens for an obscure cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I have not seen this illness in any other than in boys; and I would see all of them die, for this reason therefore I have quit the operation to them.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I have seen a boy of these whose head was swollen with water, and the head became magnificent every day, until he could not sit on himself, by the size of his head; and the moisture increased, until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture, or gathered between the skin and bone: or gathered under the bone over the sinus.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in that, if there is moisture between the skin and bone, and the pus is small, then you should find a crack in the middle of the head in width: and the length of the crack is almost two knots, until the moisture runs.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the shape of a little knife.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	But if the moisture is increased and the pus is larger, then place two cracks, according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is under the bone, and there is a sign of it, that you see the scalps open from all sides: and when you press it with your hand towards the inside, it does not disappear from before you: then it is necessary for you to find in the middle of the head three cracks, according to this way.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision has been made, remove all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then tighten the cracks with rags and powder.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then immerse it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the ligaments, and care for the neck with linen bandages, and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not stop tightening the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the sick with dry food of little moisture, until their members are comforted, and the wound heals.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another way to make an incision is to consider where the pus appears in size, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For when it is more in the back, or in the forehead, or on the right, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	So go up with the incision where you see the pus and the water fills: and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, so that you do not hit an artery, and does not happen a flow of blood, and the sick dies from that flow with the discharge of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Of the arteries that are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When a cataract occurs to the eyes or to the chest, and it has been there for some time, and does not respond to medical treatment: then the last resort is to cut these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when you are going to incise these two veins, let the sick person's head be covered so that they do not see.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then prepare the place with a rough cloth so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the sick person should tie their neck with whatever cloth they have.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the pulse is beating.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places are those that are behind the depressed ears: and rarely隠れたり, except in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with caustic on each: and cut both with a sharp knife, while looking into the mouth: and let it be done across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you see any blood vessels, insert the needle under the artery, and cut it from above with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be almost two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is incised, blood flows out with the pulse, which rises to the inside at a regular interval.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If, however, the artery does not appear in the sense, then you must measure the distance from the ear to the length of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with caustic and find until it reaches the mouth.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what should be released from the blood, is six minutes, and perhaps you release more or less of it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All this depends on the quantity that appears to you from the vein and is filled with blood.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider towards the eye.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	If there is anything stuck in the throat, then cut it so that it does not cause a sore throat: and tie the eye with a linen cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the person with ointment until he is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	Regarding the extraction of the arteries, which are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a person has an old headache, or sharp cataracts due to acrid humors and heat in the lacunae of the temples, or ancient soda, harsh, and similar things: and he is treated with the methods of medicine, and this does not work: then we are experienced in these ailments by extracting the arteries from the temples, or cauterizing them, as we have related.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the mode of operation in extracting them is, that the sick person whose hair is on the temples should be shaven, and the artery apparently visible in the temple should be intended.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	And it itself is shown to you from its pulse, and rarely hides unless in a few people, or when there is a sudden change in temperature.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it hides from you, then the sick person should tie his head with any kind of cloth: and then bring the dry place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or wet the place with hot water until it appears to you in a manifest way.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take a thin knife, which was made little before.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape with it the skin easily until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then throw it into her a hook, and extract it upward until you pull it out from the skin, and let it ooze from under any part of it.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the artery is thin: then turn it around with the end of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from that part according to how long its ends are stretched out, and turned in opposite directions, and do not cause a flow of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it does not cut, and if it does not separate, the blood will not rise deeply.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then pour out the blood from six ounces, up to III.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then it should be tied to it in two places with a double thread, strong, from silk: or from a string of alhohod, so that it does not adhere to it before the consolidation of the wound, and blood flows.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut through the superfluity, which is between two ligaments.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do that at that time, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cauldron until the nose, with a knife: until the extremities are cut, and remains in place of that work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And this work is better if he has a fever or a hot skin.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For the cauldron is from those that remain to finish the moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better to cut.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the extraction of the arteries, so that the place may be filled with an old cooking: and they are placed on top of it feathers made haphazardly.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the solution with dry medicines, which make the flesh grow, and with liniments, until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	That if while you are working a flow of blood comes out from an artery, then come closer to cut it off with a cauldron, or to fill the place with a poultice: and grasp your hand tightly, until the blood is cut off.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	That if there is nothing of those for you at hand, then place your finger on the spot, until the blood has frozen.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And soak the place with water of chilly temperature, until the sharpness subsides, and is clasped tightly according to what is necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And from that which is lighter and easier to extract the artery, it is, as a cauldron with two knives has: and the sharpness of the two knives is like an almond.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, they are much less sharp than the two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are sharp, like the two knives, it is better that they have coldness: and they do not cut into the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	And so if there is some roughness in them, a heat of fire is held in them, and the flesh is cut off quickly: so this work is better for every work, lighter, and easier to do.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And make a space between the two scalpel-like objects according to the thickness of the finger, after you have marked the two places with fire; and put the both on fire widely until they come to the mouth, and fall together in the two places: that it may become longer what is between the extremities of it.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For with this cauldron they do not harden when placed inside.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cauldron.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	¶ Of the care for the course of acute tears and persistent tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When there are persistent tears and the course of the tears from the eyes runs from the top of the head outside: and does not bring anything into them of medicinal care with medicines, and their eyes become red, and feel a movement in their front as if it were the movement of ants: and their eyelids are heated because of the acute tears: then the elderly people used to cure them with this operation, and they called this cure Ense.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is, as you command to the sick to shave the hair that are on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then cut in the forehead three slits equidistant according to the length of the forehead: and make the length of the slit almost like two fingers, and one slit be equidistant in length to the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second be according to the length of half a snake's move, and the third from the other part: and take care not to cut the arteries which are on both sides: and make your hand extend from the continuation of the two mandibles, and make the space between each incision equal to the quantity of three joined fingers: and have you prepared a sponge fragment, or many dry fabrics, with which you dry the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce the spatula between the two acute ends, whose subsequent form is as follows:
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is from the temporal part, until the second incision: and scrub with it all the skin which is between the two incisions, with chafe, which is on the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then also make this from the incisions middle to the second incisions.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract this bone also, and introduce into the first incision again another instrument called a sharp chisel, soft on one side, not sharp on the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And put his sharp side opposite the flesh attached with skin, and his soft side opposite the bone: and push him, until it reaches the middle opening: and cut off all the tools that come down from the head to the eyes: except that it continues the incision until that which appears from the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then make also this in the middle opening until another opening.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when an equal quantity of blood has run out, express the places from the clotted blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then put into every opening a chisel made of hardened iron, and put on them flints dipped in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that it does not happen that the blood clotted is hot.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day loosen the ligaments, and administer a strong infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for that with the ointment of Basilicon, and with the others which are treated with wounds: until it is healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	§ Of the treatment of acute lacrimation and cataracts on the eyes from within the head.
Caput V.	Head
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When there occur to anyone acute, sharp, and persistent tears: and his eyes look pale, thin, and their appearance is weak: and the eyelids are ulcerated, and hair falls out from them, and there is a sharp pain in the deep part of the head, and subsequent sneezing: then remove these accidents, that those materials and cataracts do not come, unless they are taken away with many.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the best treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, as you instruct the sick person to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then cut in it one opening in the middle of the forehead, or a little more around the width, and begin from the left side of the time to the right: and let the incision go down to the bone: and extend your hand from the teeth which move at mastication: until when it has been uncovered the bone: and you will dry out all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the fissure with dried old wax, or with linen liniments.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind above with dust: and dip the dust in wine and oil so that hot pussing does not occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you dissolve that, and you will see that the hot pussing is about to begin coming out: then it is necessary that you cut the flesh of the nose, until the baby begins to come out.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then take care of the baby with drying treatment that makes the baby come out: as if you took two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony: and prepare an ointment from it, and administer it to the birth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	The care that falls on gold.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	All that falls on gold is of four kinds: either the mineral rock, or similar rocks, such as iron and lead; or it is a plant, like beans and peas; or it is a liquid substance, like water and vinegar, and similar things; or it is an animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore gold falls on a rock, or a kind of rock that does not contribute to gold and does not grow in gold, expose gold to the sun alone: but if you see a stone, then distill into gold some oil that has been cooked, or put it in mustard.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer the extraction of it, and make it snort with condiments, and rub the nostrils near the coming of sneezing, after you have put on gold-colored bandages from rags, or wool, and spread the gold towards the top.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Many times has this treatment gone out with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not go out, then administer the extraction of it with gentle gestures: whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	But if it goes out with gentle gestures, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer the extraction of it with a slim black hook made from a few twists.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If then he does not come out by that [method], then make a tube from brass; and introduce the extremity of the tube into the ear hole very much, and the resin which is around the tube with softened wax with oil so that there is no wind going except through the tube: then draw it out with your breath in strong吸引.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Indeed, he comes out many times when he hears us [speaking].
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if he does not come out in this way, then take from the ash wood or from the stream, that is, the gluten prepared with which they are wetted, something like it: and set [it] at the end of a stick after you have dried up the ear with [the use of] moisture. Then introduce [it] into the ear hole with ease, after you have removed the wax from the ear with your finger.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	But if he does not come out with all that we have described, then approach to cut off before the feverish heat or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the mode of the incision is so that the phlebotome takes away the blood from the head first: and draw out [it] by the amount of the power of his skill.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the sick person sit between your hands, and turn his ear upward, and find a small hole at the base of his ear where his fat is depressed in the shape of a moon: and make the lunate shape remain until you have reached the rock: then remove it with that  [tool], as far as you can do it with your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then heal the hole from your own hand with haste, and take care of it until it is healed.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If something that has fallen into the ear comes from one grain which grows and swells: then administer extraction of it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not obey you to come out, then take a small, fine straw, according to this form.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And with that administer the cutting off of its species from the grain which has fallen into the ear, and do not consider that it is already moistened by the ear's moisture until you have put on many straws: then draw out it with a hook or with a gentle hand or with suction as we have said, for the extraction of it is comforting.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	In the water that is added to the ear, it should be used by the sick with sternutation first and foremost, and the ear has already been filled with some of the old cooked [water]: and he lies down on his side on top of the ear where the water is.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If so then come out through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of a finger, small, soft, and warm them with fire slightly, and insert one of them into the hole of his ear: and let him sweat on one foot from that part, and hit against one stone with another stone in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	So then do not stop doing that with stones and pebbles, until he comes out all the way with water.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And already he comes out with water so that you take it from a branch or a vine and introduce the end into his ear; and you light the other end with fire, until it is burned well.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then again take another branch, and do this many times, until he comes out all the way with water; and draw it out with a tube according to what has been said above in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction however of an animal that enters into it, if it is a small body like a flea, and similar to it, take care of it as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is a large body, which seems by touch: then administer its extraction with movements and hooks: and the matter of it is easier for all those who hold it in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	In the extraction however of a foal that is born in the ear, when you take care of it with that which we have said in division and in the treatise on distillation, your treatment does not bring about its cure: then you must examine the ear under the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If so then it appears there something of a foal, then extract that with movements, or with a subtle hook.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If there is nothing visible there, then take a cannula, which has this shape, narrow from below, wide from above; and introduce the thin end into the ear according to the quantity that the sick person can bear: then suck strongly with it.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this often, until all the wax has come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If they do not obey you up to the exit, then cover the cannula with wax, as I said on the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	That if they do not go out with it which I have said: then administer the distillations which the ancient ones have experienced in the infection of wax: and you will find that in the book of distillation.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your flow be as it flows with oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose shape is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see do yourself from silver or brass, narrow from below, where sits the small hole, wide from above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	So that it is pushed out what is in the concern of the cannula, let it be made of brass and be crooked.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you want, take a radium, and wrap it with a cotton wisp that is gently wet; then pour oil, or liquid, or what you want from these medicines into the cannula: and let it be in the ear: then insert the radium with the cotton at the top, and squeeze it slowly by your hand, until it pushes out oil in the concern of hearing, and feels it inside the sick person: and that which has been poured into the ear, may already be warmed a little with fire: and let there not be anything that distills in it quickly: for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the treatment of the loss of hearing due to an injury of gold.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	When certain young men come out of their mothers' wombs unharmed.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And has also happened to some men that they have wax in their ears due to a cut or flesh born in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this oileation sometimes occurs in a deep hole of the ear, which does not follow on from the injection: and when it comes to occur at the outer holes a little, and follows on from the injection.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Now that which occurs in a deep hole of the ear, and what does not follow on from the view, is difficult to cure in many positions.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which follows on from the injection, it is necessary that you should place gold-plaster on the ear and examine it: then if you see the oileation apparent, open it up with a very fine awl, of whose shape this is one that follows on; let the end of it be in that part where there is some little width, of which some sharp part is: and let the other part of the awl be soft on both sides: so that it does not wound the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If then the oileation is born from the flesh at the top of the ear: then hold it with a very fine hook, and cut it easily with a sharp instrument, until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	That if the oileation is in a deep place of the ear: then take a very fine ray, smooth it, and heat it slightly with fire: then send it into the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If then you feel the oileation with it, that it is located in a weak place of the ear, be careful to open it up easily: and carefully, so as not to wound the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put into the ear a liquid second to the quantity of width of the hole which you have opened with Egyptian ointment: leave it for several days, until you are sure that the wound is healed.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take liquid, and pour it into rose water, and powder it on top of it, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	That if you see the ear already blistering: then it is necessary that you should take liquid out, and let it with the liquid which you have used in the green ointment made with rose oil, until it is healed by itself: and then take care of the ear until it is cured.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If however there is a flow of blood: then dip the sponge, or cloth into cold water and put it on her: and use the remainder of the cure, which has cut off the flow of blood predicted in the treatise on distillation.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	On the Treatment of Athers of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Head VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These are Althelis that occur in the eyelids when they are wet, and dry when they are.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore you should hold them with tenails: or with an iron hook, and strike them with an awl from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place on the affected areas ground pepper.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If however any blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a thin lens cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And cauterize them, it is better after an incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For often they return when some of the roots remain.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned, and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	On the Treatment of Athers in the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	Head IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Often there occurs in the eyelids something that is congealed on Crandin in its strength, and hardness, and because of this it is called Grandin; and is an aggregation of moist grossness in the upper eyelid, and lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Operation on them is, that you consider then, if there is Grandin going out from it, which appears on the eyelid, and move to all parts, and the thing is easy to perform.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Then find on her a slit across the width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape off that skin from all parts with ease, until it bleeds.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then hang her up by the hook, and cut off that one.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If however you are not prepared to cut off that thing, unless after you make an incision slightly in the eyelid, then it will harm that thing which is bad.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If however the slit is large: then aggregate it with a stitch: and care for it, until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is too much, do not let a bad thing come out of it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For he will restore her, and make her flesh grow.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if there is a great hole towards the inside of the ear from the surface inward, then turn the lid upside down and hang the ring with a hook: except that you should cut it and press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	That if the eyelid is stretched by cutting, that does not hurt in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after cutting with salty water: and take care of the place with it when it is inflamed, until the wound heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	§ On the Care of the Eyebrows.
Caput X.	Chapter Ten.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is the grease that is generated in the eyebrows; and it happens very often to boys: and it damages their eyes, and they are afflicted with cataracts in the morning, and they cannot see the light of the sun, because the tears go to them, and therefore they lie on their faces all the time, and sleep on them, and their eyelids are always wet, which has been cured by inflation; and the prominent Axirnath is apparent to the eye, and when you press the spot with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the way that it works is that he puts the sick head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a piece of linen cloth and prepare it with strings, and make from it a loop according to the amount that contains Axirnath from all parts.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then put him on it, and press him with your fingers from all parts, so that the Axirnath is gathered up in the middle of the loop.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of it a wet spot with a sponge that is incident on cracks by width, and there is no larger crack that is made in the depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or you should find the whole skin, until you reach Axirnath; for in many ways Axirnath proceeds from a crack: and with a white sponge, when it has been driven out, it is called Axirnath.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if you do not see the axillae at first in the groove, then you insert a little bit into the groove until the axilla comes out.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then take it out, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then dip the cloth in vinegar and water, and place it on the spot, and tighten it with powder.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are people who put salt on, and place it in the crack so that what remains of the moisture is liquified.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then take care of this, until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if there is a hot swelling at the site, then take care of it with soiled plasters, until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	As for the methods of eye treatment, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft to the eye, so that it does not rub like it should.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11:
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hairs grow out in the eyelids, adding to the natural course of them, and become ingrained: then they hurt the eye, and cause diseases such as constant tears, enlargement of the eyelids, and whiteness, until the cause of destruction of the eye is reached.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And the treatment for Ataxmir eyes, that is, eyes that rub, is treated in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or with a caustic, using fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with acute medicines, according to the precepts given in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or treated by Ataxmir through incisions and suturing.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or with reeds, according to what I say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary that you place the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If so, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: insert now into it, where sits the hair from the lower part of the eyelid, and let the thread go through with a thread from above, and let that be close to the hairs themselves, that is, close to the edge of the eyelid, where the hairs grow out: and pull the thread up with the eyelid, and turn it around.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find in the inner part of the eyelid under the added hairs with the knife incident from the larger tear to the smaller tear.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then pull out the thread, and put under the eyelid a small tuft of wool from wool, or cloth: then mark on the eyelid with the encrustation, which sits like a figure of a leaf of mulberry.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it should be made according to the size and height of the eyelid: for this has been varied in humans.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For from them is he who does not wish that the thread should go out from the eyelid according to the quantity that softens it from the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with the knife find above the two lines that you have marked, and begin from the larger tear to the smaller one, and let there be a groove next to the natural hairs, as is the height of the radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape all of it out.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then bring together with a stitch the two lips, with an aiguille and a thread of fine wool: and wipe away the blood, and let whatever excess remains from the hairs on the two eyelids stick to the two eyelids, with certain things that are slippery, if you wish to do so: and if not, it is not important.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then let go of the stitch and the thread until three or four days: then take care of it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, let go of the hook without a stitch, and take care of it with it, that it dries up and tightens.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid rises by the sigillation of the wound and its aggregation: but a better one will come in the future.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	Thus they taught the method of treatment of Ataxmir in the ancient times.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	Indeed, in it is concern for the sick, and it is from a good operation, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another mode also in Ataxmir: and that is, as signs on the eyelid a figure, which is like the figure of a bay laurel leaf, as we have told.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then wipe the eyelid with three separate or joined hooks according to this form that follows, then cut what exceeds with small blades according to this form, with an equal incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if you are not able to hold the hook, and it does not match: then take an acme in which is a thread, and introduce it into the middle of the figure: and introduce another thread near the larger tear, and a third thread near the smaller tear: and gather between your fingers the threads with an equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then wipe your hand with an equal wiping: and wipe the skin over where is marked the spot, as we have told.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with a stitch: and take care of it, until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if there happens to be a blister on your incision or a crack: but that blister with white of egg, and these similar ones, from a ointment sitting.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And when the eyelids also happen to turn inward so that their hairs come together.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is necessary, then, for you to use on it what we have said in the incision: but the stitch on both sides is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Of the care of Ataxmir with hooks.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And is, as you turn the eyelid and divide the crack which is within, according to what we have told.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then, with art, make two hooks or two thin pieces of wood: whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and whose width is less than a fingernail's breadth: and you have already incision on the extremities of both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then collect it with subtlety on what exceeds the eyelid of the eye, and tightly tie two reeds from both sides with a strong constriction, and let go after a few days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	The skin, however, will die, be degraded, and decompose until it falls away by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If it therefore is delayed, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When it has thus consolidated, remove the eyelid: and the hair no longer prickle.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	This is the form of two reeds which you shall make according to this figure, and in quantity in length and breadth.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	De elewatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.
Caput XII.	Head XII.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	Operation in that is, that you take a fine acme, and insert in it a thread of silk, soft.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then gather together the ends thereof, and tie each with a small knot; and make the length of the threads equal to that of a palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then compose in the Alinxotatus a second thread under it, and tie the ends thereof if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then lay his sick head in your lap, and bring it near the light that the operation may be declared; for it is an operation of subtlety or minuteness.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the acme with the Alinxotatus at the root of the eyelid, and let it penetrate into the eyelid swiftly, until you draw out a natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the hair up above the Alinxotatus: and insert in the Alinxotatus that hair; if one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then take your hand with it, until the hair and Alinxotatus come out of the eyelid with a natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If it is not drawn out with the Alinxotatus, and a hair does not come out with it: then draw out the Alinxotatus downward with a thread which you have composed therein, until the Alinxotatus comes out of the upper opening, and close the eye thereof; then let go the eye for two days, or three, until the hair adheres to its place, and grows on the top thereof.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either attach a long hair from natural hairs, and cut it off with it; or let it go until it grows out after a space, and then cut it off.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	On the treatment of Al-Ashtar's disease which occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Head XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this occurs to the eye, it is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this disease of Al-Ashtar is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	So the accidental one is caused by the union of a wound, or a cut, or cauterization, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the mode of action in it is, that you may find that union, and that you separate its lips, and put into it what is between them from linen, and bind it, until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not necessary that you should use for its cure the things which dry and tighten; for if you do so, Al-Ashtar returns worse than it was: but use for it the things which soften, such as fennel seed; and bathe with water in which has been cooked aloe, and oil: and anoint with it, and apply with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the treasure of your cure is, that you may keep any idea, so that it does not harden, according to its form which it had at first.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we have described is no more than a certain correction of Al-Ashtar, so that the form of the place does not return to what it was altogether.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	On the treatment of Al-Ashtar's disease which occurs in the lower eyelid, and is either a swelling or a contraction upward toward the right or left.
Caput XIIII.	Head XVIII.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This disease of Al-Ashtar which occurs below is the one which is called Al-Ashtar's in truth.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is either natural or accidental. Et haec Alxatrati est quae accidit ex sectione
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	So the accidental one is caused by a wound, or a crack, or cauterization, and similar things. Et haec Alxatrati est quae accidit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And when you have grasped the operation on it, so that you can see two filaments therein, and wet it with flesh, and make it penetrate from the left lacrimal to the right lacrimal until the filament comes into contact with both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh toward the top with a sharp knife, and cut it with a chisel from the side.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns according to what is necessary, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take the beam, and put it in the notch, and turn it with it: and find two notches in the inner side of the eyelid, and are the ends of the two notches from two angles of incision, until they meet and make this figure, and is the Greek letter pi.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then take off that flesh according to its quantity, which is the acute lower side of it, from there that follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then bring together the separated parts: sew them with a woolen thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then take care of them with what I have said, about the soothing medicines and poultices, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if it happens to be from a notch, and stitching, or cauterization: then you should find a flat notch under the eyelids of the hair, also according to what preceded it.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate the two lips with a lint, according to what we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the whole speech about the care of Al-Khazini when it is above, or below, it is as follows: let it run in that operation, according to what was prepared from the form of Al-Khazini.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	It itself is a diverse form: and the prudent craftsman prepares his mind with whatever way it is possible for him, until he makes a figure return to a natural shape, or close to it, and himself sickens, according to what suits him from operation and instruments in various dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Of the adhesion of the eyelid of the eye with the conjunctiva, or cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	And this consolidation sometimes happens in many people so that the upper lid with white of the eye is consolidated and prevents itself from its own natural actions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	It is necessary that you insert the end of the radius under the eyelid and lift it up: or that you extend it with a pin: then cut the adhesion with a very fine spatulum which is not sharp in cutting the spatulum, rather it is slightly blunt: so that the sick one does not stir during the operation, and moves the spatulum, and hurts his eye with its own sharpness: and let your incision be as if you were taking away the adhesion with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and cures the whole adhesion.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then at that time pour into the eye water which is salty, with water cleaning it up: or distill into it from a distilled liquor, from a dissolved tin with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a string of linen: and put over the eye wool infused with alumen: and after three days use a distiller, and with consolidations until it is cured.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	Regarding the incision of the nail and the eminence of the flesh of tears.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	You know that the nail is according to two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is nervous: and it is similar to soft bone, thin.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to frozen moisture of white: which when it touches a hot iron, or a sharp instrument with a hook, tears off, and does not stick to it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds of nails do not begin, except from the greater tear: until they are gradually discovered, until they cover the eye, and prevent light and the movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operation for its incision is: so that the sick one puts his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes, and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then take the nail with a few twists, and extend it to the upper part.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take the nail, and insert it into the hoof with a few twists; then pierce it with an awl or a twig: and fasten the thread strongly to one end of the nail, and fix it in the middle of the hoof: then drive it in with a needle, and tie it with a thread around the hoof, and extend it towards the top: and scrape off with a hair the side of the hoof that follows the pupil, as if you were holding it with a hair until it reaches its tip.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut off the residue in the lacrimal root with a fine chisel or with tiny tweezers; and let go of the natural lacrimal flesh, so that the regular flow of tears is not interrupted by the incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And when the nail is extended with the hook alone: or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then scrape off with a fine chisel, which has this shape.
