Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And beware, so that the chisel does not touch the horn tunic, and a tear does not occur, and the pupil is punched through.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, pour into the eye some crushed salt, or made from a solution of zinc, and let it rest until the next day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then take care for the eyes, with what is necessary, until they are healed.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	That if the hoof is not nervy, and you cannot drive a nail into it, nor can you fix an móng in it; then this kind of hoof treatment with medicines should be carefully applied, and he will heal like a narrative in a division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	That if you want to cut it with a knife, then open the eye of the patient, and take a fine chisel, slightly sharp, according to this form.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And scrape off the upper part of the hoof with a subtle razor.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	That if you see that the eye has become red and inflamed, and it has been impressed by the razor; then pour into the eye from your own tears, made from a solution of zinc or red wine or salt: and rub the eye until the next day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat over himself the operation, until he has entirely removed him.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless there is an opposition to you in his eye a hot apophtheme: then indeed dismiss her, and care for the apophtheme, until he is healed.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation on himself with reasoning, until he is healed.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	But the eminence of the flesh of the eye, if it hurts greatly in the eye a great harm, it should be suspended with an anchor, and cut off from her that part: and do not make the last cut, so that does not happen run of tears.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then drop a rubies in his tear-ducts, or made from zinc, until he is healed.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	Of the incision of Algordainic, and the flesh born in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	It is born when and in some eyes of men there is a red flesh put together, or placed on top, until it covers the pupil, or approaches, or squeezes the eyelids, and perhaps turns the eyelids outward: and is absorbed by the roses of the balastine.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation on her is also, that he puts his sick head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes, and take her off all that flesh with an anchor suitable for it: and hold her with one pince, or grasp.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh first, until he has finished all of him with a scalpel.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And caustica from the eye, so that you do not scar him during the operation: and let your cut be which one you cut off, or with a chisel, which we have mentioned in the incision of nails: or with small tongs, with which the asebel is caught, according to which it will come after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When your cut is complete, and all the Algordainici has been removed, then fill the eye with crushed salt: or distil into it a red powder, and similar drugs that burn: and put on the eye a woolen cloth with alume, so that he is secure from the hot apophtheme.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If something remains of the algyd in your eye, and warm blood flows to it, and you see a red swell: then let go of the eye, and take care of the swelling with it while it is lying there.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then go over the eye with the operation until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And do the same for the flesh added which has happened to the eye from this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	However, it is necessary that you do not interrupt the healing of any weak eye from its natural way, or from an accidental way, while operating with iron: and do not put your hand in any of these operations until it has healed, since this member is tolerant of that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	Regarding the collection of sebaceous matter from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Sebel are red swellings that cover the eye and prevent the performance of surgery: and they weaken the eye with the passage of days.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore you must first consider, if the eye in which there is sebaceous matter is strong, and there is no other illness in it apart from the sebaceous matter: then gather the sebaceous matter.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is, as you have ordered for the sick person, to put his head in your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then hang those swellings with a hook, one or two according to your discretion: and let the hook be thin, double according to this form, or let there be two hooks separated by a double length, according to this form.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then pick them up with slight hook-like things, carefully, and wipe away the blood hour by hour until they have healed over, and dissolved: and do not leave the eye with its edges wet.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your operation be in the middle of the day before the sun, and be steady in your operation very much: so that you do not fall except on those swellings.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have emptied it, then pour into the eye clear water or red water: so that its own sharpness may corrode what is left of the sebaceous matter.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	If, however, you are not able to collect that whole [amount of] medicine at that time, then bind the eye with that which soothes the eye's pain; and leave him for a few days until his pain subsides: and keep him away from heat [contingent] on the eye. Then repeat over him in the same way again until he is cured.
Et haec est forma forficis.	And this is the form of the knife.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	The treatment of arsy-varsy [a kind of fever] to the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	They call the treatment for arsy-varsy with a funnel, which they apply with caustic or sharp medicine, as per the previous description.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	If he does not recover, then there is no skill in it: unless you discover the pus  [the cause of the arsy-varsy] under his birthmark and remove all the moisture that is in it and the pus until the hole is exposed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When, then, the hole is exposed, and you see corruption or blackening in it, then shave him with an instrument, the form of which is as follows:
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called Shaving of the Head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Let it be made of iron rod, and let the head be round like a wheel, so that it is pierced with a file or fine chisel   [a type of tool]: and place him on the site of the corruption of the bones.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then roll him between your fingers, and press your hand upon him moderately, until you know that that corruption has now been shaved off: and do it sometimes.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the site with dried-out styptic   [a type of medicine].
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If, then, the site has healed, and flesh has grown there, and the scar has disappeared   [the scar indicating a healing]: and remains for forty days, and does not return to its former state or cause any irritation: then know that he has been cured.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	If not, then there is no skill in it except to apply a funnel to the nose, as per this form.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is so that you remove the second bone with iron or sharp medicine; and when the bone has been removed, then take this kind of hammer, its end being made of iron in the form of a triangle: and make its wood an elongated pyramid up to its end, as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then put this above the bone itself: and let it be near the tear: and extend your hand from the eye a little.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then rotate your hand with the hammer, until it penetrates the bone and feels weak: by this you will see a vapour emerge from it when it holds its hand over its nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then restore the place with sharp medicine that dries up, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When then does the flesh grow and the place hardens: then the substance that flowed outside returns to the nose: so it is lighter over the weak one.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	De reductione eminentiae Oculi.
Caput XX.	The Reduction of Ocular Prominence.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye emanates with its entirety, and does not occur to damage the sight or decrease it: then you should remove the weak one: then let blood be drawn: then put vents on the skin without scarring, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then put over the eye a lotion that is made of oak, and of aloe, and of pine resin, and of sarcocolla.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then tie the eye down from above over a plaster with various powders.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the method of the powders is this: that you take soft cloths, many and double, each cloth out of four: make from them many: then put them one on top of the other, according to the quantity that the eye requires: then tie them together with a stiff cloth, strong fastening.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And again put vents on without scarring.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the vents, and let the eye rest during the day and at night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If however the ligature again softens, then you should tie it very tight: then remove the ligature after a day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If you see that the eye is now red again with new wounds of the sheath, it is good; and if not, then apply again plaster, and dust, and tighten, and wettings, until healthy.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	§ On the Incision of the Sheath.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	If a disruption occurs in the sheath of the eye, then let it be cut and removed outside the eyelids like a grain of wheat, and let it be shaped like a human form because of it, and let it be incised: then the operation on it is, according to what: and that, so that you insert the acumen into the root of the eye from below to above.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then introduce another ακουμ (acumen) which is at the place where there are two nerves from the lacrimal side, and let it penetrate; and release that other one according to its placement.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then incise the place of the double nerve, and tie with it the side of the sheath around the ακουμ; and tighten it much.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then remove the ακουμ , and place on the eye wool that is infused with albumen on the whites of the eye; and release it, until the nerve drops with the sheath.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care for the eye that comforts it, until its wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And when the sheath is tightened all around with a circle of cloth so as to give the eye great prominence.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then it is pierced with a thin awl that reaches to the depth of the eye, and moistened with albumen, and drops down, and enters immediately; then tighten it, until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	§ On the Treatment of Alconostia.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This ailment called Alconostias, is not unless it is a deposit, which is gathered in the eye, similar to water that has dropped down, and it is not itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the way of operation in it is, so that you make the sick sit on a prepared seat, or straight.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take its head in your hands from the two sides, and move it so that you do not see the deposit coming down to the lower part of its eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then stop it from flowing out and let the light be made whole; and let the sick person see things as they are seen. And if it does not flow down to the lower part, know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	But if the descent is not prepared with him as we have said, then make him sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a very fine spatula and find it with him above the horny layer a little bit towards the edge of the joining with the cornea in the crown, until it comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When it has come out then distill into the eye hot water in which you have mixed honey: or water in which you have already boiled wheatgrass and honey; and then let the rest of the cure take place, until it is healed.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	Of the cure of water that comes out of the eye, or a waterfall.
Caput XXIII.	CHAPTER XXIII.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have already spoken about the kinds of water, and which is suitable for piercing by revealing and explaining, then take the same water according to its suitability for healing.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then it is necessary that you make the sick person sit between your hands square-wise, opposite the light, near the sun: and bind the eye of the healthy hand, and tighten it tightly: then with your right hand palm the eye of the sick person if the eye in which the water is is on the left: or with your left hand, if the eye is on the right.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take in your right hand almagest (a kind of mineral), if the eye is on the left: or in your left hand, if the eye is on the right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then put the end of the almagest a little bit towards the crown by the thickness of the radius in the same whiteness of the eye apparent tear: then push the almagest with force; and you will feel that the almagest has already come to the tear.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that there be a measure of the journey of the almagest to the depth, a space which is from the pupil to the end of the darkness: and this is the crown of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You shall cut off this eye, because of the clarity of the corneal membrane.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then put on the almagra until such time as it reaches the place where the water is.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press down on yourself with one hand after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If then the water has descended at once, then he sees that eye at once, and the almagra in his own eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then you rest for a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If then the water has descended, then put it down again, except that the almagra comes out.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When then does it stop, and does not rise up again: then pull out the almagra easily: and you relax your hand little by little.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve in the water some of the clear salt of the lens: and wash the inside of the eye with it.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then put out all the eye with a cloth, or a woolen yarn immersed in oil and stained with albus: and bind it up with it so that the eye is healthy.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	But we, and those who are of our time, put over it a finely-ground chalk mixed with albus.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	That if the almagra does not obey you at the entrance to the eye because of its hardness, since it is from a man whose eye is very hard: then you should take the plant called Alberidge, which has this form:
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Then open with it the connection only for a little while, and do not put your hand at all into the hole: and is there not except that you make the way for the almagra to the small opening.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the almagra, following what we have said before.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And when you have finished your work, prepare for the sick person an awkward bedroom in which he may sleep on his back in a dark room: and prevent him from all movements, and from coughing: and let him eat that food by which nature nourishes him: and do not move his head to the right or left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let it rest until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then remove it from that dark house and test its vision; and make him see things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the ligament up to the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it is not necessary that he make it do the work of cure at the time of the operation or immediately after the incision; but it is necessary that he keep it apart: for the water rises quickly through a slanted surface.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	But if it happens that the swelling is warm: then you should open his eye before the seventh day: and make straight that which is wrong, so that it may be right when it has rested; then you shall test his vision, and put it on his mouth where his vision goes under while he rests those days, while he is in that dark house.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then let him go out of the house little by little, and let him walk about in his rooms.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that the pupil is not exempt from vision sometimes: then he should dare to look at the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed some of those who are from Al-Ayyelah have come to us, who said: "It was done in Al-Ayyelah that the eye was pierced, so that the water comes out.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	But verily I have not seen anyone in your land do such a thing; and I have not found it written in any of the ancient books; and it is possible that it is new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the shapes of the eyes, so that they may stand over them who do not know them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be made of pure brass; and let their edges be of the same delicate triangular shape, and the acute point.
Formae magda.	The shapes of the eye.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	Regarding the cure for the birthmark that is born on the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	When and how do they grow on the nose: from which there is something that is like a scorpion with many feet; and from it is the flesh of cancer that is hard, pale-colored, and fuzzy; and from it is the soft meat that is not pale-colored.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	In the part that is soft from among these flesh, not fraudulent nor cancerous, you should make the sick person sit with his hands opposite the sun, and open his nostrils and insert hooks into those flesh: then pull them towards the outside, and cut what you have gathered with a thin sharp blade from one side, until you know that all the flesh has been removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	That if anything remains of it from which removal is not possible: then shave that with one sharp tool easily until no more remains of it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If, however, blood rules over you, or an infection is hot: then oppose it with what is needed: or it is from malignant sores, then approach it with cauterization, until the blood stops flowing, and all flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then pour into the nose after cutting vinegar, and water, or wine.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If, however, the nose is opened, and moisture proceeds from it up to the palate, then you should know that he is already well.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If, however, the moisture does not penetrate, as should be the case, then you should know that flesh is born inside the upper bones of the nose, to which the cutting tool does not reach.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Then you should put a thread of linen with some thickness, and make many nodules on it: and place between each nodule the length of a finger or less: and the sick person should bring one end of the thread into his nose with a jaw, or with whatever is possible for him to do after he has done himself like this: and he should smell it, until he reaches the palate, and comes out onto his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And many times indeed young men do this thing like this in school: and it is an easy thing for him who wants to do it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place the two ends of the thread, one end that goes out over the nose, and the other that remains in the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then apply a massage to the flesh with nodules which are on the string.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Then apply a massage to the flesh with nodules which are on the string.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then take off the string: and put into the nose after abstinence of blood the liquid which you have imbibed with the Egyptian ointment: do this three days, or more, until the ointment has eaten up all that remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then put into the end of the matter a plummifed tube in the nose for a few days, until it is healed.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If however the cure requires that which dries up, use that.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For the making of a poultice for the head, when with it are distilled oil and other medicines into the nose, make that of silver or brass: which is like a little lantern, opened as an oyster: and its outlet likewise.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed tube, like a reed.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the oyster of the instrument for making a poultice for the head, is full, and closed: which has at the end a handle, by which you hold it, when you heat it in the oil, or what you wish to put into it, and fluid things.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	On the treatment of the nose.
Caput XXV.	Head XXXV.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Theul often grows in the end of the nose, and becomes larger and more noticeable with the days going by, until it makes a sort of crust.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And for this, at the beginning of its appearance, you should cut off all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then put over the place, or caustic, or medicine that burns where it is.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If however the cutting away of it is slow until it becomes larger, then consider, if it is hard and dull in colour and not very sensitive: then do not touch it with iron: for it is a kind of cancer.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	Often has been seen that which incised the flesh of man and made thereon a bad sore, and has happened from it great mischiefes to the one who had it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the apoplexy is mild and not discolored and you see that an incision can be made in all of it, then clean the sick part and make the incision without fear or anxiety, and heal the place along with it until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	On the suture of the nose, lips, and ears.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26. On the suture of the head.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You know that when there is a rupture of the continuity of one of these cartilage pieces, surgery is little use unless in certain individuals.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary that when such a thing happens to someone, you should consider whether it is a recent wound with its blood: and then add the pain of the wound to the suture: and then heal the wound itself until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the rupture has separated the lips and made one side healthy while leaving another unhealthy part, then it is necessary to remove all of the skin on that side until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then add the two lips together with the suture and tighten them and sprinkle dragon's blood on it and crushed olibanum: and put a fragment of hardened plaster on it, and some other piece of consolidated plaster: and let it be bound for two days or three.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then remove the dressing and change the medicine: and let it go until the threads separate by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then heal the wound with ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of the suture is that you add the solution of continuity, or with a thread as we have told you about the suture of the eye: or you add the solution with a thread, as I have told you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	On the removal of bumps from the lips.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27. On the head.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people have hard bumps similar to small grains of herbs inside their lips, and some smaller ones, and larger ones.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore, when you have turned the lips inside out, and found all of the bumps, and suspended them by a thread, and cut them off from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the place where the incision has been made with dried earth, until the blood is dried up.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then clean it with vinegar and treat the spot with that, in which there is a staph, until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	A wound that has come from cutting through the flesh near the gums.
Caput XXVIII.	Head XXXVIII.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	しばしば口唇に肉がはみ出し、古い人はこれをabulusと呼んだ。
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	It should be suspended with a hook; or you should hold it with tongs, and cut it at the root of its attachment, and let the blood run or the blood flow.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then put on top of the place where the incision was made, or other dry powder that is astringent, to dry it up.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	If that same flesh returns after treatment, for it often does, then cut it a second time and causticate it; but it does not return after the application of the caustic.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	The shaving of teeth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	Head XXIX.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	When the teeth are gathered in the surface from within and from outside, and between the gums there are rough parts, and sometimes they corrode and turn yellow, causing the teeth to become rotten through that corruption, which is called "dentinous" dentin.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	It should be so that you can sit the ill person between your hands, and their head in your lap, and grind the tooth and the gum where you see the nerve, and any similar material like sand: until none remains of it, and likewise for yellowing, rotting, and citrifying, and other defects until they are clean.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If then what is taken out from the beginning of shaving is good: and if not, then shave them again another day, and a third time, until you have come to the end of your working in it.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And know that the tooth is sensitive to different types of blades, and to various shapes: second, that the blade with which you cut the tooth from below is different from the blade with which you cut between the teeth, according to the shapes.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these forms of razors are with you prepared, which you see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	On the extraction of pain from teeth.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30: Head.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary that you treat the tooth with all your skill and remove it with difficulty.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For the tooth does not yield easily when it is extracted; for the substance is delicate: until, when there is no excuse for extracting it, then you should extract it when it is weak, so that it may harden, and certify with you the complaining tooth.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	For often the pain deceives the weak one, and he supposes that the pain is in the tooth and extracts it himself: afterwards, the pain does not retreat until the weak tooth is extracted.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	For we have already seen this from the operation of bloodletting.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When, therefore, the complaining tooth is certified with you, then it is necessary that you make a incision around the tooth with the scalpel, in which there is some of the power, until it is broken: then move it with your fingers, or with subtle forceps, little by little, until it is wriggling.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place there large knots on the spot in a good position, and the head of the wound between your knees: which you held firmly so that it did not wiggle: then draw out the tooth along its length, so as not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If, however, it does not come out, then take some of their instruments and push it under it from all sides with ease, and try to move it, as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If, however, the tooth is perforated or corroded: then it is necessary that you fill it with cloth: and tighten it with a slender hook, so that it does not break at the time of your constriction on top of it with the forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And you should, so to speak, do an incision around the gum with a lot of bleeding.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And guard your strength so that you do not break it and a part of it remains, and returns to the weak one from the evil which causes it more pain at first.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And so, do not make that mistake which the phlebotomators make out of ignorance and their rashness in eradicating it, except that they administer to it what we have described.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	For many times have we seen how great ailments they bring upon men, which are harder to break than they remain the roots of it all, or some of its parts: or as they take it out with some of the bones of the jaw: as we have often witnessed.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then they clean up after eradicating it with wine, or vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	That if it happens that a flow of blood comes from the places (for many times does happen) then mend some wound and fill it with it: and if not, cauterize it itself if not giving you a wound.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The shapes of the forceps are small at the ends which they move first, have long handles, thick, so that they do not double themselves when pressed upon a tooth: are as you see the thick handles of the forceps, until when you squeeze them with them, do not bite themselves, nor double themselves: the short ends, and are made of iron rod, or a split piece of wood, straight ends: and in their ends there are teeth, some of which enter into some things, and squeeze them tightly, surely.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And when they make the ends as the shape of the ear opening which is called the ciconia, and are strong constriction.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	Of the eradicating of teeth and extracting of bones of the jaw fractures.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When remains after the eradication of a tooth which is broken something, then you should put upon the place Cotum with butter one day, or two days, until it softens the place: and then introduce into it algast or forceps: of whose ends are shaped like the ear opening which is called ciconia.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	The shape however of this forceps is.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	The extremities should be made round like a lemon: or like an egg.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If he does not obey you at the exit with these forceps, then it is necessary that you stop up the root, and scrape off all the flesh, and insert the instrument which is called a small spoon-shaped scissor, whose form is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	The end should be short, somewhat longer: and it should not be soaked, lest it break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If then the root is gone out by that, it is good: and if not, it is necessary to move with these other instruments the forms of which are these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The form of the first extreme, in which there is some груssness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The triangular shape of the small extreme.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	Also move with this instrument having two branches, whose form is this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with the other instruments and tools which have preceded in the cutting of teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	Also sit the clamping with this instrument which is similar to a large hook, of this form, triangular extreme torted, in which there is some груssness, so that it does not break: and it should not be soaked.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And you should know that there are many instruments for teeth: and likewise the other instruments do not count, and the prudent artist finds his own instrument, according to which serves him operation and the diseases themselves.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Because from the diseases there are those for which the ancient instrument did not speak, because of the diversity of their forms.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If then the jaw is broken from the mandible, or from other bones of the mouth, or putrid: then examine on top of it in its own place with what belongs to him from instruments and forceps which I spoke in extracting the root, and move with the gesture, whose form is this.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	It is sat there some gruesomeness gradually, so that it is tight, or hold with it the jaw, and does not flee and move, until the exit of the jaw: and restore place with medicines fitting for it.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If there is pus in bone then it should be carved away from its own pus and cured until healed.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Of the excellent locking of teeth on others.
Caput XXXII.	Head 32.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When the teeth are not in their proper position, i.e., when they do not grow in a natural way, they become pus-filled through the shape of the jaw; and this especially happens with women and girls, i.e., those who are still growing.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore you should consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if one tooth has come up after another and does not fit, nor can its locking be done, then eradicate it; and if it is joined with another tooth, then cut it out with this instrument, the shape of which is as follows.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is similar in shape to a small chisel, and is made of iron, and has a sharp point.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And let your cut be deep, and for the hardness of the tooth, and so that it does not displace any other teeth.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	But if it is exposed and its filing is worn out, then file it with a sharp chisel made of iron; the shape of which is as follows.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	It should all be of iron, and the handle of its minute pointed tip should be like a chisel with which akos are made; with this file the tooth is gradually filed away over many days with ease, so that no other teeth are disturbed and it falls out: then make the tooth smooth by carving it with some rasps.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If a tooth breaks off and hurts the tongue, then it should be filed as well until its roughness is gone, and made smooth; and if it presses on the tongue, or disturbs the speech, then make it smooth without pressing it.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	Of retaining teeth with gold fillings.
Caput XXXIII.	Head 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When the anterior teeth are injured and shaken by a blow, or fall, and cannot be held firm so as not to fall out: and they have been treated with stinging medicines, and the treatment does not help: then let there be a design in them to be tied with gold wire; for gold changes color, and spoils after a while; but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let there be a thread of middle thickness between subtility and coarseness according to the quantity that it takes between teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the shape of retention is that you take a thread and insert it between two healthy teeth: then you tie it with both ends between the teeth, or one end, or more, until you reach the dental nerve until you hit it with a needle until you reach the healthy side's nerve.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the texture until you reach the side from which you started: and tighten your hand with subtlety and wisdom, until it does not move completely: and let your constriction be where you tighten the thread, near the roots of the teeth, so that it does not break.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut the ends of the thread that are excessive with scissors: and gather both together, and twist them together, and conceal them between a healthy tooth and a teeth-motus tooth so that they don't hurt the tongue: then let go, so that it is tight when left alone.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it becomes loose or breaks, tighten them with another thread and keep it in place for a long time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the shape of the teeth, and the figure of retention of two healthy teeth and two teeth-motus as you see them.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes a tooth falls out, or two teeth after the decay and rust in their places, and remain in place as we have described, and does not make it except for an artisan who is careful, wise, and experienced.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes a bone breaks, and becomes the shape of a tooth, and is placed in its place, from which it holds firm a tooth, and tightens it like we said, and remains with it for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	Regarding the cutting of the tongue's ligament that happens under the tongue, and prevents one from speaking.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	And sometimes the ligament that happens under the tongue is either natural, with which a person is born, or accidental, from an arrow that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation is, so that you open his mouth in his head in your bosom, and relieve his tongue; and then cut that ligament that nervously through its width, until his tongue is released from its hold.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is anything of hardness and swelling, and it is from the union of a wound; then throw into it a hook, and finish it through its width, until you cut the ligament, and the swelling is released.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And cause not to be a breach in the depth of the flesh, and cut there an artery, so that blood flows out.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then moisten in the shadow of the incision with rosin water, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then put under the tongue a piece of linen that holds the weak one all night, so that it does not harden again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	But if there is any flow of blood, then put on the spot a lump of earth.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if you are pricked by blood, then cauterize the spot with a piece of dried cow manure that comes to it: and then take care for yourself with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	Regarding the extraction of a wound that is under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Head XXXV.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	When there is a small sore under the tongue that absorbs the little frog, prevents the natural movement of the tongue: and perhaps it grows so much, until the bone is filled.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation is, so that you open the closed mouth from the sun: and consider the sore.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	But if you see that the color of it is dark or black, and hard, to which the sick person does not have a sense of touch; then do not touch it, for it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it declines to whiteness, in which is moisture, then throw into it a hook, and cut it with a fine scythe, and free it from every part.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If your blood pricks you during the hour of your operation, then put on the spot a lump of earth until the blood is separated: and then return to your operation, until it is extracted with its complement.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then cover with vinegar and salt: and treat him with the appropriate cure for that, until he is healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	In the treatment of boils, two walnuts should be used.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI. On the Treatment of Wounds and Ulcers.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	When, however, the wound is between the mouth and the tonsils, that is to say, the glands which resemble azalea and occur on the sides; they are called two walnuts: when you treat them with the cure mentioned in the division, and they do not heal, then consider carefully.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If, however, the boil is hard, of a fusty colour, with little sensation; then do not touch the boil with the iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if its colour is ruddy and its root is thick: then do not touch the boil with the iron, fearing a flow of blood, but leave it, until it boils dry.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then you shall either pierce it, or let it burst by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if its colour is white and round, and the root is fine: then the boil should be pricked.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation upon it is such that, before you perform the operation, if the boil has become warm and quiet and has completed its healing, or is about to diminish in any way: then cause the sick person to sit in front of the sun, and place his head in your lap; and open his mouth, and let him take hold between his hands, and press his tongue with an instrument of this shape.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Let it be made of silver, or of brass, that it may be as sharp as a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When you press it with the instrument on the boil and see it swell your skin: then take hold of a hook, and fasten it in the walnut, and pull out as much as you can, taking off at the same time some of the skin.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut it with an instrument which has this shape.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It is to be joined together by a hook; and yet its extremities are so curled up that the opening of each of them is in the acute angle of the other: therefore the cure should be that it be made of iron, or of a metal which absorbs.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If this instrument is not present, then cut it with a chisel, which has this shape.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	This instrument should be sharp on one side but not the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you have cut one side of the jaw, cut the other side according to the same shape of the incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then, after the incision, the patient should gargle with cold water or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there is a flow of blood, gargle with water in which the bark of the willows has been boiled: or with leaves of myrtle and similar things from astringents, until the flow of blood stops: and then care for the wound, until it heals.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And when there are other pustules in the throat, except for two in the amygdalis.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Then cut these according to what I said in the incision of the two amygdalas.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And I have already treated a woman with an abscess between her teeth, which was causing her pain and loss of taste, which had almost closed her throat: and this woman breathed through a narrowed airway, and had already lost her appetite, and could not drink water, and was approaching death if it continued for another day or two.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the abscess rose just enough to break through the two branches of the nose.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	So I hurried and fixed one of my scissors in one of the openings.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I pulled it out, and a large piece came with it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut it off where it emerged from the nasal opening.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I made the same thing go forward from the other nasal opening.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened her mouth and pressed on her tongue; and then I fixed my scissor in the abscess; and then I cut off a part of it, and there was not much blood coming out of it: so the woman's throat is completely blocked, and she immediately started drinking water again, and then she began to eat.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	I therefore did not stop pressing on that for a long time often: and the scar which I pressed on succeeded to the place of that which I pressed on until it was prolonged too much and with that one.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I therefore did not stop pressing on that for a long time often: and the scar which I pressed on succeeded to the place of that which I pressed on until it was prolonged too much and
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	So then I did not stop from that addition: and then I walked away from the part, and I do not know what God did with that after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	Regarding the incision of scars on the throat.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37. On the incisions of scars on the throat
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When a catarrh descends to the voice-box, and is scarred, and is long: then it is called a perpendicular; and if it is in the lower part thick, round, then it is called a vocal cord.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When you treat it along with that which we mentioned in the division, and does not bring about the treatment: and you will see that the scar has become cool from it, and is thin: then you should press on it.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And what is joined on to that which has become round, and has no length in it, and is bloody or dark-colored or black, and has no sensation: then you should remove the scar from it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For fear is in the scar over the disease.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Then you should, when you see it according to the way which I mentioned from whiteness, and according to its length, so that you set the sick person before the sun: and press his tongue with an instrument, of which the preceding story has been told: then fasten a hook in the throat, and pull it down: and cut it with one or two instruments which I mentioned in cutting between the two ears.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And you should not press on it, unless that is added to the natural term without adding to it.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you press on it any more, you will damage speech and conversation.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision use what we mentioned in the incision of the two ears: and care for it, until it heals.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If however he trembles with fear at the incision: then it is right that you should act with courage and without fear or anxiety during the cauterization.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the mode of cauterization in it is not, except with sharp water: and it is, that you put the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press his tongue with the instrument which we have said.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water which I have told you to take in the chapter on cauterizing, and moisten it with this fire not extinguished, and place it not thick, nor thin, and fill it with this shape of the instrument.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Sit at the end of which the medicine is placed, congealed, as congealed is the ear of a ray.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine on a bandage: and let the patient lie on his side, so that the saliva may flow from his mouth from the interior medicine, so as not to fall from it into his throat anything, and may hurt him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first put on a bandage half the quantity of the medicine every hour, until you see it has become discolored, and sit at rest with the Mordication of the medicine.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take a bath, and wet him on the end of a ray, and dip the cloth with the medicine, and insert the ray with the cloth into a tube from above, until the cloth sticks to the bandage.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Make it many times, until you get the result that you want of the new cauterization.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then dismiss him: for he will be healed and will fall after three days, or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	That if you wish to take a bath with the medicine, repeat it: and after the cauterization wash off in the new circumcision with a cloth dipped in butter, and clean up with it what is in the circumcision of him from the medicine: and cool down with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	He should be treated from the outside with poultices and from within with gargling until he is well.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This therefore is the species of treatment that is more salutary than incising and less anxious about fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes also with him cure is to be done that is finer than cautery and incision: cure is to be done indeed with suffumigations, in this way.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take also hemlock and hyssop and oregano and rue and sseah and chamomile and abrotan and other such herbs; and put them all together in an olla or some such vessel, and pour over them with vinegar and make it boil: and let the olla be well covered with a lid: and let there be a hole in the middle of the lid above which put a sharp instrument, according to this mode.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made of silver or of brass: and let the end, in which is the granule, be put into the nose, until the vapor ascends to the hole, until it is much darkened.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then do this often, until it has healed.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware, do not make this cure at the first approach of apoplexy.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	Indeed it adds something to apoplexy: and you should not make this cure except when the aposteme is declining from its heat.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if you do not have this instrument with you, then take a pipe and fit it with a plug of wood at the end, so that it may not burn the nose: for the wood prevents the vapor from burning the nose; and this is good cure with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	Of the extraction of spine and of the teeth in the throat.
