Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38. On the extraction of spines and teeth from the
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	A long time in the throat held fast a tooth or some spine, or something else.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Then it is necessary that you extract what lies visible upon that which makes the yawning, after you have pressed the tongue with an instrument against the sun, and have shown it to yourself.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, you should make the sick man die before food digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	For perhaps it would come out through the dung.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or perhaps the sick man would swallow a bit of straw, or a radish leaf, or swallow dry bread; or he might take a bit of dried sea sponge; and he should bind it with a string, then he should swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	But when it has come to the place where there are spines or teeth, and is taken out, then it comes out. Et si peruenit ad locum ubi est lacta cum radice, tunc deglutitur lacta cum radice: aut si peruenit ad locum ub
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If it does not come out with it that we have said: then you should use an instrument made of lead in this form.Et si neque id egreditur, sed manet in ventre sicut aqua, et non esset quod illum afferri possint uti instrumento ex
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	If it is not brought out, but remains in the stomach like water, and there is nothing that they can bring to him to use the instrument: then he should have his head raised up.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him keep his throat from touching his epiglottis so that he does not cough, and push with it a tooth, or spike, or insert the doctor's own hand.Et si non esset uti huius instrumenti, sed uti aliis instrumentis, quae cuncta sunt in hoc liber
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But since the sick man is pushing down, or pulling up his hand with the instrument, all of this according to the quantity that has been prepared for him, until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	Now we come to the extraction of blood from a patient.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the leech is given to him with that which I have said in the division of cure with medicamentorum, and does not work, then consider in the throat before the sun, or after the sun when you press his tongue with the instrument that I have told you.Et si non esset, cum id quod diximus ad effectum veniens, sed non veniet, tunc
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If your yawn falls on the leech, remove it with a small hook, or with subtle gestures that are not seen.Et si neque non esset id quod diximus, sed illud cadere perculsat prope locum ubi est radice sicut radicem heraeae: tunc uis sursum trahat cum
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If it is not possible to do so with them: then take a hollow tube and insert it into the throat of the patient until near the throat: and then insert into the hollow part of the tube an iron rod that has been heated with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times: and let the sick person refrain from all water for a day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a full drink of cold water, and open his mouth in it: and let him kiss the water with his mouth, and let him not swallow anything from it: and let him moisten his hand in the water for an hour after another.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For a leech will immediately fall when he feels the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if he does not emerge with it when we have described it, then let him inhale the sick person with fumes, or with a pipe that we use to inhale the smoke.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, for she will fall herself.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in inhalation is that you take a bowl, in which are placed with fire the blades of a grater: and the bowl is covered with a cover, in whose middle there is an opening: and place the end of the instrument in it.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the inhalation and let the sick person put his mouth at the end of the tube, and let him close his mouth so that it does not exit the inhalation until you know that the inhalation has reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will fall immediately.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall, then repeat the inhalation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the sick person endure hunger, and eat meat, and other things, and do not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he should emerge with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument from which the leech is extracted from the throat when it falls on it.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to a pair of forceps, as you see: but because it has a width that enters into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end is similar to an ear, which is called a ciconia, in which is a roughness of the blade: and when it grasps anything, it does not let go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the opening and cutting of abscesses, and on their general treatment.
Caput XL.	Chapter X. On the opening and cutting of abscesses,
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many types of abscesses and many ways of remembering them, as there is only one chapter on this matter in this book, and they vary in their perforation and the cutting out of their contents from two aspects.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	Of which one species of abscess is in itself, and because it comprises fluid substances.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second mode is due to the locations from which they occur in the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For an abscess occurs in the head, it is different from an abscess that occurs in the anus: and an abscess occurs in a fleshy part, it is different from an abscess that occurs at a joint; and each has its own decision according to the operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And of the abscesses there are some that should not be opened until after the blood has been congealed in them and the clot is complete; and of them it is necessary to open those that are raw and have not come to maturity according to the complement.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	As for abscesses that are close to joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when an abscess occurs near a joint and it is prolonged until the pus that is in its vicinity may have rotted the ligaments or nerves of that joint; therefore, there is a closer cause of the spasm of that member.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or an abscess at a main member; for if you delay opening it until it is complete, it will damage that member or harm another main member through it.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or near a limb, then open it when it is immature: and you should not open an raw abscess that has not been completely digested, unless it is near a limb, so as not to rot deeply, and prolong its course towards the inside of the loin, and become a fistula, or remain at its edge where it does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the time for opening an abscess, which has come to maturity according to the complement; and it is in the repose of pain, the abatement of fever, the lessening of redness, and pulsation, and the sharpness of head from abscess: and the other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	It is necessary that you make the same perforation in the lower place of the fistula, and more prominent: and let the perforation be wet along the length of the body, if the fistulas are in the parts of the hands and feet, and in the places of the lizards, and of the strings, and of the nerves, and of the arteries, and up to the last place in all places equally, where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But those which reflect, go with the perforation according to that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	But when the fistula is in fleshy places: then it is better to leave the perforation of it until its digestion is confirmed, as we have said according to the complement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you pierce it before that, the course of the virus from it will be prolonged, and there will be much sickness and decay, and perhaps its lips will become thicker, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some fistulas are pierced according to the width of the body at necessity: or according to that by which the member is stretched.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer a small perforation in small fistulas, and a wide perforation in large fistulas: or several sections according to the similarity of the size of the fistula.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are fistulas from which the skin should be tightened: and it happens when it has already been made like a piece of cloth, and has already reached its limit, that it is already dead: like that which happened to many, as a blister, and as boils.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And there are those which cut by section with three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And one of them is like a figure of the leaf of myrtle.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	As the fistula of the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And among them are those in which a round section is administered, and a lunar section, and similar sections to these.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	But that which has no head, as are the superficial fistulas of the skin, is to be pierced by a superficial perforation, or simply flat.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	When the abscess is large and has already discharged a great deal of pus, and you pierce it, so that the pus does not spread all over at that time: draw out part of it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then cover the abscess until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then draw out some more pus.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this frequently according to the degree, until it is discharged: especially if the patient is of weak vigor, or a woman pregnant, or a boy small, or an old man decrepitous: for the animal spirit from the animal is often dissolved with the exit of the flux: and perhaps the sick one may die, and you not perceive it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, take great care in this chapter.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	After you have pierced it, when you pierce these abscesses, it is necessary that you clean the wound: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If then there is a small abscess, or it is on a flat surface, then administer liniment made from linseed oil, or old cotto.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if there is a large abscess, and there are many holes made by the piercing, then at that time it is necessary that you introduce liniment into all the cracks, until they come together on both sides.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have cut off a part of the skin in the abscess, or have wrapped it around: then it is necessary that you fill it with old cotto, or as when a cloth is stretched, or a woolen fabric is brushed without moisture: and tighten it tightly for three days.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then throw it out, and take care of that with it as you must from ointment, until it is healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If however a flow of blood occurs at the time of your operation, then administer cold water and vinegar, after it has been soaked up by a cloth: and lay it down often on the site of the blood flow.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If however the blood flow persists, then it is necessary that you administer a regimen and treatment, and powders, which are mentioned in many places in our book, and from a division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If, however, it is in the winter season and the site of the pustule is a place of many nerves: then you should pour powder with wine and oil and put it on the spots.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in the summer and the sites are fleshy: then you should put powder soaked in water and oil, or in wine and oil, and all of that cold thing.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we have said, then you should remove the pustule, wash it, and administer to it what is appropriate for its care, until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary from the consideration of the cure of pustules in general.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	However, according to the halfway distinction, I have already spoken about all pustules, which way leads to the cure of each one separately.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	[De] sectione [apostematum quae accidunt] in cute [capitis].
Caput XLI.	[Head] Chapter LXI.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Pustules small occur on the scalp, and they are of two kinds: nods, which are surrounded by membranes, which are like little bags: almost as if they were caused by hens.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kinds are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Of them there are some thin ones: and of them those which contain a similar moisture like a lime: and of them those which contain a similar moisture like a flour and pulps: and similar ones, and of them the hard ones.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the section of all of them, and their extraction is not a fear, when it comes to the section of them, there does not make a contrast of the arteries.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their section is as you experience it with an instrument, whose shape comes after this, which is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	Nam  si  est  illud  quod  contenit  humiditatem,  tunc  seca  ipsum  sectione  secundum  longitudinem  sectionis  superficialis:  secundum  hanc  formam.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And to begin with the incision along line B to line G. So when the moisture is drained, then scrub the crust that contains that moisture, and do not leave anything behind.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For it often returns if anything remains.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then dip it in Egyptian ointment if present: and if not, in water and salt: and fill it with the same; and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For that corrodes what remains of the crust.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the Egyptian ointment on the patch a second and third time if you wish: and if your consent is given that nothing remains of the crust, then you may consider the wound healed with the ointment, for it will not return.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	That if the pus contains a swollen lump: then dry it out according to this form, having the shape of a cross: and throw away the hooks between the sides of the incision, and scrub the crust off entirely: and try your skill in removing the cloth that holds the lump.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If, however, it gives you a counter-direction, then do as I will tell you after.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And do likewise with the pus, if hard, from the incision, and with the same cure, as we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the incision on hard pus is easier: for it has little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are some pustules that are in the head of certain men, where there is no depth of moisture.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	Which is this: for I followed over the pustule on the head of a married woman, and found the pustule like a solid rock, hard, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if anyone struck it with anything, he would hurt the flesh.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But in the other pustules, accidents in the head, apart from these pustules that are on the heads of boys, and at the roots of the ears: all of them are shallow incisions.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	And so that their perforations are always from the lower part of them, so that the flow of blood may go to the lower parts.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then, after this, take care of them as is right for them while they are recovering from the cure.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	§ On the Section of Staphylas in the Neck.
Caput XLII.	Head XXIV.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These hernias in the neck, and under the breast, and in the groin; and sometimes they occur elsewhere in the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And of those which occur in the neck, one is enough, but many are numerous; they spring from within; and every staphula comes out of its own skin, as we have described in the case of the nods and hernias of the head.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the kinds of these staphylas are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	For some of them have leaves; and some of them contain moisture; and some of them are evil, and do not yield to the cure.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In that which you see to be of good disposition when you touch it, its color is close to the skin's color, and it moves in all parts, and is not attached to the nerves of the neck, nor to the arteries, nor is it deep: let it be separated from its upper part to the lower part of the body along a line, b. towards the line, g., and scrape it off completely: and extend two skin flaps with a hook, or with many hooks, if you can bear it, as we have described in the case of the hernias of the head, and take it out little by little.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And be careful that it does not cut the vein, or a nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the knife be not very sharp, so that it does not cut your hand with an incision, or disturb you in any way, and do not fall, for it is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If you cut a vein or prevent you from performing the operation, then place it in a tree trunk, or some powder that stops the blood, and tightly tie the tree trunk, and let it go until the sharpness of the hernia subsides, and the tree trunk softens: or begin to putrefy.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	The blood is cut off with a bandage. So get ready for your operation, until you are finished.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then examine with your index finger to see if there is anything left of the staph. If so, cut and clean it out.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If it is in the root of a new large staph: then you must not cut that staph out from its root: but you should tie it with strong double thread and let it fall by itself without causing any harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the hole with old cotton that you have already soaked in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole staph is cut, you should bring together the two sides of the wound: and then immediately, as soon as you see that there is no surplus.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If you see that there is still surplus because of the size of the staph, then you should turn your attention to cutting its root and taking it out: and administer the suture which we have described.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And as for the staph which contains moisture, pierce it with a superficial puncture so that you can see the site of maturity: and place the puncture from there so that it follows the lower part of the body, as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then after the puncture administer the liniment with ointment and similar ones so that it corrodes what is left of the corruption, until the moment when you see the wound healed: then take care of yourself with a nourishing ointment for the flesh, until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	Regarding the section of the epiglottis from the food pipe into the throat by accident.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The old people said that this operation of the epiglottis was done, and I did not see anyone in our land who did it: and this is the writing of their teaching.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in those who have a swollen throat, the section of the epiglottis should be avoided: because it does not help at all for their recovery, since the larynx and lungs are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	Indeed, those who have a hot apostema in the mouth, or in the throat, or in both amygdalar glands, if there is no ailment in the larynx, it is necessary to use the epiglottis section, so as to avoid the loss that is made from pre-condensation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we want to cut this (epiglottis), we should cut it between two circles according to its size, which is the section in the sifac, not in the cartilage: and this place is suitable for cutting because it is separated from the flesh, and the blood vessels are far away from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the surgeon is timid, then he should extend the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he finds the skin, until it reaches the larynx; he should stop the flow of blood, if he sees any from it.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he cuts the soft palate that we have mentioned; and it indicates on the section of the larynx from the mucus that is released from it, when it is interrupted, and with the cutting of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And remove the ring that opens at some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When, however, the hour approaches in which pre-condensation is feared, the two lips of the wound skin will be brought together, and it will be sealed alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then he administers medicines that make flesh grow, until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	Says Albucasis. The summary of this discourse that we have mentioned is not exposed, unless it is clear, that there is a certain apostema in the throat of the sick, and he has almost died because of his disease, and breathes heavily on his place, so that he is saved from death; and for this reason they ordered to remove the ring that opens, until the maliciousness of illness is consumed, and it is a maliciousness of three days, and almost the same: then he orders to tie the ring, and take care of himself, until he heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I myself saw, that a maid took up a scalpel, and put it in her throat, and cut with it a part of the canal of the lung.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to cure her, and I found her breathing, as it is the breathing of a dead person.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	So I took off the bandage, and I found blood that had come out from the small lung.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	So I was convinced that she had not cut her wound, nor had she bled: and wind came out from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	So I took off the bandage, and examined the wound myself, until it was healed: and there happened to the servant nothing, except a hoarseness in her voice: and she returned after a few days in better state of health.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	So I say: that there is no fear in cutting the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the section of the stomach throat.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 48.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This hernia named in the gut, is a great hernia, and of a second kind as to color, being of the color of the body: and it is common in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it has two kinds: either it is natural: or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly it is not a matter of design in the natural.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	On the other hand, it is accidental, and has two kinds, one is similar to pingueculae, and the other to warts.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other kind is similar to an ulcer that is formed from an inflammation of the artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is a risk, and it should not be assumed to do this with iron, unless it is small: and you test it, and investigate it with an instrument.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If then you cut the similar nodule of the pingueculed, and it is not suspended with any wound: then dry up the nodule, as you do to others: and take out the one that contains it, if it is in a vesicle: and if it is not, then examine all of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then the care of the place with it that needs to be cured, until it is healed.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	§ On section above the nodules.
Caput XLV.	Head LXXV.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many types of nodules, and I have already spoken about all their types in the division: and it is necessary that I should speak here about the difference between a nodule and an ulcer, in order to cause no confusion.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore, that when an ulcer is hot and feverish and there are keen pains, until the efflux of pus has run out in a stream, and corruption is completed: then indeed the fever and heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When however a nodule is not hot, nor feverish, nor painful, and it contains its own sacs, which are like beans of the body, and are of the colour of the flesh: and it resembles an acorn, and a nut, and is greater or smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are of two kinds: either small or they contain moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colours of the moisture are many, according to what I have said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore when you are treating a nodule, you should test it and investigate it with the instrument called an introskim, according to which its form will be known in the chapter which follows this one.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of testing nodules, and all nodules, is to take this instrument and introduce it into a moistened place, which you have opened in an ulcer: and you will then withdraw your fingers gradually, until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then withdraw the last of your fingers by the measure of the size of an ulcer.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then remove the introskim, and see what comes out into its opening.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If however moist matter runs out while it is being removed, whatever colour it may be: then dry the spot with a superficial cut, according to what I have said in other ulcers.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if no moisture runs out in the opening of the introskim, then know that it is fat: so dry the spot on top with a cut which has the form of a cross, according to this form, as I have taught you: and suspend it with an hook, and scrape off the skin completely from all parts with ease: and guard the case if you can over it, so that you may take out the sound with a nodule.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If, however, the belly is broken open during an operation, and it is not possible to extract it whole because many times it has happened that then extract it quickly, until there is nothing left of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if a little or a lot remains of it, it returns the second knot according to many.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	That if it hurts you and a little remains of it: then fill the wound with some acute rust powder: and tighten the wound tightly, and put on top of it a hot poultice, and care for the wound along with the rest of the cure, until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If then there is a large knot: then tear its two lips open, and care for the wound with that which has become inflamed.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If it is then a new wound that pulsates or does not pulsate: then approach and fill the place with threefold poultice, and leave it tightly for two days or three, until the wound putrefies and the swelling subsides: then return to cutting out what is left of the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Regarding instruments from outside the body for section and perforation.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVIII. On the use of instruments from outside the body for
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	There are three types of instruments for
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	Of these, there is a large one, and of these, a middle one, and of these, a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let there be made from iron an octangular frame with projecting ends, so that it may enter the wound without touching.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	These are forms of instruments for: and one of these is called a bit, that is, a perforating one: and there are three types.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	Of these, there is a large one, and a middle one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They are convenient for piercing through the wounds, exits, veins, and abscesses from which they come out between the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round and sharp, like large needles from which sutures are made, of brass perhaps, or of iron, or of silver, or of gold.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And their better ones are those which are made from citron.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And experience is also made about lead black, which they use so that through it they can experiment with the tubes, whose surfaces they smooth so that they reflect gently and reflect on them with their own reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And there are again three species.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For from them are the long ones, from them the medium, and from them the short, according to the quantity of the width of the tube and the tightness of it.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	Shape of rings, and there are many species.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For from them are the simple ones, that is to say those which have one depth: and there are three species as you see, great, medium, and small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from them are blind rings: and there are three species.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from them are hooks with two depths, and there are three species: and from them are hooks with three depths, and there are also three species: and all of these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the shapes of the scalpels, with which they cut and burn the nodes and abscesses: and there are three species: for from them is the great, the medium, and the small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities with which the cutting is done are acute, and other extremities are not acute: and they are not arranged so as to do this, unless it be with them that one does the incision of a node in fear of cutting the skin, or of the nerve: and in order that the sick person may be healed through it, and have some calmness from the heat which he has, more than when one incises an abscess.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are magda, and there are three species of them.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made from bronze, and they resemble the wire with which alcohol is made: and in the wider end there is a little spathula hidden: and it runs to the inside and outside when you want it, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of the spatulums which are hidden between the fingers at the perforation of abscesses: and they do not feel them with their hands: and there are three species, great, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of wound healing with which blood flow is interrupted: and there are three types, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made from metal, or gold, round in shape, of nearly the same length, as you see: and let them be thin.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these forms of the Winds be with you large and small: so that you can cut the blood off with speed in an emergency, and then when there is no medicine present.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use them to cut blood anywhere in the body, and do not use them except in tender places: such as those of the legs, and of the hips, and of the arms, and of the breasts, and of the feet, and of the groin, and similar ones, from tender flesh, moist.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And when they are made into small instruments like a scalpel, of the same shape as their handle: which cut blood when it flows from a phlebotomy site, or after cutting a vein, or an artery: and sometimes they are made round in this shape.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the care of the breasts of men which resemble female nipples.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter LVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the breasts of certain men are swollen towards the end of sleep (namely, when they begin to discharge their seed in sleep) until they resemble female nipples, and remain wet with milk.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Those who thus avoid that, should dry their breasts with a lunar section of a loof, from the line A to the line G, then scrape off the milky substance all over.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill a sponge with an ink-like medicine.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind together the two lips of the wound with a stitch, and take care of it, until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If however the nipple turns downward and becomes soft through its size, as happens to women: then it is necessary that there be found in its two sides, above, two sections like the moon, each holding with the other at their ends, until it forms a line containing the smaller one, according to this shape from the line A to the line G. Then scrape off the skin which is between the two lips, and take away the milk, and administer what we have said about the stitch and the powders, which is necessary in the care, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If you do not wish to make an incision where necessary for your incisions, due to anxiety or because of blood flow: then it is necessary that you fill the wound with a submerged unguent that is corrosive, and leave it until it has corroded what remains from the swelling.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound, until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On perforations caused by the skin rash that occurred during the time of Titus.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 58.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These skin rashes that occur during the time of Titus are of two kinds: one is hard, and has a scaly surface, and the other is moist.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	These that are moist should be dried out with a lunar section, as shown in the diagram, from line b to line g; and when all that is left in the pustule has been drained, then fill it with old ointment, and leave it until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the ointment should be removed, and the wound should be treated with a suitable ointment, until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the pustule is of the kind of knots called strophulas, then cut it open, as we have said in the section on strophulas that are equal.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, the sore extends and discharges pus, then administer a cauterization to it, as we have said above.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the incision of a pustule that has occurred through an artery or vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery bursts and the skin that is above it becomes stiffened, then often a pustule occurs; and also happens to veins, so that a pustule and swelling occur in them.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it can be known that a pustule and swelling are due to an artery and vein are these: for when the pustule is due to an artery, it is long and deep within the body; and when you press the pustule with your fingers, you feel as if it were whispering.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And what is due to vein, is round in apparent body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section on this wound is an error, and especially what is under the armpits, and groin, and neck, and in many places of the body: and it is great indeed.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, so that its care may be removed with iron, and that which is also from it in the extremities, or in the head, should be removed.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	And on this then what is from it from the inflating of the opening of the artery, find in the skin in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with a hook, then the artery: and free it from the tunics, until it is detected.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert underneath it a hook, and let it penetrate as far as another side, and tighten the artery with a double thread in two places, according to which I taught you in the extraction of two arteries which are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then prick the place, which is between the two ligaments with a needle, until all the blood that is in it has gone out, and solve the apoplexy.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer the cure which generates pus, until the ligaments fall: then care for it with ointments suitable for it, until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If the apoplexy is due to a vein section, then you should hold your hand, which you can manage from the apoplexy with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert a hook underneath the place which you held with your hand, and let it penetrate: and let it be in it a double thread, until you bring it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind with it the apoplexy with good ligament: according to which I told you in the binding of a thread, from two parts with two extremities.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If however you should know that the thread is to be extracted, then insert a hook with another thread under the apoplexy all around the incision of the blade: press, and tighten your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry the apoplexy in the middle of itself, until it is completely gone out from it: then cut off the excess of the skin, and let go what is bound from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put a very thin layer of the powder that you dipped in wine and oil on your wound.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply the cure, which is made with liniments and ointments, until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	A post-mortem examination of what happened due to a torsion of the neck.
Caput L.	The head of the lower leg.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	As happened in the apostema of Arteria and Vena, so also happened in the nerves: what happened to them is percussion, or it happened from excessive work, and similar: and it often happens in the places of the adductors, or calcanei, and in any place where the tendineae move: and it is a gray apostema.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color is similar to the rest of the body, and it is in many dispositions without pain: and when it is pressed with a thump, it feels in it a similar kind of fainting.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And this apostema is not aggregated in the deep part of the body, but it is under the skin, and it moves itself to all parts, and does not announce itself to the front, nor forward, nor backward to the back.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	What then is in the joints, should not be moved with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps indeed what happens: contraction may happen.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which is in the head or in the forehead, find a skin with a thump.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If then it is a small apostema, then hold it with forceps, and cut it off from the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is a large one, then hang it on a hook, and scrape it off: then take it off, and join the wound with stitches: and care for it, until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Regarding the section of apostemes that occur in the belly.
Caput LI.	The head of the lower leg.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	To some people their bellywind often occurs, and to the rest of their bodies, those little things that they call 'fungus', due to similarity of those to the mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	The root of these is thin, and their heads are thick, and their lips are loose.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And it comes from a few things: and it is from them that it becomes great.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I too have already seen a man, and in his belly were two small mushrooms, which were more than similar to other things: there was no difference between them, they had white roots, and their lips were spread apart, and they were ending, and moisture always flowed out of them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	So then I cut them open, and I found in weight one like ten and eight ounces, and in another like six ounces; and the operation on them is so that you consider this then, if it is damp, and the color of the mushroom is white, moist, with a fine root: then cut it open with a wide chisel, and let cauterizes be present with fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often is driven out from its section much blood: so then if your blood wins it, then cauterize the body.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	That if you see a sick person trembling from the incision with iron, then take a thread of lead which is made crookedly, and tie it up with it: whose method is that which we have said, and let go of him for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the tightening of the lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	So then do not cease to tighten the lead, when it presses on the mushroom, until it is cut off, and falls by itself without work.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the mushroom is large in root, then there is a certain fear and trembling in its incision: above all because it is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However, it is possible that you cut in half.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize the body so that it does not bleed back.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care of the body until the wound heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And do not suppose that you cut into a mushroom which is of a fuzzy color, of few senses, of an appetizing appearance: for it is a cancerous pustule: and I have come with a reminder of the crab after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	Of the care of an eminence of the umbilicus.
Caput LII.	Chapter LII.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	Ex many causes of umbilical eminence.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from the sirocco hole, which is above the navel: and comes out of it the hernia, or the intestine, according to what happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from the blood that flows from a vein, or from an artery, according to what has been said above.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from the hernia, as it was said.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If, however, it is due to a sirocco hole and the exit is bad: then it is of an apθημαtic color, similar to the color of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and appears at different locations.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the exit of the intestine, then its location is with that which we have described, more varied in location.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you press it with your fingers, it is hidden: but then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it: and it increases greatly at the entry of the sweat, and laborious rumbling.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If, however, it is due to moisture, it is soft, then it does not hide itself when pressed with your hand, nor does it contract, nor does it add.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	That if it is due to blood, then, with these signs, an apθημα appears towards blackness from the navel.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If, however, it is due to a natural birth, then it is an apθημα of gray color, thick, hard, and shapes itself according to the quantity of one unit.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If, however, it is due to the flow of air, then the sensation of it is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in it is, to consider then, if the umbilical eminence is due to blood of an artery or vein, or air: then one should refrain from treating it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in it is fear and dread, as I have taught you in the chapter in which I said about aptelemas due to an artery and a vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	That if the umbilical eminence is due to the intestine or a hernia, then you should prescribe to the sick person that he keep his breath, and stand with his back erect.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then mark with caustice around the navel all around.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then order him to lie down on his back between your hands.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then, with a sharp blade, mark around the navel on the spot you marked with caustice.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the midline to the upper part, with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind him strongly around the navel with a thread, or with a silk cord, so that the knot is tied on the abdomens of the bound man.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the midline that you have extended above the navel.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you have already found the man captured by the ligature: then pull out the ligature and insert your finger into his anus, and push the stool into the inner part of the abdomen: and if you find feces, then take it with a hook and cut off the excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If the artery or vein is on the opposite side, then bind him very tightly.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles and insert two strong threads into them: and insert the two needles around the spot you have made in the form of a cross, which you make to penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the knot in four places on the needles: and if there is a wound, remove the needle, and leave the spot until the flesh has rotted: and it will fall off by itself: or cut it when it becomes thin and rotten.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the man with the ointment as needed until he is healed.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If the navel eminence is made of flesh that has dried up in it, or from moisture: then you must tighten the knot, as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And drain the blood, or moisture, which you have injected into him.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then take care of the man with the ointment so that the spot hardens up.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	Of the cure for cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken about the division of cancer into species, and how to treat it with medicines; and to beware of treating it with iron so that it does not ulcerate; and we spoke about cancer generated in the womb, and about the precaution to take when treating it.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that whenever cancer is in a place where it can be eradicated: such as cancer which is in the breast, or in the hip, and those like them, from the member located to extract all of it: especially when it is beginning to start.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When, however, it has been long established, and is great, it is not necessary that you approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I could not heal from it anyone: nor did I see another who had come to it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation on it, when it is located as we have said, is, like a prolepsis, and you remove the disease from time to time.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then the phlebotomy itself if the wound is filled with pus.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the sick with preparation, in which he is placed with the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then throw on cancer hooks that are suitable for it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then close it up from all sides with a wound, according to the examination, until nothing remains of its roots: and let not the blood flow, nor do you tear it quickly off, except express the places, and wipe away the gross blood entirely by hand, or with whatever is possible there.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if the opposite makes you flow of gross blood from the incision of an artery, or a vein: then cauterize the vein, until the blood is severed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the cancer with the remaining cure, until it is healed.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	§ On the treatment of water-on-the-skin.
Caput LIIII.	Head XLIV.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have already spoken at length in the division of the species of water, and how it is gathered: and the signs of each kind, and the treatment of it with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And those who are cured with iron, it is not except a single kind of asclepius: and does not approach the iron of the tympanic species: nor does the hyposarcous species go deep into the body: for that is mortal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this species of water-on-the-skin with medicines, and your treatment has not been effective: then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	If a person is already weak, then further weakness is added, or else another sickness besides hydrops: as when there is coughing, or loosening of the eyes, and similar things: then be careful not to treat him with iron: for that is feared.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see a person with a vigor of health, and there is no illness besides hydrops: and he is not a boy, nor an old man: then the manner of operation in him is, that you should stand him upright between your hands, and let him spit out water with his own hand driving it to the lower part of the chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a bent pitchfork, shaped like this.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Set the two acute ends, one long, and the acute end like a pitchfork.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	But in him there is something of a hiccup now and then, so that he does not disturb you while you are operating inside the abdomen, and let him go.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if the generation of hydrops is from the part of the intestines, then it should be extended with a section of three fingers' length from the navel, towards the lower part directly above the chest.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	But if the generation of hydrops is because of liver illness: then your section should be left from the navel by three fingers' length.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.
