[But of the dry scurvy there is one little eminence, rough, filtre-like, round on top of the skin.]Si quoddam uel magne facit in pedibus aut in digitis, non est iidem cum in corpore: sed si in corpore fit, curatur
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	[If something makes a mark in the feet or toes, it is not the same as when it is on the body; but if it is on the body
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	[And its treatment is to spread the scaly skin and cover it with a cloth; or to tie it with silk thread, or with down, until it falls off.]Cum ergo est incisa, et stridentia, et non cadere vel exire: tunc oportet ut cum rasione ve-semem, aut cu-m uncine, donec resipientes sim
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you see, you cauterize him according to what has been said before with fire, or with sharp medicine: and now the athelial that is spread out are eradicated, and not those who do not spread out with an instrument which I say.
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	But the ant also is an eminent small filtered one, thick, on the surface of the body, waddling into the depth greatly: and when it comes to him cold, it feels in it a similar stinging of an ant, and becomes in the whole body: and most of it is made in the hands.
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its cure is, that you take a tube from a goose feather, or a strong swan feather: and put that tube on the ant, until it contains a circle of tubes from its parts.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then you rotate your hand with the tube, until you separate what is in the circumference of the ant: and put that on a deep place of flesh, and eradicate the ant from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you see, do that with a tube of air, or iron, according to this form.
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let it sit on the upper limit, pulling a soft covered thing, so that it eases the pressure of its grip and its rotation.
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you see, cauterize the ant according to what has been said before in the cauterization of Athelial in the chapter on cauterization.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	Regarding the forms of instruments that are used for douches in ailments of the goose, and for the relief of venereal disease and colic.
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter LXXXIII.
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	When the douche is made of silver, or of gold-plated brass, or of fine brass, or of mallet.
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And when they are made from these small instruments, and from the large ones, according to those in which they are administered.
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	So what is administered in the cure of young boys who are weak or aching, should be small, and those whose anus is weak or painful, such should be the douche.
Clistere magnum.	The large douche.
Cistere paruum.	Suture the small cyst.
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	Suture the small cyst. Cannae ite, v.s., caput superius in quo ligatur uter sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, traens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in lato altero foramen unum.
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And let the width of the foramen be according to the thickness of the rays, and thicker in parts, and let the uter in which they are placed be from animal fat: or from a piece of parchment that is according to form as if small: whose root is one palm.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And let there be many holes through which it passes, and let the space between each hole be as long as a finger's length.
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into those holes a strong thread from raw silk, which is from ten threads or so, and bind it together with the thread so that it is like a bundle of reeds.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	So when this uter is placed in it, let it be fastened in the head of the cyst with two distinctions by strong constriction.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then let the cyst be sewed up with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the form of the uter as it is depicted here, and the holes.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of the sewing up with it is this: so that the uter be filled, or animal fat from medicine which is heated according to the tolerance of the nurse, and let it not be hot or cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then let the sick person lie on his back, and raise his legs up: and place it under him, that is, a cloth over which men sleep, or a mattress.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then dip the end of the cyst in oil, or in chalk milk, or in mucus of fenugreek, or like it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then insert himself into the anus with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then let the attendant take him by both hands and squeeze it with great force, until all the contents are emptied into the cistern in the intestines.
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then remove the clister and raise his lame legs towards the wall.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If the medicine makes him want to defecate, then he should hold it as much as possible.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps all night with it, it is more effective for recovery.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if you use the clister to relieve his ailments and bring on his bowels' movements: then repeat the clister, until he is healed.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are hemorrhoids or itching in the anus, then let him use the clister very gently, softly, with the clisters that are used by boys.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this should be the form of a subtle clister that is tightly wrapped around what has a skin covering it.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	For the treatment of wounds to the head without a broken bone.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter LXXVIII.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already spoken in the division of the treatment of wounds that suited the book, and I now speak here about this treatment with the hand, and with the aid of a second medication.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say, therefore, that wounds differ according to that by which they are made, and according to the site on which the wound falls.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	So then the kinds of wounds that are caused frequently are like the impact of stones: or the cut of a blade, or the strike of a lance, or a piece of wood, or an arrow: and similar things from among many.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	But wounds that are caused by sites of the body are, for example, a wound that falls on the head, or the neck, or the chest, or the belly, or the pelvis: and similar members of the body.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am telling about the treatments of some wounds, so that I may set forth the reasoning and rule for the remaining wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with simple head wounds: because remembrance of composers will come at the beginning of Chapter Three.
Dico ergo.	I therefore declare.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	I therefore declare. When there is a simple wound in the head and there is no fracture of the bone: consider then, if it has been caused by a stone or something similar, and it has already broken the skin alone: and it is a great wound, and be careful about subsequent healing pustules of heat: then proceed immediately to phlebotomy on the head: and do not delay that: and draw out of it according to the quantity of its strength: if there is no impediment to phlebotomy, especially if it is blood which is coming out from the wound in small quantities.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let there be phlebotomy from the opposite side of the wounded area.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the sick person refrain from drinking, and wine, and coarse food.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If, however, something prohibits him from fasting, then he should abstain from food, and do not approach meat, nor wine.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And place on the wound if it happens that there is a warm pustule, a solution infused with oil of rose alone, or with wine in which there is stenosis.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	If, however, you are free from a warm pustule, then place on the wound if it is young with its own blood, and do not change it: and if it has already changed it itself, then place on it some ointment, until it heals.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If, however, the wound is large, or has been made with a knife, and similar: and if its edges are not joined together by pustules, then join them together with a suture, according to what I will narrate about the wounds of the limbs concerning their sutures.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If, however, the wound has already been detected from the bone, and hangs down, and there is no hold of it, except in a small suspender: then cut it.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then take care of the wound with medicines, and restore in it hard flesh where the skin is, and command the sick person to eat food in which there is coarseness, such as are heads of corn, and cooked wheat, until it has become like a pulse: and like things for them.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If it putrefies in the wound and does not adhere to the bone: then incise the whole putrefied part and throw it away: and then care for it.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	But if there is an artery in these wounds or a new one from which blood flows and does not stop even with medicines, then inquire about the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If you have not cut it open yet, then dry it up with Spatem or tie it up.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	What if necessity forces you to do so before the above [treatments], then burn it, until the blood stops flowing.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	But if these wounds are small and simple, then the treatment of them is easy and light: so that dust over them this dust: for they harden before they change [into a putrefied state] with air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	The method of using powdered incantation.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take part of olive oil, and two parts of dragon's blood, and three parts of non-extinguished lime: mix them very much together, and sieve them: and fill them with the powder, and tighten them tightly so that they adhere well to the wound, and are congealed with blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then tie it up from above with the powder, and let it go, and do not remove it until it is healed, so that it does not open again.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For this medicine will not get rid of it until it has been healed.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And whenever it does this calcification by itself, for you do not have olive oil and dragon' blood at hand either; the same action is performed on many large wounds when it is placed on them and tied up, and are wounds with blood of their own that have not changed with air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	What if it has already been altered by air in some way, especially during the summer season, then this powder's intention is not in position: therefore care for it with what we have mentioned, so that you place on it a kind of digestive ointment: or place on it a paste made from barley flour, made with water and honey, until it discharges pus.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then, care for those remaining wounds until they heal.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If, however, there is a fracture of the bone and it is small, then extract it with the Wrist: and I will already be saying the cure for fractures of the skull in that which is to come.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Regarding injuries to the neck.
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter on the Head (75)
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	If, however, an injury occurs in the neck, there is no difference in treatment between it and a simple injury to the head.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	If, however, an incision has already been made into the nerves of the neck, or into an artery: then if it is a nerve, there is no skill in its treatment unless it is taken care of so that it causes a sharp pain, like a twinge, and makes one blind, and gives similar symptoms.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	Because they hurt the nerves, and make them jerk.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not put anything cold on a wound at all: for the substance of nerves is cold, and its continuance is with the brain, which is a higher member: and let that be treated by physicians with lene, like a calx poured out with sweet water sometimes infused with oil, or with rose oil, and alumen, when it is rinsed off as well with sweet water: and also with other wet minerals, in this way, and with moist ointments.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	If the wound is large, then apply a stitch: or cover it with powder.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound, until it heals.
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	If, however, the depth of the wound is great, or it has occurred in a sinus lower down on it, where pus has already accumulated: then pierce it with a sharp instrument in the low place.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If, however, an incision has been made into a nerve, and the blood flow from it is successive: then separate it, or dry it up, and tie it up: or cauterize it, if necessity compels it to do so.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If, however, an injury has occurred to the spine with a spondyl or two, and they have healed in such a way that you cannot tell where the injury was: then join the skin together with a stitch on either side of the wound, and do not touch the wound, but reduce it to its natural shape.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then tighten the wound with a strip and leave it for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound with ointment until it heals over.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If the wound has already made an impression on the bone, then examine it: if there are any bone fragments inside, remove them all, or as many as you can; and if it is not prepared (for treatment), leave it until the tendon rot and separates from its exit.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If the tendon is fresh, then powder the wound with the powder that you have made.
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If it has entered into a tendon and formed a fistula, then treat it with what is written about it in the chapter of its treatment.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	Surgeon's knife.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter LXIII.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If the wound is from a lance or a dagger and you can see its depth, then examine it carefully.
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If the tendon that has been wounded ever comes to be free from pain, then know that the tendon is healed.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it is not deep and is fresh with its blood, then do not put powder on it at first, nor tighten it up so that the blood does not flow into its depth and return to its heart, causing injury; but rather put on the wound a tempting ointment, and loosen it twice a day.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	But if you do not have ointment available to you, then put on a cotton poultice that is wet with ointment, so that it soothes the wound as it drains its secretions: and let the patient sleep on the wound, so that the accumulated secretions flow into it.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	But if the wound has been there for three or more days and no spasm, bad tremor of the heart, or constriction of breath, and the other symptoms of it are good, then know that the tendon is healed.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound with care, and with the rest of the cure, until it heals over.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If indeed the cure is successful and it has already opened up again, then you know that a fistula has already formed.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Then let the cure of itself from this chapter.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from an incision of the knife or chisel and it is simple on the surface of the breast or back: then let the cure be with it that preceded from the suture, if it is large; or with dust, if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if it has already made an impression on the bone and has come from it a splinter: then investigate the wound, and approach to remove those splinters, if they are separate.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	If not, then let them go, until the splinter rotten, for the extraction of them is allayed.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	But of the remaining wounds and injuries in the other members, the judgment in the cure is the judgment of that which we have said.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	About wounds of the belly, and exit of the intestines, and their coming out.
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter LXXVII.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The rupture that has happened in the belly is great, and medium, and small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	So when this great one has gone out, or the number of intestines.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Why is there an introduction and a suture more severe and more difficult.
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And a small rupture also can be difficult in another way.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	So, that your reduction may be more difficult, if you do not approach the introduction of its place immediately: for it swells, opens up, and thickens: why is the introduction difficult?
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore, this being so, the rupture is a good one: for when it does not cause difficulty in the reduction of the intestine, as it happens in these two species.
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that the suture of the belly is according to four ways.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two common sutures meet in the suture of the belly, and in the suture of the remaining wounds of the body: and two other sutures separate to each other communicate with the other wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	Truly they are more proper with suturing the ankle: and I tell you one as well as another with explanation and announcement.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say then, because when the injury is slight, and something comes out of the intestines, and it is difficult to reduce it: then it is for two reasons.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Or because of the slightness of the break, as we have said: Or because there is swelling in the intestines from cold air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When then is it so? Then you must heat the wound like this: so that you dip a sponge or a damp cloth in warm water alone.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or you make it up in water with squill, and hyssop, and pepper, and pound it with the intestines, until the swelling goes down.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	When then does the ankle do that has a sty: and it is better than water alone in solving inflammation.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When then you see the swelling already resolved, then wet the intestines with the water in which the ale is cooked, or make it bad.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For by this the entrance is relieved when it is small.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	If, however, the retreat of it after this cure is excused, then find in the disruption a little, with the instrument where they scrape the hemorrhoids.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first cure is better when it is prepared, than the section; and there is no pressure to cut after need and want of the instrument.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	It is one part of it that is bent, sharp, and the other not acute, and the tip is slightly less so than the Spatemil's sharpness; and this is similar to a claw, as you see.
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When then does the ankle get larger, and the intestines are drawn in, then you must reduce it according to its natural form in its own place, if possible about it: for it is better.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When then is the disruption wide in the lower part of the ankle: then you must place the sick one on its back, and raise its legs with its head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the leg, then place its head, and make its chest higher than its lower parts.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And likewise if the break is in one of the two parts of the leg, then place your intention, and always keep this in mind, that the part that has the wound should be higher than the other side.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And so it should be, that you handle those who are large wounds, and those who have medium wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	In small wounds, place it according to what is prepared for you.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make sure that the minister who holds the entire break in his hand is present between your hands: and spread his lips.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then detect from him who follows a thread something after something: and this is the common method of sewing one thread.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is, so that you take an acute angle, or a number of acute angles according to the width of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then let go from the end of the break the amount of the fingernail, that is, the doctor: and fasten now one more than what you put into it in the two ends of the skin, with the two ends of the thread that is under the skin from the inside, until you make it penetrate from the other side, and you have already joined the two ends of the skin, and the two ends of the thread: and there are four orders.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then tighten with a double thread around the acupuncture from both sides, sometimes a few times, until the two lips of the wound have been joined together as they recede.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let go of the bulkiness of the finger as well, and fasten now another one: then make it straight with a thread, as you did with the first acution.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	So therefore do not cease to do this with him who has the break, until you complete the constriction of the wound completely.
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let there be an acute angle between the bulk and the slenderness: for the acute angles cut the flesh quickly: and the gross ones are difficult to enter into the skin: therefore let there be a medium angle, and in slenderness, and in bulkiness.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it should not be that the needles are inserted into the two ends of the skin of the nearby part by much: so that the flesh does not quickly get hurt, and the wound does not open before its own consolidation, and the sutures are also not elongated when they are sewn, so that the wound is not kept away from consolidation.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut the end of the needle so that it does not hurt the sick person when he sleeps: and place on them little pieces of leather from all sides, which hold the ends of the needles: and let them go until you know that the wound is already consolidated.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this kind of stitch with needles is much more convenient for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For it is enough in the stitch of these that one needle, or two, or around them.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	But the second common stitch is to join with the stitch the four ends: the two ends of the skin, and the two ends of the thread in one thread, with a needle in which the fillet is wound equally in thickness and subtlety, and
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you pierce with the needle the four ends, bring them back from the part from which you started in the same way, so that the thread is caught from above on the skin: so that it is a stitch, like the stitch of cloth, and place between each stitch the thickness of the little finger.
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	This kind of stitch is known by men.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this stitch I sewed the wound of a man on his belly, which had been cut by a knife, and the wound was large enough for a palm: and about two palms of middle intestine came out from inside, and there was a break in the middle of the abdomen.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	So he reduced that after twenty hours had passed.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	The wound was consolidated in the space that had been around fifteen days: and I took care of him, and he recovered: and after that he lived for many years, in his own condition.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the doctors judged that he would not recover.
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And from a miracle it was that I did not cure him with ointment.
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	For I was in a place where the ointment was not available, and there were no medicines.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	I then put on the patch twice a day, and I kept washing it with honey water until it healed.
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	But two kinds of stitches, I will speak about according to the narrative.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And is, as you begin with sharp stitch: and introduce it from the outside to the inside part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	And when the needle has penetrated into the skin, and has gone into a loop according to the length and width of all the body: let go of the end of the thread on the outside in which you have introduced the needle, and make it penetrate from the inside part to the outside on the opposite side.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	And when you have made it penetrate, then make it penetrate again in the same end towards the inside: and let go of the end of the thread that is in this side, and make it penetrate from the outside part to the inside: and let go of the end of the thread, which is in this side, and make it penetrate with your penetration so that you make it penetrate into the end of the thread, which is in the opposite side, until it penetrates all of itself.
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then also from this same side, and pull out the thread with the end that is outside, and bring it out of the skin where it has penetrated.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then also reduce it into that skin, and pull out the end of the thread that is outside, and bring it out of the skin where it has penetrated. Then also make this end go around in that side with the other end towards the inside: and bring out of the skin what is from that part, and make it go back and forth until it is all outside according to that example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the height of this stitch is as the sutures of the skin: so that the end of the thread that goes around from one side to the other, makes a loop; and so let go of it from one side, until you have completed it all.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	Secunda species suterae propriae, quam dizit Galen.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	The text translates to: "The second type of sutures are those which Galen mentions. This is the description he gives, that they should be applied in a way similar to the way in which one joins together all the parts by nature: and they should apply one end to another, and one end to a third.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is what I will tell you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	You should fix it so that it penetrates into the inner part, leaving it from the outside: and you shall leave the two ends of the suture together.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then, turn the wound around, so that it penetrates from the outside to the inside on both ends of the suture, that is to say, from each side.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn both of them around as well, and let them penetrate from the inside to the outside, on both ends of the suture, that is to say, from each side, so that they penetrate on opposite sides, which are next to each other.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of stitching is better than the common simple stitch, and it is a stitch whose precursor was remembered.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is therefore the speech of Galen as well.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some said:
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture of the hand with two fingers.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is to say, you should insert one thread into both of them: and begin with the insertion of the needle from your side, for that is where it is, and let it penetrate all the way to the other side; following the sutures of those who are equal in their nature.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And you should know that when the break is in the middle of the hand: then the suture of that hand is more difficult than that of the other places of the hand.For if one will begin to stitch from the place where the break begins, and will go towards the center of the hand, he will have a hard task: for he will need to
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	Judgment in fact of medicine for the wound, is judgment of other wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is to say, for when you have got the wound fresh with its blood, before it changes itself; and you reduce its intestines, and its own flesh, and make it fit: then place it over the powder of the scar.For this powder is good for the scar: and it will give strength to the scar and make it firm.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	If the bone has been damaged by air: then place on it some ointments that are present with you until the pus forms: and let the threads fall, and become firm the Sifac, and mirach.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for that as is the cure of other wounds, until it heals.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if you do not have with you the medicines, then place on it immediately, so that the pus begins to emit, and change the dressing every day as I have taught you, until it heals.
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need other medicine in many dispositions when wounds are simple.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	But if you should be in a time that the wound communicates with the main members in injury, then it is necessary that you dip the wool in oil of moderate heat, or in rosewater: and place it in the circumferent places which are between the hips, and under the armpits.
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	That if it feels pain, or punctures, or putrefaction in its intestines (for this often happens) then cleanse the body with wine vinegar, black, warm: especially if putridness has already set in the intestine, and a penetrating discharge has reached the perineum.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And you should know that what is from the large intestine is easier to heal: and that which is from the small intestine is more difficult to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	But the intestine which is called Jejunum does not accept healing from a wound that has befallen it at all: and this is because of its multiplicity, being from blood vessels, and its size, and because of the softness of its body, and the nearness of its nerves' nature.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	But if that which proceeds from the wound is clear, and you have succeeded in collecting it: reduce it according to your reduction, by which you reduce the intestines equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if it has passed the space, and has already become dark or light: then it is necessary that you tighten it with a thread above the place which has been darkened by it, so that blood does not flow out.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	In zibro enim sunt uenae et arteriae.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	For then cut what is beyond that ligament, and place the two ends of a thread hanging from the lower part of the wound outside itself: so that its attraction above you is alleviated, and its extraction from the zib is facilitated, and the pus of the wound is released.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remembering the wound that happened in the Intestines.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When the rupture happened in the Intestines, and it was small: then it is possible that, in some people, it can be restored: for I saw who was wounded in his belly with a lance blow, and he had an old wound on the right side of his stomach, and it had become a fistula, and exuded a discharge, and there was a hemorrhoid.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	So I applied the treatment, until I was not confident in its cure: and I did not hesitate to examine it, until it was cured, and the site was consolidated.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw the site had been consolidated, I feared on the illness that could happen to the belly after a bad accident: and it did not happen to him from that accident.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better conditions, eating and drinking, and enjoying himself, and entering a bath, and exercising himself in his diet.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some experimenters said, for when a wound happens in the Intestines, and it is small: then it should be bound according to this way.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is, that you take big ants' heads.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then gather two lips of the wound, and place one ant with an open mouth over the two lips of the wound.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	So when you hold it above it, and squeeze its mouth, it is cut off, for it adheres and does not release itself.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant next to the first one, and do not stop doing that with the ant after the second amount of wound of all.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce the stump, and cut the sinew.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	Now if any remaining head of the bowel is attached to the intestine, remove it until the intestine is complete and healthy, and do not cause harm to the entire gut.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And it is also possible that the intestine be tied with a thin thread: which, when removed from the animal, remains attached to it after it enters the bag.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is as if you were to take the end of this thread from the intestine, and cut away much flesh.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then tie the end of this thread with a thin, wrapped thread.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert that thread into the bag, and sewed to it with the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then reduce the stump to dissection.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of sewing with a needle and thread is not but second to the first in trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	You should know that the sinew is great and wide, especially if it is in one of the small intestines: then it is not a skill but cutting, and its healing is entirely incomplete.
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	Regarding the care of the scrotum and fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Head 78.
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	You should know that every sinew, or when it has grown old and aged, becomes a wound, does not heal, and always discharges pus, and does not close: then it is called a fistula everywhere that it may be, and we call this very thing by the name of Zuchema.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula is second only to the truth in being filtered, hard, white; it does not cause pain, and has stiff feathers: because of this it is called by some as risatus, that is, feather.
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And it is sometimes moist in hours when it discharges pus.
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps it splits the moisture at certain times.
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And when this moisture is much, and little: and thick, and thin.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I have already pre-empted in the division, then when I said sinews, that every wound which does not heal, and does not grow in it flesh, is not but for one of causes.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	One of these is due to the scarcity of blood in the body; or because of the malice of his disease; or because between himself and his lips there is hard flesh, which prevents the birth of flesh; or because it is full of noise and filth; or because the wound in his sebo is putrid, and the matter that is shed from it is of a bad quality; or because the remedy is inappropriate for its cure; or because corruption falling upon the region is the kind of pestilence, or by virtue of the region itself, as happened in Caesaraugusta; in which place it becomes difficult to digest the sicknesses, and the healing of ulcers through nature is delayed; or because in him there is only one jaw, or a small number of bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have already shown you all the causes and signs of them, and the treatments for them with surgeons divided up: and it is necessary here that I should show you the treatment of the fistula and the zuken, which is carried out by means of a surgical operation with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	So you know that the fistula happens in all parts of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For from them are the fistulas which reach the great veins and arteries, or nerves, or intestina, or urethra, or some of the ribs, or some of the vertebral bones, or some of the joints of the body, such as the hands and feet: and from them are those which reach the vicinity of principal members, and similar ones.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Which, however, of these fistulas is according to this mode, is from a difficult sickness which does not receive healing, and is an occupation with it, a labour and ignorance. Quod autem de Fistula scis, quae ex Aegritudinis, est per uiam operationis curanda, et non per injuriam: nam in illis uel in uesica, uel in intestinis, uel in costibus, uel
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	That, however, of the fistulas do you know, which come from sicknesses, are to be cured by means of an operation, and not by injury: for in them or in the urethra, or in the intestina, or in the ribs, or in the vertebral bones, or in some of the joints of the body, there is a depth which does not reach these places which I have mentioned; and you hope, and trust in the healing of them, and examine them with your hand: then take a piece of brass or iron, if the fistula tends along the straight line, and investigate it with that.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	If, however, there is a curvature in the fistula, then investigate it with a thin lead probe.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	For lead nhẹly allays the pain of the body, and it eases the curvature around the tortuosity.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	That if the fistula has multiple openings, you cannot make a sign over it with a probe.
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	So apply a clister from one of its openings through one of its openings.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For humidity which the clister applies to it, goes towards other openings, and runs out of them.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then inquire, according to how you are able to: that you may learn that there is an opening, or a nerve, and it is a fistula distant or near: or is a fistula with many openings, and it lies over all of it, with your greatest power: when you ask the question, which asks about the sick, and find out the pain by pressing with your hand to the spot, and similar signs and causes of symptoms apart from the explanation.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When you have thus stood over all of them with a true station, then proceed to the cure according to confidence: and is, when you consider then, if it is a fistula near appearing, or in a safe place far from an opening, or from a nerve, or artery, or vein, or one of the places which I have told you: then stop up the fistula according to what has been said above, and remove what is in it from filtration, and rotten flesh, which comes out of its opening from the flesh, or the fat, and similar things: and cure it, until it heals.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If, however, the fistula is in a deep distance, and is in a straight line: then it is necessary that you should separate it in depth as far as you are able to do.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then cleanse it completely from all of its corrupted flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer a solution of the iodic in acute medicines: and introduce it into the fistula as much as you can comprehend with iron: and do so sometimes, until the corrosive medicine has eaten away all that is left in the fistula's concavity from corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with ointments that generate healthy flesh, until it is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	But if it does not heal by means of that, then cauterize it according to what we have said.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	But if the cause is a fistula and it has been certified by you: then examine that person and dry that person up according to what we told you: if it does not restrain you from anything of new growth, or nerve, or main member, as we have said.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	But if a tooth has been detected in it and there is some corruption and blackening: then shave that tooth, until the whole corruption is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for that person with the ointment that incarnates the flesh, until it is healed.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	That if it does not heal and discharges pus as it did before: then you should know that you have not achieved the total eradication of the corruption.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	So examine it again and carefully feel the area, and thoroughly clean it with your last strength.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore that person.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	But if it is healed, then it is good: and if not, then you should know that that corruption is deep in the distance of the body, which you have not succeeded in reaching.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	It is therefore not within your control to heal it, unless you let nature take its course.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	But if the corruption is in a small tooth and it is possible for you, attract that tooth with slender instruments which suit that purpose.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	But if there are many bones, then carefully feel all of them, and do not let anything go with your strength.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	But if it causes you any opposite sensation from moisture, and there is no fear or mistake in cutting them: then cut the moisture and flesh, if they are there, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	But if you do not have the preparation to remove the bones at your own time, then place over the joint what will decay that person: and let it go, until it decays what is around those bones from flesh and moisture.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And guard the limb so that it does not heal badly.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And tighten the wound as you sewed in your operation.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	By placing a bit of lime on top of the wound, if necessary, rub it with sulfur after having dipped it in oil; or dip it in Egyptian ointment, or some other kind of ointment.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those certain humors putrefy and the bones separate from them, their removal relieves them and attracts them away.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If, however, there is one large bone, such as the leg or hip, and it is rotten, then cut off that part with a saw until the blackness and corruption is removed.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the limb.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If, however, what is rotten in it is a large part and the corruption has already reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to cut off the limb, and to cut into it all the way until the place where the corruption lies: then care for the wound, until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I will tell you about the injury that happened to the man in his leg as an example and a help for your operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	He was a young man of about thirty years of age, to whom pain came in his leg from within the body, that is, from the insides, until it reached the bone, and there was an ulcer, large and open, and he had no external cause.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	So the time went by with him in the error of doctors until the ulcer was opened wide and many substances gathered there.
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And his treatment was delayed until the leg was closed up and many holes were made in it: all of which discharged pus and the humors of the body.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	He was then treated for two years by a multitude of doctors, and there was no wise man in the art of hands, until I was called upon to see his leg, and saw that the matter that was flowing out of its orifices went away with a great course: also all his body was very weak, and his color had become cerulean.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	Therefore he inserted his hand into one of the orifices and his hand reached the mouth.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings: and I found that they came to an end within him in one joint of his leg.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	Then I bent on and cut through one of those openings until I reached a bone part: and I found it decayed: which was already decayed, and rotten, and putrid, and pierced all the way through to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I sharpened the end of what I had found, and made it smooth from the corrupt bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I left behind that which was not bone, but only decay; and I sharpened and made smooth what remained.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I had now cut away all of it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I set the wound with medicine made from a long-dried poultice.
Et non est consolidatum.	And this was not made firm.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I tried again, and found a second bone above the first detection: and I found that corruption continued to the bone; and I sharpened what seemed to me also from that corruption.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I tried to set the wound.
Et non est restauratum.	And this was not set.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	Then I tried again to detect it, and did not cease striking the bone in pieces, and trying to set its wound; and it was not set, until I struck out of the bone a little palm-sized piece, and pulled it out with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I set that wound with medicine, and it was soon healed; and this repetition of the operation and sawing through it was not necessary, unless for the weakness of the nurse, and her lack of tolerance, and her fear of me over him: for it happened to him in all hours from bad discharge of pus.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was then healed by sound health: and there grew up a new bone in place of the old one, and his disposition in his body was good, and he regained his strength: and he did not do him any harm in walking at all.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If however the jaw is prominent in the place of the body already broken: then it is necessary that you hold him thus: and he is: that you take the ligament, and tighten him at the end of the prominent bone: and order someone who extends him upwards: and put another ligament from wool on the first one.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the bone on top of the meat, which is below the bone: and extend its end so that you pull the flesh downward: and you cover the flesh over the place where you want to cut it, so as not to hurt the saw when cutting the flesh.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place the board below the bone slightly: for when you do this, it does not prevent you from cutting the corrupted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that it be a little higher than the corrupted place, so as not to appear on the appearance of its own sense, and forcing the force of its own device: and another screw should appear in its appearance.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	That if the bone is corrupted and not prominent, a part of it continues with another part: and the corruption is in the middle of it, or in one of its parts: then you cover all the meat with all its parts.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place the board below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then cut that from the first part where there is corruption, until it continues with another part of the screw: and let the screw be of about the same length as the corruption, according to what we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	That if the corruption is in the joint, cut that joint that is corrupted, and then cut the bone where it continues from another part:
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if the corruption is in the continuation of two joints, then there is no other connection but an abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	That if the corruption is in the knuckle of the hand, or in the knuckle of the foot: then the matter is difficult to manage greatly.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But you should ask how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape it off, and clean it up according to how it appears to you in any way that is possible for you, and with whatever skill you can master: when it does not make you a contrary vein or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that incisions and saws are many for incision of these bones according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness and fineness, and their size, and their smoothness, and their hardness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that you prepare the tool suitable for this operation for all kinds of operations.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations require a lot of time when studying the instrument you hold in your hand.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the methods of this art is a witness to the methods of diseases: for then you will discover through yourself that which suits him from instruments for every disease.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments that you set out as examples on which you cut, and a proof of what you experienced on others.
Forma Serrae.	Form of the saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Form of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of an alternate saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of an alternate saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the saw is drawn, but not made to perfection.
