Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its bow be higher and its sharpness from iron: and its handle from beech, and let its pyramid be made decentered.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Form of the rasors joined together.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this razor be shaped like a star's claw: and its points be shaped like the points of an elk-fang.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not suit you unless you join with it the heads of the razors when they corrode, or a wide and large mouth; and it is wide and great.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Form of the larger razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	Form of the medium razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	Form of the wide razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Form of the razor with a concave shape.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Form of an alternate thin razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Form of an alternate curved-end razor.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Form of the small, thin razor for the tip of the finger.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Form of the razor used to cut bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Form also of the large razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is like a radio, and the ends are like a saw: it is shown in many places from the reason of the bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape of a saw which agrees with its sawing that which is pierced out from the bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its ends are triangular, its corners are acute.
Fit ex Indi.	It fits from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And likewise it is necessary that all which we have said of the saw should be of the chisel and of the saw.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	About the incising of the ends and the locking of the bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The ends putrefy, or for an extrinsic cause, or an intrinsic one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have been wounded by that corruption with the cure of medicines, and it does not confer the cure: and you see that corruption extending to the member, where there is no consequence of corruption; then it is necessary that you should extend the cut to the place where the consequence of corruption follows, in order that the sick may be healed from that death, or from that greater malice which is the defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign to which that happens is that the member is disfigured, until it is healed: that it is burned by fire, or putrefied after being red: until it is extended to that corruption which follows that member, and creeps into all the body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore approach with its incising, and likewise if the cause of corruption is from some venoms that are pierced: like the scorpion marine, and the bee, and the nettle, and others similar to them.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption, or the piercing is in the end of a finger, then cut the finger, and do not leave space for the corruption to run, so that it may run up to the remaining hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And likewise if that happens in a hand, then cut it from the root of a sharp tool, and do not leave space for the corruption to run, until it takes up into the arm of the sharp tool.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it has grown into that, then cut the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If however corruption has passed over and you see that he is surrounded by pus: then in him is death the nurse.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And besides that cure, it is a matter of amount of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And also do the same with the foot, when corruption appears in the nail, then cut it right at one knuckle: and if it goes into the sole of the foot, then cut the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	That which if corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no hope in it but to cut off, and leave it to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the mode of cutting a limb, or of stretching it out is, that you may tighten the ligament below, which you wish to cut: and tighten another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And stretch one minister of the ligament downward: and stretch another minister of the ligament upward upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you shall separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments, with the spatus or chisel, until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut it, or stretch it out.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And you should place a sheet of linen cloth so that it does not touch the sound part, and cut off the wound with an edge, adding a hot poultice: and apply to the sick a poultice of cold.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if while you are working blood flows inwards, then cauterize the place quickly: or put on it some powder that stops the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then go back to your own medication, until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a proper ligament, and take care of it, until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I will tell you what happened to the man in his foot, this same thing that I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened to the man's foot, that was burned by the same fire that makes ash; and that corruption first began in his toe, until it came to his whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	So he cut away the cord from itself, when he saw the corruption touching a member with a great swelling, which was caused by pain and burning; and he cut it himself at the joint, and he recovered.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after he had passed a long time, that same corruption happened to him again in the little finger of his right hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	Then he came to me, and I tried to restore that superfluity with him as soon as I put on the hand with the medicines after purifying his body; and the superfluity did not recur, but it began to heal in another finger: until the corruption began to spread in the hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called me to cut his hand; and I did not want to do so, hoping that the same superfluity would recur on him: and I was also afraid of death when cutting the hand itself.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the strength of the man was above death.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Then he turned away from me and returned to his land; and he came back to me about it, for he was eager, and he cut off all of his hand; and he recovered.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this account until it should be an aid to those who suffer from such a disease: and that it may be understood what is meant, and according to how it is applied.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the Treatment of Syphilis and the Quality of Clustering with Medications
Caput XC.	Head 80
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When it happens that an apostema occurs in some flesh member, and the space of the apostema is prolonged, until it makes a collection of blood; then it breaks, or pierces, and that which is in it is discharged out, leaving behind a hollow place like a well: and the skin that is on top of it is as thin cloth: and does not impring on the last in its corruption, nor prints on the mouth, nor the ligaments: it deserves to be called Sinus: but it is not called Fistula: nevertheless, if it prolongs the space thereof, until it prints the corruption on some of these members, then it is called Fistula, or a fistula.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the cure is that you should strike off his skin as it has grown back; and above all when it has become thin, and like a piece of cloth; and trust that it will not adhere to the place because of its decay.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If, however, you hope that the skin will adhere, and does not bring about that last corruption: and if there is a thickness of flesh there, then cure him with clister: and it is, as you consider, towards the navel.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that is discharged from it has a foul odor: then clisterize him with the Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, and oil, and myrrh, taking equal parts, mixed together in an ointment: and let it boil over fire until it turns red: and let it come to the consistency of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and clisterize it with that navel: and tighten the opening, and let the medicine enter into it for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract him with the expression: make him spend days until the navel is cleaned up, and the foul smell is gone away.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when you clisterize him with water of ash, when this medicine is not present with you: and it is, that you take the ashes of willow wood, or the ashes of holly tree: and pour them on top of it.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then dip it in, and clisterize it with that, until you trust that the navel is already cleaned up.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	That if the sick person does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine, and water of ash, then clisterize him with water and honey, in which has already been mixed some crushed myrrh.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or clisterize him with honey and wine mixed, since of the property of honey is to clean and wash away, and wine makes the navel adhere, especially when there is an abundance of astringency and dryness.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do this sometimes and trust that the corruption of the sinus is now far away: then cleanse him with what he does to give birth to flesh in him.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And is, that you receive from the plaster dyafinicon: and dissolve him with oil of rose, and wine stimulative: or cleanse him with some medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I wrote in the treatise of ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	That if the orifice of the sinus is strict, in which the cannula of the clister does not enter: then enlarge it with iron a little: or put in it licorium infused in Egyptian ointment, or in basilicon ointment, until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the orifice is also wide, then gather his lips with a suture: and let go from it a quantity in which the clister is to be added without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the orifice of him from which runs pus is raised upwards: then dry him up in a lower place that is in him, so that the pus runs down from it: for when pus is stopped up in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from being born in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	That if you are not able to dry the sinus all around below it according to what you want: then try, that you prepare the member with a preparation which runs from it with ease according to how you prepare it for yourself.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try, that you do not retain anything of the pus at all in it: and receive medicines consolidatives which are put on a mark, suited to what you want.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let there be such a quantity of the cloth that it may come into communication with all of the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps in the direct orifice of the sinus hole, a little larger opening of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the ointment soft things over another cloth according to the quantity of the hole: and put it on him at a distance from the orifice of the sinus, that the exit of the pus from it may be eased: and do not remove the large cloth, until after some days a drop.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	That which is above the opening of the sinus, that one who is moved at all times, so that he goes out when it is gathered in him from pus; and know that, that which runs out of it virus, is much or little: or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you consider this place again of the sinus itself, does the lord feel pain in it, or is there no pain in it? And does he feel a puss in it, or not?
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	But when your treatment extends thus far, and you see the matter which comes out above the opening of the sinus, then know that the sinus is already attached, or approximates to attachment: so then loosen it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you loosen the wound, then change the cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if a virus comes out of the sinus after a long space, then do not despair of its attachment, for the healing of it approaches, since there are those who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and those who act in the opposite way.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if a pus comes out of the sinus after many days, then know that the sinus does not attach.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	But if the attachment of the sinus is prolonged, and its duration is prolonged: then add to the drying of medicines, that the doctors may make them, so that they are in their substance wet, and in their virtue dry: as the unguent of dafinicon, when it is added thereto an excess of addition by the zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the greatest of these, when it is cured, that you take the unguent of dafinicon, and dissolve it with olive oil, and rub it on the old wound to the equal substance of its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then confirm the wound with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And this same action of this is done when the unguent of dafinicon is not present with you, honey, when it is heated up, and you use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Take myrrh and aloes and olibanum; prepare a whole mass, and sprinkle it on honey while it is still hot above fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then spread the paste over the poultice and tie it over the wound: and add to it the honey with which you have been mixing, until it has thickened: then sprinkle the powder on the poultice and put it on again, and tie it up.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes add to it long aristolochia, and the roots of the star-lily, and there is a lily; and herb powder, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple, or in a mixture, prepare it thoroughly, and screen the paste: and sprinkle on the honey that you have mixed: and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the infection persists with this treatment and does not heal: then you will know that there is corruption in its depths; or it has already made an impression on the bones, or on the other hard members, or on the ligaments: then treat it with fistula treatment, as has been said.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	As for the cure of the finger called panaris and the scraped nail, and the incision of the digit, and the section.
Caput XCI.	[101]
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaris is a swelling that arises under the nail of the thumb or of the foot, and possibly also under the other nails.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	And when it has persisted and its treatment has been neglected, and has become a sore with pus that is hot: or has rotted, and has sent out pus until it corrupts the nail's root; and possibly also has corrupted it completely, and possibly also has caused its corruption to reach the mouth, until there is a foul odor: and makes the end of the digit thick, and darkens its color.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	And when you treat the wound, keeping to what we have said about its division, and your treatment does not bring relief: then you must cut off all the excess that remains under the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the nail afterwards.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For the cauterization is very hot.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If the bone is truly sound, and the nail also is sound, and the additions of the waxy nail have already compressed the flesh toward the inner parts, and have begun to prick it, and are hurting it: then you should put on a fine radium under the angle of the nail that pricks the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut into the flesh with ease, and put over it what remains of the flesh from the medicines burning, burned until it all moves away.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then the care for that with the nail, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If, however, the corruption has already impressed on the bone, then you should cut into that bone and take it out: for it does not heal at all while it remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see the corruption and the corruption running into the finger, then cut it at one of its joints, according to what has been said above as a reminder.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then the care for that, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, the nail has been worn away, or struck: and there is a severe pain in it, then you should let blood from it first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp Spatula across from above to the nail bed.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard, so that the cut does not go down to the flesh which is under the nail, for you would make happen through it a very painful pain, and it will be a cause of birth of flesh added in place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then the care for that place with him who sits and feels the pain:
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger which is added and born in some hands of men, perhaps is meat-like all over: and perhaps there are bones in it, and perhaps has an nail: and perhaps its birth is in the tendon joint, or is birth in some joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	So then that which is born in some joints of the finger does not move: and that which is born at the tendon joint, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, whoever has this flesh from which it is cut, its section is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	Which is, so that you hit him at the root of himself with a sharp instrument.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But whose birth is in the root of the joint, his cure is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, abstain from cutting him.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But in that one who is born in the finger at the last of the knuckles, then you must hit him with a round incision from the beginning of his flesh all the way to the mouth.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then close the mouth with one of the convenient screws.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound, until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	But the consolidation which happens in the fingers one-by-one, it often happens or from the birth of man, that is, he is born with it, or from the consolidation of the wound, or from the burning of fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, you must remove this consolidation, until the fingers regain their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then put between them a chisel, or rags soaked in rose oil: so that they do not consolidate quickly, and separate them: or put between them a thin lead plate, until the spot consolidates as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And likewise, if a consolidation happens in some fingers with the palm, then dry out that consolidation, according to how it is prepared and suitable for the form of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	As for the incision:
Caput XCII.	Head LII
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	The veins are swollen, large, and full of melancholy fluids which occur in many parts of the body: and most of them are in the legs, especially in those who walk a lot, and carry burdens.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, you should provide strong extraction of the body from black cholera by sometimes extracting it strongly.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then draw blood from the patient with a wide-mouthed bottle.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of these veins with iron is in two ways.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One is, so that they rest, and black blood is extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And another mode is, that the vein should be kept open and all taken out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The sectioning is however done in this way.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	First wrap the limb with warm water until the thick, foul blood has resolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tie the leg tightly around the hip from above to the knee with an underwrap, and make it tight with strips.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry the limb in one, two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then let the blood out with your hand from the lower part of the leg up to the upper, and from the upper part let it flow to the lower; first let the phlebotomists draw the blood.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the limb down to the bottom: until you see that enough blood has come out and that the strength of the blood is bearing up.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie him up; and order him to refrain from foods that cause black cholera: and again allow the bloodletting and phlebotomy when the veins are filled, and it hurts the sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation is however done in this way.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Scrub the leg with a brush if there are many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then dip him into a bath, or wrap him around the limb with warm water until he feels hot and the veins are pulsating; or exercise him hard, if there is no bath available, until he gets warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin in one direction along the vein from top to bottom: or at the end of it near the knee, or at the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a hook and scrape off the scales from all parts until they are gone; and at their appearance, you will see them turn red to black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When you have thus washed it, you will see it white as a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then dip it under the radium, until it is poured out and dried on the skin: hang it with a blind hook, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry off with a cloth close to that cut-section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the loin, until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then clean it with rags as you did, and hang it with a hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry off another cut-section, or multiple ones, if you wish.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then clean it again, and make the last cut near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull it out to the section above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this, until you have pulled it out from the upper section; or with higher sections, until when it has completely come off: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you when you try to pull and clean it: then insert a sharp tool with a double blade, and tie it up, and pull it out; or insert below it Radium: and roll your hand over all of it, until it has completely come off.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And cauterize, so that it does not bleed.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it bleeds, it will be difficult for you to clean it well, and it will enter the body's damage.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have completely pulled it out: then place it on the wound-place soaked with wine and rose oil, or oil: and care for it, until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vine is contracted, having a twist to its parts, and it does not correspond as we said according to its rectitude: then you must find on it for all of its twists, and the locations of its inverting.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then hang it with a hook until you have completely cleaned it; and be careful near the cut-section on you, or wound: for it will be difficult to clean you, or to pull it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Then preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	Form of wound that heals.
Forma Vncini caeci.	Form of the blind hook.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not as delicate as the other fingers, nor are its extremities acute, so that it does not hurt when it touches; and it is pliable, soft: for if it were slight, it would injure with its slenderness; but there is a surplus softness in it, as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of a vein from the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Title: On the extraction of a vein from the leg.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in warm countries, such as the Al-Jazira and the lands of the Arabs, and in arid, warm lands, scarce and tender, that is, in places where grass does not grow and trees do not spring up.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from the putrefaction which occurs under the skin, just as it happens within the bodies of snakes and worms, and worms are generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein is that which occurs in the leg, a painful swelling.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the spot becomes sore.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to issue from the spot of the sore, as if it were a root of a plant, or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When this extremities begins to appear, then you should twist around upon it a leaden rod, the weight of which is equal to two drachmas and a half, until it reaches two drachmas; and remove the leaden rod from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever this issues out anything to the outside, twist it around upon the lead, and mark it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	That if it is prolonged for a long time, then cut off a part of it, and twist around the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut off its root before it has completely issued out.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it, it will contract, and go into the flesh; and it will cause an ulcer to form, putrefaction in the place, and a bad sore.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	For this reason it is necessary that they should be gently pulled out, little by little, until they have come out of their very ends and nothing remains of them in the body: and from this vein emerges in some men which is in length five palms and ten fingers.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it had reached me, for he had come out of twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if you are injured during your treatment: then insert a ray into the hole and pierce it with a long ray along with the body until all of what is in it has come out, and administer decay to the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care of yourself by taking care of the wounds.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears in the joint of the foot or in the foot itself: and many openings happen to it, and a branch comes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Take care therefore of herself, as we have said in the division, and with that which has been mentioned above.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Regarding the cutting above the worms that are born under the skin, and it is called the evil boil.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter XCIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This evil is called in our country the evil boil: indeed, it often happens that boils, and is a small wound between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And he showed himself all over the body, going up and down: and it was evident to the sense when he walked with his leg or his arm, until he broke out somewhere on the skin and came out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the corruption of some humble humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As happen worms and snakes, namely earthworms, and roundworms in the stomach.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they are afraid of its malignity.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	For when he walks in the body and lifts up his head and reaches out to a place: then perhaps it opens within him, and comes out, and destroys his eye; and this happens many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	But when you are caring for him and removing him, then that should not be done except by his walking and the appearance of his own feeling.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	So it is necessary that you hold what is above him, and what is below with strong constriction by the ligament.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over him, and remove him.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it is buried in the flesh, and not to harm him itself: then put on the place of cautery with fire, until he dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater what is feared, is his corruption, which corrupts his eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see him already coming to the head near the eye, then tighten under it with good tight pressure.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over him, and remove him.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that he uses his own purification of his body, with physicians who dissolve bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him guard himself from food that generates putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the section on sickness of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Head 105
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This sickness is called in our language Nakir: and it is a pain that happens to some member: then it passes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I have already seen him myself, according to what I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a woman who is sick in some parts of her body.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And he held out his arm, and I saw an inflammation in the armpit in the neck vein.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw one inflammation running with fire, like fire, rising to his shoulder faster than it could be: so that it was like flowing silver, when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Then the pain left that place, and it was fixed in his shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then he sat for an hour, and it ran in the rest of his body, until it came to another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that it was running all over his whole body, according to what I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I marvel at the swiftness with which he replaces one member with another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I too did not see this sickness in my eyes before that one so quickly.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I saw many who suffered from a painful disease that was replaced by a member, and I did not see it with my eyes like I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that it was because she was from those who are found from the wounds of dry eyes, and that is why the sense of sight appears to be so swift.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary for those who are pleased and have moist bodies, unlike the woman, to not appear in this way according to this reason.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you then begin to heal him and the patient feels pain, if it appears to your eyes as we have said, then raise it above him and move it quickly: and dry it out over him until he comes out of that swiftness: and burn the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If, however, you do not see it with your eyes: then heal the member with the drying of the body, and with that which drives out the winds, and with carminative pills when you apply them, and with those of the fern and others.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On Extraction of Arrowheads.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter LXVI. On the Extraction of Arrowheads.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows differ according to their species and according to the places in which they lie in the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	However, there is a difference between them: for some have large points, and some are sharp; and some are cased in the skin, and some are bare.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And of these there are three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And from those there are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And from those there are stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	However, those which lie according to the members, are according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For limbs are of two kinds, those which are joined to the principal members, such as the brain, and the heart, and the liver, and the lung, and the kidneys, and the bowels, and the bladder, and similar ones.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When then falls one of these limbs on you, and appear to you the signs of death which I will tell you about later, then it is necessary that you should remove from him that arrow which is lodged in him, for death comes to him where he is lodged in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these evil signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden deep within the limb, then extract it, and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when the signs of brain injury occur when the arrow enters the skull and pierces the bone and comes out above the brain, it is: for there come from it violent fever, scotoma, dizziness, redness in the eyes, swelling, language paralysis, spasms, confusion of thought, and memory loss.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out of the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is lost and language destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And there comes out of the wound's place a white, slimy fluid similar to pus.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And there comes out of it something similar to meat water.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If then these signs appear to you, then refrain from cure, and extract the arrow if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow that falls into the heart are: it is near the left nipple: and it feels as if it were fixed fast to a hard thing, not to a soft thing.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow has a movement similar to a pulse: and black blood runs from the limb.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And it follows that cold sets in to the limbs, and cold sweat, and fainting fits.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know then, that death is certainly coming near.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow which wounds the lung is the flowing of frothy blood from the limb: and the neck turns pale, and changes color when it is touched.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And it breathes out a great, deep breath: and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into a wound in the chest, which is within the rib cage: then it is close to the lower back; and there is a great pain with a sharp sighing breath, with a sigh; and all the shoulder muscles move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the belly, then perhaps it has come out through a sore caused by undigested food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the belly and comes to rest within it: it may come out through a sore caused by stool, or by a knuckle, or by an intestine that has already been torn.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope for his recovery or for the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow falls into the bladder and comes out through urine: and if it proceeds from there to the outside, and the pain is stronger over the sick body; then you should know that it is a deadly wound.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The rest of the limbs, such as the face, neck, throat, jaw, arm, shoulder, hip, leg, and foot; and also the aids, ribs, spine, and cradle bone, are healed according to many different dispositions; but if the arrow does not hit an artery or a nerve: and the arrow is not harmless.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I will tell you that I saw such things about these arrows, so as to indicate by means of them your recovery.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because a man has an arrow that falls into his tear eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I removed it from him on the other side under the fat of his ear; and he was healed, and there was no injury to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I removed from him another arrow that had fallen into his ear fat under the lower eyelid; and the arrow was now hidden, and I could not get it out except for its end, which was stuck fast to his wood; and it was a large arrow of the arrows of the Turks, with a soft iron point, in which there were no bars.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	He was a Jew, and no accident befell his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I took another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabic arrow, and that is where the ears are.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I followed it up between two arrows; and already it was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	So I was careful when I took it out: and he remained healthy.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I took another arrow from a man who had fallen into his belly; and we thought that he would die of it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After he had therefore lain forty days, and nothing changed in him of his disease, I followed the arrow up; and I was careful on it, and I took it out; and he remained healthy, and no accident befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man to whom the arrow had fallen on his back, and a fracture was set on it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After he had therefore lain seven years, the arrow came out at the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom the arrow had fallen into her belly, and a fracture was set on it, and the arrow remained within her; and nothing changed in her of her disease, and the woman did not find any harm in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man, to whom the arrow had fallen on his face, and a fracture was set on it, and it remained, not finding him much pain; and similar things were many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I took another arrow from the prince of the king, which had fallen on his nose, and already was declining a little to the right side: and the arrow was completely concealed.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	So I was called in to cure him after the loss of the arrow until three days later.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	Then I found the arrow's shaft very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	So I probed it with care, and I did not feel it; but he himself felt the prick and the pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore hoped that it was just a dot at the extreme end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	So I bound the wound with a plaster in which there was healing power and the ability to draw out poison, confident that the place would heal, for it seemed to me that a mark of the arrow would appear on it so that I could cut it off: but nothing like this happened, indicating that the arrow had already struck
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	So I bound it with a plaster for many days: and nothing like this happened, and the break healed in the meantime: and it remained weak because of the removal of the splint for one day, until he felt the arrow in his nose on a certain day.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	So I applied an acute medicine to the wound for many days, until it opened up: and when I tried to touch it, I felt a very slight spot of the arrow still adhering to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound by applying that acute medicine, until the end of the arrow was clearly visible: and time passed me by with him for about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then when the break had healed and it was possible for me to insert my fingers into it, and move them, and it did not come out: then I did not desist from trying, and devised means for it, until on a certain day I managed to take it out with crooked forceps, according to the form of their shape at the end of the arrow, until I took it out.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the break.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the doctors say that the cartilage of the nose has not been restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	So I restored it, and the break healed soundly, and the wound healed completely without any harm to him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you about the quality of taking out arrows: so that you have a rule and a sign about it which I did not mention.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not understood by telling: nor does that book understand it, and the skilled craftsman compares little with much: and when something is missing, he finds a new operation, and a new instrument when things outside this art happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say, therefore, that arrows do not exit from the body except by two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place from which they entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by the opposite side.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And those which exit where they entered, or are proceeding in a fleshy place: and are attracted and exit.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	That if it does not obey to exit at the time in which it falls: then it is necessary that you should let go of it a few days, until it putsrefies the flesh which is around it: and the attraction of it will be alleviated, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And likewise if it is blocked in a bone, and does not obey to you to exit, then let go of it too for a few days: and again bring it out with the attraction and movement every day, until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	That if it does not obey to you to exit after days, then it is necessary that you should perform in the circumferential direction of the arrow in the bone with a sharp instrument until it increases.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it, and pull it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If, however, the arrow is fixed in the osse capiti, and has already proceeded into one of the vents of the brain, and shows some of the accidents I have mentioned: then refrain from attracting the arrow, and let go of it until it is even.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the top, then death does not prolong to it.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, unless it is in a human body, and does not penetrate as far as the top: and remains weak for a few days, and does not happen to him any of those accidents: then use your wit in attracting the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If, however, it is fixed firmly, and does not obey to you to attract: then apply a sharp instrument around the arrow, as I have mentioned: and then take care of the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow is already hidden in the body, and concealed and hidden from sense: then seek it out.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it with some instruments that are suitable for drawing.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot reach it due to the constriction of the bone and the length of the arrow in the deep: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein there: then find it until the bone becomes enlarged, and it becomes possible to remove the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	What if there are ears that need to be held onto: then free the flesh from them on all sides, with all your skill as you can, and use any tools if it cannot be done by holding the ears in a fracture, and their twisting, until they heal.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you administer the extraction of the arrow, wherever it is, then use the twisting of your hands with forceps to all parts, until you make it heal: and the last subtlety, so that the arrow does not break, and it becomes difficult for you to attract it, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	What if you cannot reach it in one hour: then leave it for a few days, until what is around it decomposes.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for indeed bandages If however the opposite causes you to have a flow of blood: then administer what we have said in our book on treatment: and guard your skill from incising bone, or nerve, or string.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer skill in every way that is possible for you to remove the arrow: and let it be with ease, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it should be that when you take out the arrow, it is broken according to its figure, according to what was at the time of the arrow's injury in itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Since it is more careful.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	What if you cannot do that for you: then administer what is possible for you in figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow that comes out from the opposite side, or has already gone out a little to the outside: or makes the tip of the arrow stick out by the sense from the top part of the skin nearby, and you see it sticking out: then cut off over it, and make the section according to the quantity that hold in it forceps.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then attract me: for she herself becomes easy to bring out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If however it is retained in the bone, then turn your hand around according to the curvature, until it presses the Arrow on the bone and strengthens itself for itself: then pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let it go for a few days: then repeat it, until it goes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	That if the Arrow is in her, then push her with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If however it has fallen and the impulse needs to be given: then introduce into her a smooth instrument so that her smoothness enters into the end of the Arrow: then push her with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If however the Arrow is smooth, then push it with an instrument entering within.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the Arrow is relieved through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	That if the Arrow is poisoned, then let there be given to him a whole piece of meat in which is venenum: if you can do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of her with it as far as it goes to that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	That if the Arrow is falling in the breast, or in the belly, or in the bladder, and it is close to something that can be touched by trying, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and then take it out with care from the incision of the flesh, or of the nerve, and then remove it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then tie a string around it, if you see it, and take care of that, until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the pincers, with which the Arrows are removed.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let the ends be similar to the ear, which have been made like irons: when they grasp onto the Arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And there are many kinds of them, great and small, and medium ones, according to the quantity of the Arrow's size, and its thinness, and the narrowness of its wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Form of the Pincer that pushes inwards.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And form impellentis surdi.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the end of the sentence and does not need any translation as it has already been translated into English above.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This is the end of the sentence and does not need any translation as it has already been translated into English above.

¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	§ About the phlebotomy of two veins after the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The phlebotomy of two veins which are after the ears is an oath to ancient catarrhs and hemorragiae and sahafati and bad sores of the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of phlebotomy is according to that which I tell you.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, so that he brushes the head: and rubs the occiput in the site of two veins with a rough cloth with good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then he should tighten the neck of the sick man with a scarf, until two new appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And the sites of them are after the ears in two depressed sites of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	So ask them with your finger, and where you feel the pulse of them under your finger, there are the signs with the caustic.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the phlebotomist's scalpel, and he is that which is called Incidentes.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce him under a new vein in the cut, until the phlebotomist reaches to the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then wash your hand with new blood and cut on the upper side, and pierce a new vein with the cut of the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision is the quantity of two fingers spread out, or about that: and make to come out from the blood as much as you can.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tighten it with a cloth, and let it go, until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And he also preceded in the beginning of the book the incision of ears, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On the venesection of two arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	But two arteries which are in the two temples for venesection as a means of preventing an old haemorrhage, and also to prevent the swelling of the eyes and the palpitations caused by excess fluid flowing out acutely into the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of venesection depends on what I tell you now.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The neck of a weak person should be stretched much until two veins appear clearly and then touch them with your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then, for the signs are with the caustic.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then, after applying the caustic to the skin of the vein at the top with your index finger and inserting the venesection instrument below, pierce the vein above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it as you did in the two other veins, and let the blood flow according to the amount required.
