Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then remove the tourniquet after an hour and place your finger on one of the veins.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then put a cotton wool ball over it and press strongly with your finger on top of it and then remove the pressure slowly until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And the memory of the incision of ears and their extraction preceded at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	On the venesection of a vein on the forehead after the venesection of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	But the means for preventing an old ailment of the face and also to prevent haemorrhage and redness and bad ulcers are as follows:
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of venesection depends on what I tell you now.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The weak neck should be tied up with a bandage until one vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called the fossorial.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its form.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Then place the acute tip of the fossorial which is on top of the vein and hit it with a comb or something else in this way and let the blood flow according to how much you want.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then dissolve the perforation with medicine, and bind it tightly until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes when it opens with a blade.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary that the phlebotomist be of acute ends, like the other phlebotomists, but rather that he be of broad ends.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And phlebotome it according to the incision: for the mouth is near; and perhaps in that [part] the phlebotomist breaks when he is thin.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of phlebotomy Of the veins In two tears.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The procedure for the two veins that are in the two tear ducts of the eyes is to put a ligature on them near the eye, and perhaps in the eye itself; and to stop the blood from flowing by wrapping it up.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is so that it binds the neck of the one who has the fever with a ligature when he bleeds.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then phlebotome them: and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And do the phlebotomy according to the incision a little along the length with the phlebotomist a little and the edge a little, for there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If then the phlebotomist is thin at the end, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make it run out with blood as much as you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put a sheet over them, and bind them by night, and then dissolve them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of phlebotomy Of the veins of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	However, the veins of the nose phlebotomy are to be used for an acute fever and a rushing pulse, and the sicknesses of the face, such as a headache, and the redness that occurs in the face; especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of the phlebotomy for him is so that he binds the neck of the one who is sick.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take the nose of him with your left hand, and take a thin phlebotomist, long; and bind it in the middle of his nose, between what distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the old do not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And you should, when your hand is being taken by the phlebotomist slightly: and make the blood run out according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it up a night one.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For itself is restored quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	The Guide on phlebotomy of the old.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The two, however, of the Guide on phlebotomy is to constrict the feverishness, and to initiate leprous disease, and melancholy diseases, and impetigo and bad ulcers, and corroderents, that is, snake-bites.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of phlebotomy is so that it constricts the sick under both of them with a ligature in his neck: and the artisan stands over the head of the sick person, and the sick sits sitting on the chair.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then the old phlebotomy is done to the width of the broad phlebotomy slightly.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then extract from the blood a measured quantity, or according to that which you see from necessity which is to that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise about the other old.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then solve the ligature, and constrict two old with a medium stringency: so that the sick person does not pre-focus.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let it go until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound is healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	The Guide on phlebotomy of Al-Ghafir.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins, however, of Al-Ghafir phlebotomy is to provide for the alcohol in the mouth, and corruption of the gingival: and bad ulcers: and cracks of the lips, and bad ulcers, also which are in the nose, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of phlebotomy is so that you make the sick person sit before you: and constrict his neck with a ligature.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then roll the person's lips, and look at two old: of which one is on the right side of the mouth, and the second is on the left side of it: and the demonstration of both is by the darkness of amber.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because the ears are covered with a fine black skin.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	So cut both incisions as you cut.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if there is doubt about them on you, and you do not know which are the ears: then intend to the incision of the larger ear, and make known more clearly.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And also do for the two veins that are in the upper lip: and indeed much more runs with this custom: and cut the two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	De Phlebotomia: Veins under the tongue after phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The truth is that the two veins that are under the tongue phlebotomy is to say, that phlebotomy of the head is to the pre-cautions which are in the throat, and the sickness of the mouth, and the sickness of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that it sits sick between your hands before the sun: and make him swallow the juice, and look at his tongue on one side and on the other side: and the color of both turns into blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	So phlebotomy either one or the other: and take care, so that you do not put your hand in their blood-letting.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under them are arteries, and perhaps it happens that the flow of blood comes from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	De the three veins in the bed.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	But the three veins that are phleboto- mized in the bed, are in which the phlebotomy runs with custom in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And the phlebotomy of the ears is made according to two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by piercing with the phlebotomy on the side: or applying to the subtlety of the turning away: or cutting with the phlebotomy on a chisel, and it is sharp.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	So Alnesil is, which is suitable for the section.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And of them are species wide, and subtile according to the width of the veins and the narrowness of the ears: Form phlebotomy with a knife sits wide, as you see it.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	It is appropriate to open new wounds, full, coming from outside, visible, thick, and those that contain thick, turbulent blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomist is less in width, and more subtle at the extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	It is appropriate to perform a phlebotomy of thin veins that contain pale yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	[The text continues with a discussion of the location and characteristics of veins suitable for phlebotomy, and the
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	 basilica, which is one of the three veins suitable for phlebotomy, is the iujiumentum.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the ailments that are below the throat and neck, which are below the chest and abdomen; and it is appropriate for the phlebotomist to be careful when performing this phlebotomy, because an artery is underneath.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If he then makes a mistake and adds the phlebotomy point, he will cut into the artery, and will cause a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is appropriate not to perform phlebotomy with the phlebotomist's knife: but rather it should be done with a cutting action using the Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	That if the basilica does not appear by way of a manifest appearance, then it is appropriate to remove it and change it for another, or you can seek out one of its branches; or perform a phlebotomy at a place where one of its branches passes.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For she is revealed by way of a manifest appearance, and it is cut with the Alnesil phlebotomist's knife, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	But if you wish to perform a phlebotomy of its very same blood, then it is appropriate to touch the point before the brachial artery is tightened, so that you may find the place of pulsation.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then, mark the spot with caustic substances, then the arm, and cut a convoluted wound with the Alnesil phlebotomist'a knife, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And make sure that the impact does not fall through the space from the site of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see that the knot is tightened, and there is swelling at the place that you have marked with caustic substances; then this swelling is swelling of the artery: so remove it from that spot.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood rise up at venesection, like a boy's urine, and it is thin blood, red: then you will know that it is from the blood of an artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore, and place your hand on the long space, and then take away your hand.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	But if blood is cut away (for it is often cut away): then bind the arm firmly, and let go of it: and let him who is ill rest from his motion: and let him sit on a chair.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And let him not move himself for several days, until he is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if blood does not cut you, and does not allow you to medicate yourself at the moment: then cut an artery for you, if it seems to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its ends do contract, and blood is cut away.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of an awl, and find it: or take half, and bind it to the tight spot going down, with thread and flour up to another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is cut away, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	Then if not: then take care of the person with the reminder from the place where the blood was cut away: and cutting away his blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the small wound, and possibility of a bandage from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On venesection from the arm of Fuscus.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	But the veins of Fuscus are a phlebotomy aid, which draws blood from the upper part of the head and lower body: since it is composed of the branch of the Basilica and the branch of the Cerebrum, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it belongs to the phlebotomist to take her, so that he is afraid of venesection from her, for a nerve is under her.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	But if he adds into the venesection a phlebotomy, and finds a nerve, it happens to her that she is in a stupor, and it is difficult for her to recover, and perhaps she does not recover thoroughly.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in some men, and is fine, and does not show itself: then you should put your phlebotomy on them by which they are phlebotomized, with the cut of Alne-sil, and the removal of nerves with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	That if it is between two nerves, then find a nerve in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the head.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	But the phlebotomy of the cerebral vein is a holdback, because it draws blood from the head, and contributes to eye illnesses.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this own vein, if you want, that you phlebotomize it by pricking with the phlebotome oil, or with the phlebotome myrrh: because it is salutary for all veins, because it is not below an artery, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	But it is necessary for you to phlebotomize, that you take the skin off with the phlebotome only a little on the head, and seek a easier place: and it does not hurt him, if it is not found with the punch first, so that it returns over it with phlebotomy sometimes.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	But perhaps he is apustulated when he is not phlebotomized in the first punch, but it does not hurt him that apustulation in some.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the usefulness of Phlebotomy and precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality also of Phlebotomy, and the accidents of it out of it, on which you should think.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First therefore of its is that you need to know, that phlebotomy is administered not, unless in the conservation of health, and perseverance of it, and precaution from advent of illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And let there be made phlebotomy in one veins of three which are on the bed, that is the cerebral, and the fusca, and the basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And let there be made phlebotomy in the beginning of spring on fast, in truth, and summer: and in autumn, and winter after meal, when apparent signs of repletion.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let phlebotomy be done on the first day, or on the third day, after three hours have passed.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	But phlebotomy which is administered to the sick does not have a determined time; but when it provokes convenience and necessity for it, at night, or day, and at all times, and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not necessary that the boys should be bled until they are fourteen years old.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a pregnant woman be bled until the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should old people be bled who have already passed sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	But when anyone wishes to have phlebotomy done in any way: it is necessary that he should clean his intestines before phlebotomy with a laxative, if there is much retained dung in them: so that the blood does not attract venereal diseases from the intestinal secretions that are harmful to the main members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should a patient who is constipated be bled, that is, nausea: nor intoxicated people, until they have removed the intoxication from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor a sick person with hydrophobia.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be repeated after a fever, a bout of sickness, a flow of blood, an increase in sexual intercourse, labor, exercise, vigils, fasting, or any other thing that dissolves virtue from the body or from animals.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider with care the humors before that, if the blood is thick with food and drinks, and medicines: if possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then apply a hot bath, if he does not prohibit it for anything: or exercise himself in some exercise, to make the blood subtilize.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place phlebotomy on his chest in his secret place about the third day of the week, as we have said: and consider, so that his chest is emptied of all animal evils on that day: such as anger, fear, and worry: and of all bodily evils, such as labor, pain, excesses, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And so that he may make those things present which are related to his habit, out of aromatic substances, and odour, and mirth, and similar things for the possibility of quantity.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	And then the phlebotomist will sit on top of the arm, which should be higher than the arm that is being phlebotomized: then he will take his own arm, and rub it with his hand twice, or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then he will tie the ligature with a thong, and wrap it around twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And the constriction should be tempered, because the constriction is uneven, or by excess in the constriction, then it prevents the flow of blood: or in softening, then also it prevents the course of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the constriction, so that he rubs his hands together in a clockwise direction, until they are red and feel warm, and reveals the sensation to the touch.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist will wipe off the phlebotomy with a little old oil of his own.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he will place his index finger of his left hand on the vein under the spot where he intends to perform the phlebotomy, just a little: so that the blood does not run away, and the sensation of pain is prevented.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because the veins are those from which blood flows like a string when phlebotomy is performed: and they are the ones that are full of blood: and when you place the phlebotomy on it, it is squeezed under the phlebotomist, and the phlebotomist is deceived, and does not open the vein: and if he opens it, it is constricted: therefore, so that he may tighten it, and be alert in all these things,
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he will place the phlebotomy.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If then one vein opens from a single vein, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat the same vein below that place a little, or above it with some haste: if not, then the spot will not be stimulated.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	That if it is stimulated, or it hurts, then release him for a day, or two days: and do not tie the ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	The hot poultice would attract the abscess.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And let there be no bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then let him draw blood, if he wishes it.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or the blood flows finely: and beware that you do not lose an excessive amount of blood: then repeat the phlebotomy at the same place according to the direction, and add a little to the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do it with speed, before the place becomes infected: for the place will become infected in many people during a small procedure.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	But if you see that he has already been lanced, then do not touch the place at all, for you would not excuse yourself from doing anything before me.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put on the place some of the feces of oil: for it soothes the course of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than the person's own oil, and than any other oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the feces of oil in all your phlebotomies, when you phlebotomy veins at a time when the course of blood is forbidden: and they make it myrrh, and saffron, when it is put from one of them on the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For blood becomes finer and thinner, when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If it happens that there is a large abscess at the place of phlebotomy, for many times it happens, especially if he has not been phlebotomized except at this time, or if there is a small opening in the vein, then tie and put on the place a sponge Infused with water and salt, gently heated: and string it for an hour: for it will be resolved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And you should, so that you make the thing after the departure of blood from the vein of its own, with its complement, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	That if there remains in the place after a few days of blackening, or viridity, it does not harm that thing: and if there is a wound, put on the place some of the oil, or dissolved myrrh: or some of the juice of mint, that is, calamus or something like it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And often too there occur ruptures and eminences at the venesection of the basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	So put your hand upon it; and then if you find it soft to the touch when you press it with your hand, then that eminence is a bad one.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	So cause you to put something of that which we have said upon it.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from it of the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster with it where there is a stain so that the place may heal.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound with the rest of the cure until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary so that every man should take the blood of an ox according to the quantity of its strength.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears from a red hue on the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it not go out until it turns red; and likewise if you see it thick: then let it not go out until it thins out: and likewise if it is sharp, then let its sharpness be taken away.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for the one that is full, strong, and resistant to the extraction of blood by a single stroke, so that the venesection of the leg may be increased, and that the phlebotomist should stand on its side: and in the one that is weak, that it may be on the contrary.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary so that he draws the blood out through a vein, and that there be a closed passage: and it is better if it is administered in venesection of the leg, that it be a transverse cut, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of venesection is salutary from the flow of blood, and from the cutting of the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy, and healthier than venesection by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it is customary to have syncope at venesection, let him eat before venesection with moderate bread in grape juice: or wine-skin if it is warm: and let blood from the three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	If the complexion is cold, then before phlebotomy he should take food infused with honey syrup, or with a syrup infused with spices, or with a scented syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If syncopes occur during phlebotomy and the cause is multiple exits of blood: then he should drink a broth of meat water, and syrup with subtle odor: and apply aromatics with algarrobite, and open his chest with it: and use all the things we have mentioned in the chapter on syncopes in case of draining.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But if he wants to stop the arm from bleeding and let his blood out slowly: it is necessary for him who has phlebotomy because of a lot of drain, and his strength is weak, that he should let his blood out little by little through a quantity of strength in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	But if he wants to stop the arm from bleeding and let his blood out for the second time, and his body is strong: then he should do it after seven or nine hours from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	But if he wants to draw blood from his body towards the opposite part to which he tilts: it is necessary for him that he stops it on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In which body there is already much blood heated and it becomes acute and causes a fever to occur: it is necessary for him to let out blood in one beat, and extract a lot of quantity: and increase the opening until the syncopes occur: after you have kept all the conditions of phlebotomy: and put your hand on its pulse at the site of blood flow, so that death does not occur at the place of syncopes.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Because this often happens when the phlebotomist ignores it and falls by negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not good when you want to stop the arm and let your blood out for the second time, while the opening of the vein is already closed, and the exit of the blood becomes difficult, so that it rushes on him with a sudden movement, and it extends quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	This is bad for a long time; then cut off itself, until it bleeds again.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with the acuteness of phlebotomy that which has coagulated from blood in the orifice of the rectum, and put on top of it some dissolved salt in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put on top of it some from the Tyrocum or the Sageene, and put the compress on gently, until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	But if the anal opening is already wide open, then let it go, and do not squeeze it, until it closes up.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	That if necessity compels to the bleeding again, and there is no excuse, then either phlebotomize the person above that place, or in another arm in another anus.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But the vein of the arm is phlebotomized at the place of the Fossa and the Basilica, if they are not found, and are hidden, because it is composed from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that the sick person puts his hand in hot water, until it turns red, and the anus appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then let a slightly tight ligature be strung over it.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then let the second phlebotomy be made little by little, not acrosswise, and not along its length; and let the opening be wide enough, and your phlebotomy be such that you phlebotomize it above the incision of the hand just a little bit.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	That if the exit of the blood is stopped, then again put the hand in hot water, and let the blood run into the water, until you satisfy your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you were in the days of summer, then you are excused from the repetition of putting the hand in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed the course of the blood in hot water is long in the time of winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And this phlebotomy of this anus is healthier than all other anuses, because there is no pulsating under it, and there are no nerves.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy of the right hand of salutellae is for those with liver illness.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that you tie the hand with a ligature, or your own hand, after you have introduced it into warm water, until it gets red, and shows a strong sensation.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then phlebotomy her while.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely, it will not hurt that one at all.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And preserve, so that you do not lose your hand with phlebotomy.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under it are the nerves of the fingers bare from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then repeat the hand to hot water, and let the blood run in her.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not repeat her in hot water, the blood will clot in the hole of the vein, and it is stopped from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	But when you extract a quantity of blood as needed, then put oil and salt on the vein so that it does not congeal quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And likewise it is necessary to do the same with every tightly bound branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The grip of phlebotomy is on the left hand, for it is suitable for illnesses of the spleen; and likewise do the same with its phlebotomy as you did with the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The grip of phlebotomy, however, is for illnesses that are in the lower part of the body, such as those of the bladder, and retention of the monthly course, and illnesses of the kidneys and old boils and similar ailments from sickness.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that you introduce the sick foot into hot water: and make a friction on it until the vein bursts; and tie above the ligature with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the place of the vein is at the heel, visible towards the thumb: and many branches grow out from it on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	So phlebotomy her in a larger branch of hers, or at the heel in gathering of hers; for it is better and healthier.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you make a phlebotomy on that part [of the body], then caution is needed so that the nerves underneath do not affect the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy where you want to make a phlebotomy from behind, so that you don't hit it: and set up the phlebotomy Nobile.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	But if the exit of blood is prohibited, then wash that part of his foot with warm water: and let the blood run out of it until it empties.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	That if there is a mistake with the phlebotomator in the first cut, then let it remain with phlebotomy to some extent higher, because the place is healthy, and do not fear from it evil when you caution the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And also with the saphenous vein of the other foot evenly.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	But veins of the sciatic region, as we have said, are located near the heel from the outer side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the tension of that phlebotomy is, at the pain of the ankle, when it is due to warm blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of that phlebotomy is, so that it enters into a weak bath, and refreshes: and tighten his leg from the ankle up to the heel with four fingers, with a long thin thread; for it does not appear unless for that.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it does appear, then make the phlebotomy for you as possible according to your art, or according to the transection: and it is better, or as if you hit it with an incision, or cut it off with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For that part of his body is healthier, and it itself is very hidden by many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	That if you do not make it known by sense at all: then phlebotomize some of his ramus, and that is what appears on the back of the foot, and towards the earlobe: and caution the nerves, and let a quantity of blood run out as much as you want.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then tie it tightly, and put it on the part where you made the phlebotomy, and tighten the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	He heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	On ventilation, and on the quality of use thereof.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Vents are made from horns, and from brass, and from iron.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And ventilation is made in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	When there is scarification and extraction of blood, and another kind of ventilation is without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this type of ventilation without scarification has two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	For it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventilations that are given with scarification and extraction of blood are four-and-twenty parts of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of these four-and-twenty parts of the body, one is the Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is last of the head: and Alkehel, and that is middle of the neck: and the vents of Alhagdahim, and they are two laminae of the neck from both sides together: and the vent of the mind, and it is under the mandible at the bottom of the mouth: and the vents of the two spatulas: and the vents of the two claws: and the vents of the two cheeks.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And this type of ventilation does not draw blood from small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of that its strength does not drop out of them, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	And it should not be administered that ventilation whether with fire or without fire in any disease that is caused by accumulation until the whole body has been drained.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity requires ventilation because of a disease, or for the habit, we shall administer it at any hour at the beginning of the month, at the end of it, and at its mid-point, and at any other time.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	That is to say, because there is a man who, when blood accumulates within him, finds relief only through ventilation, and he has a gray hair, and he sweats.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from them comes the swelling and redness on his face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from them comes the itching in his face, forehead, darkness, and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from them comes the place of his wound.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from them comes who has many laughs.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from them comes who has a taste of blood in his mouth: or he spits it out with his tongue, and spits up the blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from them comes who has many dreams.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from them comes who sees in his sleep blood and redness, and those slain, and plagues, and things similar to them.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When then do we see anything from them, and especially if it is in the third month of the year: then do we make the wound heal, after having let pass two hours of the day, or three.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The treatment for the wound on the neck is this: for it brings with it a burden in the head, and because it drips down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it should be after the whole body has been emptied.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this is called a local phlebotomy on the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it should not be used by one who has a cold complexions, or in whom there is catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings about a great injury.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And for this reason, those who are elderly should not use it, and in whose head there are cold diseases.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But whoever uses it with diligence, forgetfulness comes over him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for this reason you should order the wind-sucker to lay his hand with the wind blowing slightly towards the lower part, fearing the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosation, or alcohol, is a local phlebotomy on the purple color, and also on the blue color, and because of it brings about sneezing, constriction of the windpipe, and the裂开（裂开） instrument of constriction, and coughing, and swelling.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	It is necessary that Ventosa Alchehel be driven forth a little further, because if it is put below, it generates weakness in the heart and the stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosation however has a cure for the accidents of headaches and eyes and hemicrania and perforations and pain in the roots of the teeth; and is a place for phlebotomy.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And you should order the Ventosator not to put his hand on the scarification: so that he does not cut an artery and a flow of blood occurs.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	But if it is under the chin, it brings about alcohol in the mouth and corruption of the gums and similar diseases that are in the mouth; and stands in place of phlebotomy for Alieherich, which are in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	But if it is a spatulum, it has a cure for alchafacham, which is caused by a rebound and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	But if it is an internal part of the body, it has a cure for phlebotomy of three veins, Basilica, Fusca and Cephalica: because it itself draws blood from all the small veins in the flesh; and these small veins draw the blood from other larger veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And you should order the Ventosator not to make a lot of scratches: because it is a bare place of flesh, and under it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	But if the Ventosation is done on top of alchausos, it brings about hemorrhoids in the Anus and ulcers from below.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And you should order the Ventosator so that there is a great Wind and that it is made of iron: because the place does not admit to strong suction, and perhaps the fine ones are broken by the Wind; and the large scarification is made.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	But the fine Wind diminishes with a clear appearance: because it draws blood from all the body and brings about old pains in the kidneys and bladders and urinary bladder; causing menses and colic and heat; and stands in place of phlebotomy of two veins, and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	Indeed, the body becomes very weak, and causes fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the treatment of the two cracks of the wind is close to the treatment of the wind.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the winds is that you should place the wind in the first place empty, and moisten with moderate suction: and do not continue the position of the wind, but put them quickly, and shake them quickly so that the humors come to a place of arrival equal: and do not cease to repeat that and continue, until you see the place already red and swollen, and appears the redness of blood: then therefore scrape, and repeat suction slowly.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider in the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For he who is among men with tender flesh, rare pores, should cut himself once, not more: so that the place does not ulcerate.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And instruct the wind-starter so that he amplify the scraping and dig a little: and moderate suction in convenience, and quickly, and movement of his own.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	That if there is grossness in the blood, then you should cut yourself twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In fact the first opening of the subtlety of blood, and its moistening: and in the second perscrutation of the exquisite extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If, however, the blood is fecund very much, then let the scraping be done for the third time: so that the last result is obtained.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And to the last, when we want to extract blood slowly, slightly, one scraping is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	That if we want multiple extractions of blood, then we scrape with multiple scratchings.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick: then it is necessary that scraping be done with a deep scratching: and an equal end in the scratching, is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is that which should be administered from oils at the position of the wind, and what does the wind-starter caution?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that, indeed, whose skin is thick, tough, dark, and whose pores are tight, it is necessary that the places be anointed with open, soothing, and resolving oils: if it is in the time of summer, such as is the oil of several, or olive oil, or almond oil, or oil from sweet almonds, or oil from pumpkin seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the time of winter, then oil of narcissus, or of lily, or of chamomile, or gin: and similar ones.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If, however, there is a lot of superfluity, cold: then oil of wormwood, or of balm, or of almond, or of annatto, or of saffron: and similar ones.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If, however, it is ventous, with open pores, and tender flesh: then it is necessary that oil be forbidden to it, and these places should be washed after fanning with rose water, or cold water, or water of amaranth, or water of pumpkin, or water of portulaca: and similar ones.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	But he whose blood is very humid should wash the ventose places with vinegar, or with myrtle water, and sumach: and similar ones.Et si superfluitas est in pedibus, in calcis, aut in uiris: tunc oportet ut superius locos mictis urini et moco, et similes suis; et quod superius mictur
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	And if there is a lot of superfluity in the feet, in the shoes, or in the feet: then the ventose places should be washed with old wine, or with water of samsou, or with decoction of anet, or of chamomile: and similar ones.Et si superfluitates sunt in capite uiri, aut in labibus: tunc oportet ut superius mictur urina et moco, et quod superius sint alii similes; et quod
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary that the fanning be done in a bath, or in a bathhouse; and it should be administered after leaving the bath for an hour, or two hours.Et si superfluitates sunt in uiris: tunc oportet, ut mictur urina et moco, et quod mictur non sit prope uiris sed per horam, aut per horas duas; et quod
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not fit that any should sleep after dressing.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is the need for one to be bandaged or bled before dressing?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after that, you should consider first of all: if the person is jaundiced and their blood is thick, then their sharpness and inflammation will be due to a lack of cooling, like granatum muzum: also dill with vinegar and lettuce, and secaniabin, and juleb: and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And put on his food porridge, and meat that is sour, and cooked foods with apples: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And if his complexio is cold, he should take syrup of honey, or of almond, or alsecaniabin made from seeds: and he should drink medium-strong wine, which is between new and old: and let him be instructed to eat a little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And put on his food porridge, and hempseed, and paschal eggs, that is to say, many birds: and let him eat pigeon loaves.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink of dressing and phlebotomy be more than the food, and that it be given in wine to some men in Horica tyeroca or a remedy made from musk, that is to say, muscata, or alesselithe before dressing: and before phlebotomy, or after: so as to strengthen the main muscles, and refine the blood.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it is not fit that they drink it warm in hot wine.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	Of dressing without scraping.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Dressings that are without scraping are dressings that are put on top of the liver, and the spleen, and the podagram, and over the navel, and places of the testicles, and the pixie anchae: because these limbs do not suffer from scraping on themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not asked for them, unless there is an outbreak from a member of blood to the limb: as we put dressing on the breasts in the sickness of blood flow from the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them so that we can heal a cold, sore member in the limb: as we put air on top of the bowels, and the navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it itself tightens up the member, and warms it, and removes the pain because it has healed that cold sore.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	Also, we put air on the kidneys when there is an accumulation of dung or stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For with his own power it may well open up a discharge, or remove a stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And also when it is put on the liver, and the spleen when there is a cold sore in either of them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these Wind-sores are dealt with by means of a cut only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are dealt with by fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are given with warm water when there is a pleural illness; and that is, so as to fill the Wind- sore with warm water, or water in which have been boiled herbs suitable for the purpose.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	The form of the Wind-sores dealt with by fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the width of its opening be two fingers wide, according to the shape we have made; and let the quantity of it in the depth be half the palm: and let it be in the back of its place which is about the middle of it, a little hole, according to the quantity that is put into it: let there be also made, of copper, brass, or iron, an equal rod across it, so as not to hurt the limb at its position over it; and let there be in the midst of it a wire of copper, or iron, through which a candle with fire is held.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And this great Wind-sore may also be made, larger than we have described, and a smaller one, according to the illness and age of him who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For the Wind-sores are different in boys, and in those who are weak, from those in men, and in those who have large bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of this wind-sucking application with fire on the arm, that is, to light a flax candle or a small candle with a wick; and put it in the middle of the wound above the skin, so that the fire surrounds the lower part of the wound, so that the body does not burn.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then place it on the arm, and let the finger be placed over the hole that I have said, until we hold it in place: while we hold it, remove the finger, and the vapor will come out of that hole immediately and the wound will open.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then light the flax again in the same way, and repeat it if you want to.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	But in the wound that is applied to pneumonia with water, there is no cross-section and no hole; it is only filled with water and placed on the arm.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this wound, the more it is big, so that it takes a lot of water, is better.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	In suspension of blood sugar.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter LXIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Sanguine sugar are not applied to many members, unless the position of the wound allows it, due to its smallness, such as the lip and the gums, and similar ones.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or on a naked member, stripped of flesh, such as a finger, or a nose, and like them.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality to be used is this: to come from blood sugar that are in sweet water, cleaned from putrefactions.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they are left to rest in sweet water during the day and night, until they become thirsty, and nothing remains in their stomachs.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body is emptied in the first place with phlebotomy, and with wind-sucking.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then wash the wound with water, until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Then put on them.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When they are filled, and fall down, and it is possible to suck the place with wind-sucking, then it is more effective in healing: and if not, then wash the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then, with much water, and knead, and squeeze.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the course of blood is prolonged after the loss of blood and it remains bloody: then pour a cloth made of linen into cold water, and place it on top until the blood clot is removed.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood increases, then sprinkle powder on top of it made of dried blood, or eggshells, and things like that from astringent: until the blood is cut off.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or they place on top of the place half of the ground up bark of oak tree: and they leave it, until the acorn sticks to the place, for the blood is cut off.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And it should be that if the need requires a repeat of the bloodletting, when possible, change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If, however, they prohibit bloodletting by suspension, then clean the place with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or tie them up now in places, until someone leaves.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then they are placed on, for when they feel some of the blood, they stick immediately.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When, however, you want them to fall down, sprinkle on top of them some dried aloe, or salt, or ash: and they fall down immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	Part II
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	The Book of Surgery by Al-Zahrawi (Albucasis) - Part III
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	Section on general principles of restoration, dislocation, treatment of twists, and similar conditions.
Caput I.	Head I:
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This chapter is also often needed in the art of medicine, and it is restoration of a fracture, and dislocation of accidents in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know ye, O sons, that this chapter is for the most part lost to the medical men who are dull-witted and of the herd, and who have never examined the old book, nor read a letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And for this reason it has come to pass, that this mode is secret among us.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I was not occupied with it at all, and I was not qualified in it unless because of the length of reading of the old books, and study over their understanding, until I drew out the science from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then, by experimentation and study, I measured the length of my scar.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.
