Then, I will describe to you from that in this chapter all of my knowledge: and, regarding what was the experiment of mine, after I had abridged it for you, and released it from the occupation of elongation, and abridged it by its end of abbreviation, and showed it by its end of decline: and I formed in it many forms from forms of instruments that are administered in it, because it is from the addition of decline, as I did in two previous chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	Now, and from the fracture of bones, from which it is necessary to begin the re-membering of broken limbs, and diverse, if of each one.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is necessary, that we say in the prolog of this chapter, that summa of discourse and chapters, to which an understanding is considered at first by the artist on the veracity: that is, so that you, and who are ready, know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say, then, that when it happens to someone that there is a fracture, or dislocation, or twist, or a fall: then you should properly, first of all, prepare to phlebotomize him, and solve the wound, or both at the same time: if not forbidden by anything, such as the weakness of virtue: or he is that boy who has something from those things: or he is an old man of senility: or it is a time of great heat, or great cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then, be satisfied with your food, cold drinks, and feathers, and hair: and forbid wine, and fatty meats, and what fills the belly with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until you are secure from heat of apoplexy, and do not wait for the flow of matter to a limb: then return the sick to their usual customs with which he runs.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When the mouth is broken, then it is necessary that the sick person be fed with food rich in nutrients, thick, brown, and full of flavor: just as food made from wheat cooked with water, and rice, and heads and feet and entrails of fowl, and eggs and fish that are fresh: and strong wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	For with this regimen the healing of a fracture takes place more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And know that bones which are broken, when they are in the hands of a man who is in the first age of old age and decay, cannot continue nor consolidate themselves according to their nature always, by reason of the drying up of the limbs of them: but they consolidate themselves and continue such as they are at the end of lightness, like the bones of young boys' small arms.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	However, nature adds something to the broken bone from every part a little glue, in which there is thickness, by which it clings and binds itself, until it is joined together, and bound together, until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was at first, until it does not prevent its operations: and for this reason it is necessary that you put nutriment on the sick food, in which there are thickness, and flavor, and thickness, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And know that the species of fractures are various, according to the diversity of the limbs: for a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the skull, and a fracture of the breastbone is different from a fracture of the spine, and likewise each limb has all its parts very different: and I come with a reminder of every kind of fracture exposed in its own chapter, distinct from the other.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And the species of fractures of bones also differ in themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	For a fracture is made by an arc, except that they happen in a star.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And when a fracture is made according to the length of the bone: and there are fractures of his stagium, that is, stars, and additions coming from, as there are in the stem, when it is caught by a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And do not proceed: and is fracture with ulna and disruption in the head: and is fracture small crack.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And all kinds of people are skilled, or their own instrument in restoring him, according to what will come to his memory, distinguished in their places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from this it is known that the break in the bone, its curvature and eminence: and its appearance to the sense, and its sound when you press it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	So when there is no apparent curvature in the place, and no sound at your touch when you press the bone with agitation, and it does not cause great pain: then it is not a fracture, but possible that there is a curvature or a small crack: so it is not necessary to move it with your hand and squeeze it all, but rather put something from the doctors, for their memory comes about, after the time that suits the place: then tighten the tightness slightly.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you know that the place when it arches and is split into two, apart from what happens in it of satchels, but all its parts are removed from each other: then you should start to correct it from your time, straightening it before it happens to it a swelling of heat.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	But if it happens to him a swelling of heat, then let go of the bone for a few days, until it rests the swelling.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then make the bone equal by any way you can of softness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And you know that the restoration of it, and its equality, is easier than of bone, in which satchels happen.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then tighten it, according to what comes to your memory about it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	But if in the bone are satchels, then necessary is the extension of this broken member from two parts, if it sits with a hand, or with a foot: or with your hand when the member is small: or with two ropes, or with a rope and a hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And set your position so that you place the limb on an equal place, according to its natural figure, until when the parts of the broken member are extended: then take care, that you return them with all your inventiveness, and in whatever way you can in their places: and be careful, according to your strength, that no pain should happen over the weak by your operation, or any fault: and take care, according to your strength, that you apply one two bones with his friend, according to better forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And it is necessary at that hour, that you try and touch him with your own hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If then you see there anything different, straight it out, and make it equal by the quantity of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And be careful about the sudden extension, and the strong compression, as many do with the stiff.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	For often it happens through their own operation that they make the limb hot with a fever, or contract it in the member: for we have seen this thing often from their operations.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then join on after the healing, and on the relaxing of the operation, and on the tightening of the limb, and peace, and calmness: and warn the weak person over it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And make the limb rest, so that it does not move in the hour of its strength, and its sleep when it is in a state of resolution, and agitation, and its movement at its last power.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And be careful, so that the limb does not take a position with which it follows pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	That is, because when it feels the pain of the limb's position, or injury: then it is necessary that you change it to a position other than that from which it does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And be careful with him, so that his position is equal and straight: so that no tortuosity happens in the limb when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of a broken member's tightness is according to what has been said.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	Be aware that broken limbs differ in their length and size and shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	Of which the shorter members, such as the arm, and the finger, and the thumb, and the like, then it should be, that there is a spread of soft cloth, thin.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	But of which the thicker members, such as the hip, and the leg, then it should be, that there is a spread of broad, hard cloth in them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	Since the wide ligament connects the large member, and tightens it with equal tightness from all sides, so that it does not enter it a stain.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then begin after you have drained to place the ointment suitable for that, in a soft cloth over the site of the fracture.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to spread three or four times over the site of the fracture, depending on how much the member is stretched, and lightly tighten your hand with the ligament.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then move it along with you to the upper side from the site of the fracture, and tighten less than how tight your tightening was, which you tightened the broken place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then stretch yourself out with the spread from the site of the fracture a little, and soften the tightness gradually, until you have recovered from the place a large piece.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another clean one, and spread it again over the broken site with spreads.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Then move it along with you to the lower side from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And let your operation be in the tightness of the spread, and in the softening of it, according to what we have said in the first spread above.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place between the spreads a soft cloth, or a cloth, with which it is even the curvature of the fracture, if there is any curvature: and if not, do not place anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then spread again over that other clean one.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	Then make the stars of the spreads even immediately, if there is no swelling or fever at the site.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	If, however, there is swelling or bruising: then place something on top of it to support that bruising, and remove the swelling: and let it go for a few days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then bind firmly to it then stars.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And the stars are from the middle of canes broad, rasped, formed wisely: or they are from wood where cribs are made, which are made from pine, or rags, that is to say, branches of palm, or calix: and let the width of each star be according to this form, and let it have this figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	However, the star that is placed on top of it should be wider and longer by a little bit than the other stars: and the length of the star should be according to what is suitable for the member in size and beauty.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then bind the stars together with another string, starting from the first one to form a group.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then tie from above with a string that is slightly less stiff: and it should be, so that your stiffness covers the fracture spot more: and the less it extends from the fracture, the stiffer it is.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it should be, that the middle strings in thickness and softness are made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	For if the strings are thick, such as is the case with strings used for stiffening of wooden frames in surgery from twisted linen chords, it is a great mistake: because the stiffness comes out of shape with them.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And thin strings do not suit either: for you will not get the desired stiffness with them.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it is not suitable that there be less than a space of a finger between each star.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	That if a sick person is laid between the stars after the stiffness has been applied to the healthy places: then place something soft under them, such as fluffy cloth or red wool, until there is no pain from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When there is a fracture with an injury, and there is a break in the skin, I return to this chapter to remember it in detail.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	You should know that not every broken limb needs to be fixed with splints from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	That is, because the limb when it is big, it should not be placed on top of the splints, unless after five days, or seven, or more, according to your security from blood clots.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the way that the ancient ones used to fix it, which are placed on top of the fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	The common short way of doing the plaster, for restoring the fracture, suitable for many cases, especially for women and children; because it is not hurt by heat or cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is so that you take from the flour that is ground, and there is a dough that hangs on the walls of the gristmill next to the rolling mill: and make it as it is, except that you add chalk to it: and put its coating not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	The other way of doing the plaster, for restoring the fracture and dislocation and torsion.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Take almsgiving, and lauds, and acacia, and cow's milk, and mug; and honey, of all kinds of myrrh, and aloe of both sexes, of the XX parts of alethah, as much as there is, and add it to the chalk, and mix it with water of alethah: or add it to the chalk if the case is warm.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For this is a good composition, it restores the broken bones quickly, and suits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	The other way of doing the plaster, which also suits the fracture and torsion.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Take mug, and almsgiving, and white aloe, of all kinds of myrrh X parts, and of acacia VI parts, and of bolus Armenian XX parts; twist them together with much grinding, and add them to the chalk, and make it with water, or add it to the chalk: and administer.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	The mode of applying plasters for joints, and bones separated from their places: and to assuage the pain, the injury, the cutting of the bone, and the fracture.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Take wool wetted with sour milk, and let it be submerged in vinegar and oil cooked, and let it be placed on the place.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And in this plaster, there is no virtue of restoration, but it is good in the sedation of hot swelling: and it drives away pains by itself.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	The mode of applying plaster, which restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take leaves of fig and leaves of wild papaw: and dry them all, and make a plaster of both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	The mode of applying a short plaster, applied to the restoration of a fracture of a bone: and when you wish to resolve a residual swelling.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Take the root of marigold, and of chamomile, and of flowers of violet, and of herb-weed, all one half: dry them all, and make them with wine, if it is not a heated member.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If it is indeed heated, then make that with coriander seed juice, or with water, and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	The mode of a stronger plaster in the resolution, which is greater than this, when it happens that a swelling is harsh on the restoration of a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Take the root of marigold, and of flax seed, and of poplar bark, and of mealy-seed, and of sweet grass, and of violet flowers, and of chamomile, all one half: dry them all, and make them with water of willows, or with sweet water, or with wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	All this depending on the calor of the member, and on the quieting of heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	Hippocrates indeed did not say in his book, that a plaster placed on a broken member should be made from the ash of the oak and oil: nothing else: and he related, that it should be between harshness and softness.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	But Galen did use, that plasters be placed on a broken member at the restoration of it, in which is an drying up of heat, such as myrrh, and aloe, and olive-oil, and things similar to these from which we have spoken.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	The mode of poultice which is beneficial for injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Take mutton, and chickpeas, and hair of man's teeth, or feathers of birds, and herbs, and equal parts of salt: they are to be ground, and rubbed together, and made into a poultice.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	But as to the quantity, according to what is necessary, so that it remains a dressing, and then dissolves away, consider this then, if pain does not occur, nor itchiness, nor does a broken jaw move from its place: then do not take it away after many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If it happens to him that there is a stinging itchiness, or a troubling pain, or inflammation: then do this, and dissolve it away in the hour itself, and take off the poultice from him: and receive a cloth of wool, or a sea sponge of wool, wet with water: and dip it into the lukewarm water, and wash with it the place, until the itchiness is calmed down, and the pain is soothed.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then let go of the member to rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then put over it a woolen cloth, soaked in vinegar and oil, or oil rubbed with rosewater: and bind it on for the night, so that he is safe from the heat of the sun, and the swelling of the member has ceased, and the pain of his has gone away.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then repeatedly examine him to see if he is healing well, and the poultice is small: but do not bind him with your own constriction first, and soft things, until he has healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that the swelling, and redness, and pain, and inflammation, and all the other accidents have entirely disappeared, and there is no need for the poultice or constriction anymore: then do this again as you did before, equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If not one of those things which I have said happens to the member: then do not take it away, unless after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when the member has been left for twenty days all over, according to what appears to you from the healing of the member, as we have said, until such time as the fracture is healed, and the coagulation of the blood on it is approximate: also add to that then more constriction than your first constriction: and add also in the swelling of food, according to what preceded its remembrance.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	If, however, you see the place of fracture already drying out and becoming more extensive than necessary: then you should know that nourishment is forbidden to reach it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	So wrap the wound with warm water at all times and leave it open for three days and then apply a little ointment.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	Therefore, in this operation, nourishment runs to the limb and is quickly healed.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	But that which the careless healers do from a broken limb, when they do not restore it at first, and then restore it according to its need and restoration according to its bend, is a mistake in their operation and a great fear: and if it had been right, the ancients would have said in their books, and they would have operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I did not see any of their legacy in this at all, and it is better that it should not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	[On the Making of an Injury in the Head.]
Caput III.	Chaps. 3 - On the Making of an Injury
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	(There are various kinds of fractures and many forms of it; and its causes are separate.)
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For the fracture is from a punch which passes all the way through to the other side, which is beneath the bone, as it does in the axe in the wood: and for that reason this kind of fracture is called the axial fracture.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or a blade cuts some bone, and it hits its face, but the cut does not go through to the other side: and this kind of fracture is called the Kalaan fracture, that is, an absolute Let-down.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And there is a joint of two fractures, or a large one, or a small one.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	(And from a fracture is a crushing, or a grinding): and its cause is a punch with a stone, or a fall on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	(And this fracture is also penetrating, which is about to break through a skin, which is beneath the bone): or it is on the surface of the bone: and these two fractures are also small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	It is from a fracture that is hidden in bone and subtle in hair: and it is a small crack, and for this reason this type of fracture is called Capillaris.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And from these is a fracture that happens by accident or by the hitting of a stone, and similar to these, which make a layer of bone go inside, and makes a concavity: as happened with the caldaria of air when it was hit and some of them went inside.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And most certainly this happens in the heads of moist bones, such as are the heads of boys.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And all these types of fractures are separated from each other, and I will add something about this whole thing in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we know all these types of fractures by detecting them and inquiring about them with the help of a probe, and by removing the corrupted flesh that is on them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	The Capillaris species is recognized in this way, that it is detected on the bone and scrubbed and applied with caustice to it: for a fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In the cure of a fracture, consider first the enferms: then if you see from the enferms that it means a clear indication on fear, such as a fever of cholera, and extension, and loss of intellect, and loss of speech, and syncope, and acute fever, and exit of eyes, and their rubor, and similar things to these in many conditions, without a doubt he will not be healed: and if you see that the enferms are not frightening you, and you hope for his recovery: then begin to cure him.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	That is, if a person comes to you wounded for the first time: and it is on a cold day, then one should study to remove the bone before the 24th day according to all conditions.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is on a summer day, then one should remove the bone before the seventh day, before it corrupts what is under the bone from a pannicle, and those accidents that we have described.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	If the fracture of the bone has reached the meninges and is small, then draw it out with attraction; then you must break the broken part and grind it according to what I have told you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And then you must shave the head of the injured person: and find out on the bone in any way possible for you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is more suitable for the sick.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	If you encounter a flow of blood or a hot sweat when you are examining the bone, then oppose it with what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And fill the place with cloth soaked in wine and oil; and let the joint rest until the sweat subsides, and be safe from the flow of blood.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin the treatment of the bone and removal of it.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And make it as one or two ways.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	The one way is to break the bone with a sharp chisel: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then give another Incisory wider by the same width: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then also give a wider Incisory, as wide as the second one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	The second way is to have a number of Incisory tools with different widths, some wider and some narrower: and let the latter be at the extremities of their sharpness, and made of iron or metal; and use ease in striking on the Incisory, so that it does not hurt itself and hurts itself.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	If the bone is strong and hard, then you must drill around it before administering the Incisory with Terraz (an instrument), which do not go deep: for they are not called so unless they do not pass the edge of the bone to that which is behind it: because Terrizo is a round extremity on it, below its sharp head, like an edge, and a small circle prevents sinking into it, and going through the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	It is fitting that you should receive from these Terribles a great number, each of which corresponds to the quantity of thickness of bone, until the present one is entirely in your skull: whose extremities are acute in length and brevity, according to the quantity of thickness of its skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the form of the three Terribles, or trepanations.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	But the quality of drilling around the fractured bone is: as you place the Terribles on the bone and rotate your fingers, until you know that the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then exchange the Terribles for a different place, and put whatever quantity of thickness is around any hole or circle it.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut with the Incisors whatever is between any hole from the bone: and make it thinner than you can on it from the edge of lightness, as we have said, until you eradicate the bone, or your hand, or with some other instrument that you have prepared for it: such as tenacles, and fine pincers.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And it is necessary that you should take every precaution, so that the Terribles or any of the Incisors do not touch a sipha, or anything else.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When you have thus drilled around the bone and separated it from a sipha, if it should be continuous with it, and you extract it, then you must file it, and make the same end of it as remains in the bone with some other similar instrument of the Incisors.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	However, it is necessary that it should be thin and thinner with the other Incisors.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	That if there remains a little of the bones left, and it is difficult: then take them with ease, with whatever is near you from instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then care for the knots after that with oil, and the ointment which we have said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And another way of operation is simple, quite far from fear: which Galen said, and praised it much: and this is the words of his.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	It is necessary that you first, when you begin to handle the bone part from the place where the fracture is greater and more evident: until such time as you have handled it and placed under it this lens-shaped incisor, whose form this is.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the lens-shaped part, does not affect anything at all: and the sharp part of it moving on both sides of it from lengthwise, as you see: so that the lens-shaped part is placed on a chisel, the face of it striking sharply into the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike on the incisor from one side with a small mallet until you hit the whole bone with ease, as it turns over: and you will be safe from panic, for there is no danger of anything happening to it, which you truly fear.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the healer was not a fool among men, and rather ignorant of it, and not asleep, then if there remained anything attached to the bone from the pannicle in some places, he would hit it himself with the extreme end of the lens-shaped incisor, and set it free from it with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	For it is freed from it without harm, and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the bone fracture does not penetrate as far as the pannicle, and that which is cut off from the bone is the face of it, and there remain in it roughness and subtle knots: then you should remove this roughness and pluck out these knots with fine rasps, so that it is possible for you to administer them at all times more convenient for them, and straighter for them, according to which the surgery leads you, and that broken bone, and its form.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And you should administer in your ration, at first the root of the bone, with a wider rasp of these rasps.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use after it a finer edge of the blade.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And you should not stop doing that according to continuity, until you reach the point of administering them thinner, and finer of all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	In every other case of remaining lung cracks and thin fractures, you should give treatment according to that which leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And this is a thing that is not hidden above all, to which in this art any study is useful, and stands on that which we have written and shown in the case of large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	But if a patch has been placed and retains the wound: then you should take a piece of linen cloth, according to the quantity of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the wound's opening.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another piece of cloth, doubled or tripled, immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it over the first cloth: and make it so that you can do this more easily than the other, so that it does not chafe.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then apply a broad bandage over it: and do not tighten it, unless by the amount that holds the wound only: and leave it with this treatment for one day or two, until you are secure from fever.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then dissolve it, and administer after it the medicines with which there is no need of dryness: such as lilies' roots, herb flour, thorn powder, and similar things: and it is, that you make a powder of these medicines, which you sprinkle over the wound like those which are dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And administer universally in it all medicine of its property, which is to cleanse and not to bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And take care, according to your skill, that the wound in your cure is clear: and is not in it an ointment, nor any sort of dirtiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	And do not leave any wart aggregating therein at all: because when a wart aggregates over the haircloth of the skull, it corrupts it, and makes it putrefied, and brings about great evil after that: and this has already happened to the scalp's skin, when it is washed away from it, especially if its care is neglected, and there is blackness on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Therefore, consider then, if happen accidents to the sick which we have said, know that is certainly dangerous.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if the blackness does not happen, unless by medicine which is put on himself, and it is in the virtue of its medicine, to make him black: then you should take from honey a part, from oil rose three parts, and with them linen cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then put the patient on a bed: then care for the patient with the species of cure which are appropriate, until he is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	Of restoration of the nose when it is broken.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that they do not break from the nose unless both parts of it are at the same time, or one of them: since it has two bones: for the lower part is cartilaginous, does not break, and does not happen to him except by wearisome, and twist, and roughness.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If it breaks one of the two parts of it, then you should introduce your little finger in the nasal opening, and align the fracture with your little finger and thumb, until the nose returns to its natural shape: and do this with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And be careful, so that does not happen by your operation on him a pain on the sick.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	That if the fracture is in the upper part of the nose, and does not reach to that finger: then you should adjust the end of the rib, where is a small thickness.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If, however, the fracture is in both parts, then you should make it similar to him: and attend to his restoration on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after seven or ten days at rest from the heat.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then introduce into the end of the nose a piece of linen cloth if the fracture is in one part: or introduce two pieces of linen cloth if the fracture is in both parts: and let it be in the piece of linen thickness such a quantity, which fills the nasal opening.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And certain restorers of antiquity said, let licinia be infused with butter, and be exchanged every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	That is not true to me, but it seems necessary that licinia be infused with alum, however, when combined with the powder to be ground.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then remove the licinia, until the bone is hardened and the cartilage is strengthened.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And when a feather of a goose is introduced into the nose instead of licinia, after it has been wrapped with a soft cloth: and so it is, that it holds the fracture of the nose more firmly together, and prevents the sick from breathing in.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you want, do that: and if you want, do licinia.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	That if the nose should be again injured while you are working, apply an cold poultice to the nose, or one made with a herb called hyssop, or with a little oil of rosemary, or with a little dandelion.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	But if the cold poultice does not work, then it is necessary that the nose itself be wrapped with a sisam flour paste, and with thuris powder mixed with alum.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then put a soft cloth over the nose, and do not bind it with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	But if the nose bones are broken or crushed, then it is necessary that you split them open, and remove the bone with the appropriate instruments.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then cut away the flesh, and take care of the nose when it is infected, and hardened with the plasters suitable for it, or with a ointment.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	That if a nail is stuck between the nose, then it is necessary that you care for the nose with licinia: and administer a brass tube until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	Of the restoration of the lower jaw, when it is broken.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is broken, and not with a nail: examine then if it is only a fracture of the side, and not a break in two, and take care of the internal parts: then it is easy to know it.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	If there is a fracture on the right side of his nose, then you should insert your left index finger into the hole: likewise, if there is a fracture in the left jaw, then insert your right index finger: and push it in with ease to the outside with your other hand from the inside of the bone, and align it in place.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the fracture of the jaw has already separated into two parts, then you should manage to pull apart the two sides, according to the straightness: until it is possible to align it.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If an injury has already occurred to the teeth, or a dislocation or fracture: then you should tighten them together with a gold wire, or silver, or silk thread.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place the poultice over the fractured jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then place a doubled cloth over it, and an uneven-sized wooden splint: or a fragment of skin, the same length as the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind it from above, according to how you have prepared the ligature for yourself, and allow the application to remain in place until it is destroyed: and instruct the patient to use tranquillity and calmness: and provide him with soft food to eat.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If you think that something has already changed in the shape by some amount: then approach it, and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then straighten out what has been moved from it, and cover the jaw with a powder that is ground, mixed with chalk or flour, after you have removed the poultice: and place a thin woollen cloth over it.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While that adhesive poultice remains attached to the jaw and its position of the bone does not change, let it be: and do not remove it, until healing is complete: or tighten the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	This fracture is often tightened with three seven-day periods.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If a cold sore occurs while the adhesive is still in place, then administer to it what we have said many times in its treatment, until it disappears.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	If there is a fracture with the ulna, consider.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	I have already separated the fragment from the bone, or with a saw: then I made it very small, so that you can remove the fragments of sawing together with him when you want to remove them from the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If in fact the opening of the wound is tight, then I increase it with the phlebotomist according to the quantity that you need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you remove these saws and there is nothing left of them, then close the opening of the wound if it is wide: and if not, put over it from the placards that fit on it, and let it heal up until it is well.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	The restoration of the fork when it breaks.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	Many things are broken from the front part of the shoulder, and the break in the fork is made according to one of three ways.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or if it breaks and separates into two, except that they happen in the sawing: and it is easier to restore it.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or thus, so that they happen in the bone sawing: and it is more difficult to restore.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or thus, so that there is a fracture with the ulna.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And the operation in it when the fracture is without the ulna, is, so that you make the two ministers present, so that one of them holds a support to follow the broken fork, and the other extends the neck towards the side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then you make the fracture of your fingers equal, until it takes on shape according to what is needed: and it does not stand out in it, nor is it convex.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	That if you can bear to extend more, then it should be so that you put under a ball from a cloth or wool: and let the size of it be according to the quantity that you need: and extend it, and smooth out the fork, and crimp the ball with your hand, until the fracture is equal, according to what is needed.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you cannot bring the end of the Furcula to the outside because it goes deep inside: then let the sick person lie down on their chest and place the middle part of a feather under their shoulder blade; and press the shoulder of the sick person towards the lower part, until the bone of the Furcula that is in the depth comes up to the top: and then set the broken bone straight with your fingers and make it equal.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If you feel a creak in the Furcula and it moves: then you should find something to put on top of it and take out the creak with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If it is stuck in the bone, then take one of the incisorium instruments that you prepared for it and place it under the Furcula after you have placed a lever on top of it to lift it up; and this instrument should be made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It is joined to the ear which is not hollowed out.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	And its width should be according to the position of your shoulder and its size.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	The length, however, should also be according to what is possible for you to operate.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And it has two ends, as you see: and one end should be wide, and the other tight.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If the wound you made while extracting the bone's creak is wide and dries quickly with warm air: then join the two edges of the wound together with a stitch.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the break is small or you do not have warm air to dry it: then fill the wound with rags and powder according to the amount of the wound's length.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If warm air comes, then pour a mixture of rose oil and vinegar and wine on it and place it on top.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	The rigor of the bone is what it is like when there is no wound and no break, that is, when you place a paste made from pounded flour with ash on top of the bone.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And set a stump of wood upon it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a ball under its toe, if you can tolerate it.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take the blood, that is, the bag which the Saracens hold, which is long and very thin: and let its breadth be that of a palm or about it.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a double layer of cloth on top of the stump and a pad.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take an Astrolabium from a thin board, whose breadth is that of three fingers, and whose length is similar.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in a cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then wrap the cloth with the Astrolabium in the place of alchemy which lies over the fracture and the spot.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the alchemy over the fracture like a turban, and wrap it over his neck, and under his healthy toe, and under his unhealthy toe: and reduce it on all sides, and see how the constriction holds the fracture fast: and this is that it does not cover you above, and in whole, so that it does not move the Astrolabium from above the broken nose.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And for this it is necessary, that you should see the sick one every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever therefore the ligature softens, and you see the Astrolabium start to move: then straighten it, and tighten the ligature.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place a pillow of medicine behind his back, and under his healthy toe next to his pillow in the night, so that it aids him from its side when he turns.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Thus is broken the fracture of the forearm by elevation of the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Or bind his arm to his neck: and do not loosen the ligature, if it does not happen to dislodge by itching, or from a change of position, until twelve days have passed.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then mend the pad, if you see his face towards that.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And add to the constriction, and let him go, until it is restored and has clotted.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	The fracture of the femur is also pulled and strengthened after a few days: and sometimes it happens in some people with less strength.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	On the restoration of the fracture of the spit.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	Rarely does the spatula break, and in its width place; and do not break from it except its edge.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	But when it breaks from it place, and breaks in the middle of it, and is not known that except by touch: then according to what is the shape of the fracture prepare the preparation.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And reduce it to the natural form at all your skill, which is possible for you.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then put on place powder of grinding with alum, and a stopple of wood, and put above pulse from a doubled cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then put on top of it a thin plate of metal from a thin board according to the quantity of the spatula of all, or larger than that a little.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	But if the bottom is crushed under the plate in some place of the spatula, then make it equal with the stopple of wood, until the plate falls down according to the equality.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then wipe above with long-haired alkimium, with a pressure of it, and a firmness of the plate, until it does not move away from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	And consider the ligature every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Whenever that is softened the ligature, tighten it, and make the plate equal if it moves away from its place: and lie on the injured side on his healthy.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	And the spatula is restored in twenty days, or in twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	But when this number is completed, then dissolve the ligature: and you are in safety.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For that itself is from bones whose community is not feared, and their solution.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	But if it proceeds from an ossicle, and stings under the skin: then cut above on it, and take it off.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	And do as we have said in the fracture of the fork from the seat of the pus, if anything happens from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	About restoring the fracture of the breastbone.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	The breastbone sometimes breaks in the middle, and this rarely happens.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	The extremities of it are most often broken, and they are destroyed by accidents of it.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	When it is broken in the middle, which turns downward toward the lower part, a severe pain takes place, and difficulty in breathing, and perhaps a cough, and he may spit blood, and there seems to be a fracture of the bone, and this is not hidden from feeling, The restoration of it is so that he shall lie down on his back: and let him put under his armpits.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	Then he shall press his shoulders and bring the ribs together from both sides or from the sides with his hands: and gently adjust him in alignment, according to all possible ways that it may be fitting, until he has restored the shape of the bone, as it should be.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	Then he shall place over him plaster and a board, and put beneath him from the table a light one, made of willow or of holly, and of similar things in a state of lightness, after you have dried it up with cloth.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	Then gently fasten him with a bandage over the broken bone so that it does not move: and sometimes he shall walk with a limp, going with a tight grip when turning.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	Then consider the bandage at every hour, and whenever it becomes soft, tighten it: and if need should prompt its loosening in order to cure an itch, or a rash which has occurred at that place, or pain, or pus: then go through with it, and loose it, and remove the plaster, and set right what has happened in the course of its treatment.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	Then reduce the plaster, if you see toward it: and put on a tight grip, until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	Regarding the restoration of the ribs, when they are broken.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	Know that the fracture of ribs does not occur unless in the places near the back and from the extremities thereof from the anterior part.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	And it does not happen to them any attrition, except therefore, because they are cartilage-like.
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	And the knowledge of this is not hidden from the sense in inquiry when the fingers are probed.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	And the restoration of it is made so that the equal fracture with the fingers in a possible second way, until it is equal in figure, according to which is necessary.
