Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	Then apply an overlay, and tightly fix the broken bone with the splint, if it needs it.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	And if the fracture of the ribs is hidden to the interior: then it happens to the sick a sharp pain, and a puncturing, like that which happens to him who has pleurisy: for the bone pricks the wound, and also it happens to him that a difficulty in breathing, and coughing, and blood-letting: and this is difficult to cure.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	And already the ancients have devised in it with many contrivances: and among them are those who say, Let you place food that generate an inflammation and a ventosity, so that it inflames the belly, and extends, and pushes the fracture towards the exterior.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	But we really despise, so that there is no cause of haste in making an emetic that is hot, if it does not happen.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	But if it has already happened, then add this to it.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	And said some of them: Let it be placed on a ventous place, and then suck with strength, and it is similar to reasoning.
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	However, it is feared that the ventosity attracts suppurations to the place, because of the weakness of disposition.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.	And said some of them: It is necessary so that the place is covered with wool which has already been immersed in hot oil: and let there be placed down feathers between the ribs, until it is filled up: so that the ligature is equal when it is probed, according to its roundness.
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	The sick person shall be nursed with food and medicine until he has recovered from the pleurisy.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.	If the sick person is being pressed by pain, and if his nose itches or pricks, and we are afraid for the sick man: then we should split him on the spot and detect any broken rib.
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	Then let us place over it an instrument that keeps it open, of which the memory precedes: and we will easily cut the bone, and we will cut it itself.
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	Then let us gather two skin flaps of the wound, if it is large with a stitch: and let us heal him with plasters until he heals.
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	If it happens during the time of a feverish swelling, then let it approach, and pour flour into rose oil and place it on the spot: and let the sick person be nursed with it as is appropriate for the swelling.
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	In the meantime he shall also lie down on his side where he sleeps until he heals.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	For the restoration of a broken spine of the back and neck.
Caput X.	Chapter X
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	Of the bones of the neck when a fracture occurs, and it rarely happens that they are worn out: and likewise to the spines of the back.
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	But when this happens to someone and you want to know whether it will heal or not: then trust in the Lord.
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	For if you see his hands already softened, and stuporified, and dead: and he cannot be moved or extended or tightened, and when you tighten them with your fingers and prick them with a pin, he does not feel it, and does not feel pain in them: then know that he is not healing, and there are many dispositions that are fatal.
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	But if he feels it when you tighten them and prick them: then know that the neck bones are healed, and that the sick person will heal with treatment.
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If something similar happens to his back spine, and you want to know whether it will heal or not: then look at his feet: if you see that they are softened, and the same thing happens to them as happened to his hands: then when he lies on his back, he moves and has a desire to go to the toilet, and when he leans on his stomach, he wants to urinate, but cannot: then know that it is fatal.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	Therefore, do not interrupt his work.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	If, however, nothing of this happens to him, the matter is lighter.
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	And the cure of him that happens from this is, as you seek to calm inflammation of the hot sweat: so that you put on oil of rose alone: or when you wash with water alone.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	Place over it now and then in the day, until he is calmed down with a hot sweat: then place on one spot from healing plasters, drying up, and tightly binding to him with the bandage: and order the sick person to use rest and tranquility.
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	And let him not sleep over the part that hurts when he feels pain, until he is healed.
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	That if it happens at the separation of a bone's splint, or something that has already been separated from it: then you must, as it separates on the skin, and remove it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound, if it is large, with a stitch.
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the person with some meat that has grown on him, from ointment, until he is healed.
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	But if, at the end, the hip bone is broken and has come off, and the tail is cut off: then you must, with your left hand, put your thumb into the hole in the hip, and, with your right hand, push it back together as well as possible, and second, by equating it.
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then place over him, and take him away: and take care of the wound with the cure that preceded it, until he is healed.
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	The Restoration of Ankles.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	Bones of the ankles are rarely broken.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	If they are broken, then their fracture is not, unless it is split at the ends of the bones: and they break lengthwise, and bend inward towards the inside: and happens to the person pain in the place, and a bruise: and the leg breaks that is broken.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	And the restoration of it is, as you stretch your hand over it, until you stand over the fracture like this figure:
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	If the fracture is in the extremities of it only, then make that fracture equal, according to how you are prepared from equality, until its figure becomes similar to its natural one.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	If, however, the fracture is in its length or already declines towards its insides: then make the sick person lie on his/her stomach, until his/her fracture is prepared for restoration.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	When, therefore, you have made that equal, put over it a plaster: then put over it an wooden or skin splint: and tightly tighten the straitening over which you do not fear the displacement of the fracture, nor the removal of the splint.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	And when those equalities have come together with it so that it fills it, until it receives that stricture according to the equality: and order the sick person to sleep on his/her back or on his/her healthy side.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	If, however, there occurs to him a hot swelling: then cease from extending it, and from its restoration, until the hot swelling subsides: and put over him what sits, according to what has preceded, then return to its restoration: and tightly bind him as is necessary.
Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	If, however, it has happened that the bone is stuck or broken, extract it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	The assistant for the restoration of a fracture
Caput XII.	Chapter XII:
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	The aid is that which is between the bed and the head of the spoon.
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	If it is then broken, its restoration is according to two ways.
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	The one is that you take a flat piece of wood of medium thickness, according to this form, which follows.
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	And bind together with two straps the two extremities.
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	Then hang it from a raised place: and let the sick person sit on a seat.
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	Then let him throw his broken arm over the wood, until it reaches to its touch-point, in which middle sits an annexed piece of wood.
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	Then hang from above the person some heavy thing, so that he extends his arm towards the lower one.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	Then let the physician break the bones in his hands at once, until the fracture has healed, as it is necessary.
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	And another mode is that he should lie on his back upon his breast, and hang his hand from his neck with a bandage.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	Then order two servants, that one of them should hold this which is above the fracture with his hands: and that the other should hold below him, and should stretch both of them on either side.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	And if you will that the extension be stronger, then bind beneath the fracture with a bandage, and above it with another bandage: and should stretch both of them on either side.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	If then the fracture is near the end of the arm, then it is necessary that there be placed one bandage under the joint, and another under the fracture toward the hip.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	And likewise if the fracture is near the hip: then it is necessary that there be placed a bandage on that place, and on the hip itself.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	Then break the fracture with ease without labor, until it is made equal when it has healed: and then apply the bandage well: then bind it if there does not occur a swelling warm.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	If then a swelling warm occurs: then let go of the binding until the seventh day.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	And place on him wool which is soaked in vinegar and oil of roses, until it has stopped the swelling: then bind it: and the mode of binding it is that you should place a plaster upon the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	Then place an innovation from new cloth upon the plaster.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	Then let the assistant take the arm and put it on the shoulder: and he shall put his hand open upon the shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	And place a cloth, and bind above the assistant's arm so that the arm stand in the place of the stars: if he does not forbid you to do anything, and does not change about you anything out of a broken bone.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	That if you should find that there changes about you anything out of a broken bone: then use stars: and it is that you should place upon the fracture a star which is wider and stronger than the other stars.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	Place the splint between all the fingers with a width that corresponds to the length of the fingers, and make it so that there are three fingers' lengths from one side to the other end of the fracture plus three more finger-lengths.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	Then tie tightly with a string over the splints as I described at the beginning of this chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	And it is so that your tension on the splints should be stricter than the place of fracture.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	And to the extent that the fracture lengthens, the tension should be lessened.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	If then you see that the splints are long and the tension is strong, as we have said, in the hour when you restore the limb to life, then do so: but if you wait for the swelling to go down, then remove the splints and the bandages until the seventh day, as we have said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	Then examine the ligaments in all three days so that there will not be a prickly feeling, or swelling, or prevention of food from reaching the limb, due to the tension on the swelling.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	So make it right again as we have said above.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	But if you are in doubt, so that there is no risk of anything from it: then do not remove the ligaments until after three days or longer.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	And lie on his back with his hands on his belly and put under his pillow a stuffed cushion made of wool.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	Consider this at all times, whether night or day, so that the broken limb does not move around and the ligaments do not become loose.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	So make it right again with your own power.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	And set before him food according to the order that we have described, so that there is light food at first, until the jaw begins to close: then it should become heavier.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	For the habit of helping and of the limbs is that it should be strict for forty days; then it should be loosened, and given a bath, and treated with ointment that makes it right.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	If the fracture has been broken, ground down: then do not remove the ligaments and splints until after fifty days and up to two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	On the restoration of fractures of the brachial bone.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII On the restoration of fractures of the brachial bone
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	The arm is made up of two bones called the humerus and ulna.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	One of these is small, and it is that which follows the thumb.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	The other is large, and it is that which is placed below the little finger on the lower part.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	Perhaps then, only one of the bones breaks, or both break at the same time.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	When therefore one of the bones breaks above, then is its restoration easy and its healing easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	And when one of the bones breaks below, it is a bad fracture, and its healing is difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	And it is worse when both bones break at the same time.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	If therefore the broken bone is the little humerus above, then it is fitting for the doctor to restore it with ease, that he extend the small one properly, until it is even with it.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	But if the broken bone is the big one: then let it be, that he restore it with a stronger bandage, tightly bound.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	And let him set the hand in its place, and its extension above the little finger.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	And let the thumb of the hand be set at a higher level than all the fingers; and let the articular inferior be set for all the fingers, or for some of them; and let it rest sitting on its haunches, and let the little finger face it, or directly in front of it, in height, so that it does not suffer from any trouble.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	Then let him extend the arm from its lower part, or with his hand, or with a bandage.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	And another one of them should extend it from above.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	Then let the doctor adjust the bone until he has set it in a better position than he can achieve.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	If there are any fractures that are out of place, then strive to restore all the bones to their places with your skill.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	But if it seems to you that there is a fracture of the bone and it stings the skin, and there is no hope of restoring it: then remove it according to the manner which we have spoken of in those which precede.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	If, however, there is a fracture with the radius, I have already done so to that singular chapter, therefore take care of it from that side.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	If, however, in the beginning of your restoration there is a warm swelling, then take a thin cloth made of linen, blue in color, and place it between the thickness and thinness: and tightly bind the cloth to the stricture with care, until the swelling sits down: then stir up the liniments, and put on an emulsion prepared from fine flour ground with albumin.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	Then put on the splints, and let the splint that is placed on the fracture be a little wider and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	And know that the number of splints for the arm is six in various dispositions: whether the fracture is in one shaft or in two shafts at once.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then place your splint on the location of the fracture, stronger and more robust, and somewhat more with the splint towards the upper fracture, or towards the lower part: or place a softer splint on the splint, according to what preceded the memory of it at the beginning of the chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	And let there be cloths wrapping around the fracture, soft cloths, moist: and let them not be hard, rough.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	And let there be a thread that is tied with linen itself, between thinness and thickness, as we have said.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	And consider the member and the ligaments after some days.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	If anything that requires correction happens, such as a rash that occurs in the member: then one should soak the member with hot water, until that itch subsides, and remove the member not constricted, until it subsides, and then repeat the splint.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	If the stricture has already been softened, and the bone has already receded, and similar things: then repair it completely with your skill, and consider again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	For if nourishment is prevented from reaching the member, because of too much stricture: then one should make it a little softer, and remove it for a few days, until it heals up, and then bind it tightly.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	But if some of those things we said do not happen to the sick person in question, then it is not necessary that he be cured unless after twenty days or so.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	Then his hand that was injured should be suspended from his neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	And his neck should be made level and guarded with strength against movements.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	And let him sleep on his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	And know that this fracture is restored in twenty days, or in thirty-two; and perhaps it will be restored in thirty days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	All of this depends on the condition of the skin and the strength of the body.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	Of the restoration of broken hands.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XXII.
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	You should know that it is rare for a fracture to occur in the knuckles and joints of the fingers.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	And it does not happen to him unless there is repeated rubbing.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	When, therefore, the fracture has occurred or the bruising, then the sick person should sit on a level seat; and before him should be placed a second seat at equal distance.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	Then place his hand on that, extended.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	Then the surgeon should make the bones that are broken join together with good union.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	Then he should put on a poultice and a bandage, if there does not occur a hot swelling.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	Then place the splint from above, according to the quantity of space on the skin; and you have already bound it with linen thread.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	If the fracture is below the knee, then make a sort of ball out of linen cloth; and direct the sick person to put it on with his injured leg: then tie it tightly with long linen thread.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	And let him sit on a splint made of linseed, so that it is soft, in order to apply the linseed to the body with the injury: and tie it tightly, according as it is needed.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	If the fracture is on the outside, then you should place a splint from above and another one from below the injury; and let the hand be held open and straight.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	Then put on the splint, as the hand turns, and extend between the fingers with the ligament.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	If a bone of any finger is fractured, then if it is the thumb, it should be made equal according to what is necessary.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	Then tie it with the sole of the foot: and if you wish, put a straight stick under it so that it may not move, in order that the fracture may heal without moving.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	If the fracture is in any of the remaining fingers, such as the middle, index, or ring finger, then it should be made equal and tied to the healthy finger that follows it: or all of them should be tied together according to their length, and this is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	Or put a stick on top of it, as we have said for the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	And consider this in your restoration, and after that arrangement of the splints, warm them with hot water: and oppose to it whatever is necessary, when anything happens from it, according to what he tells us.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	On the Restoration of a Fracture of the Hip
Caput XV.	CHAPTER XV.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	The hip bone often breaks and is felt: because it turns toward the inner and back parts.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	And its restoration is such that one ligature is tied above the fracture, and another ligature is tied below the fracture.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	And the sick person extends his hand on his face.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	Then he should extend all the ligaments for their sides according to equality: and this is done when the fracture is in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	If the fracture is near the root of the hip bone, then one ligature should be on the side of the pelvis so that it hangs down to the top: and another ligature should be below the fracture.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	And in the same way, if the fracture is near the knee joint, then one ligature should be near the knee joint so that it hangs down to the bottom: and another ligature should be below the fracture.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	Then the doctor should make the two hands equal to each other until he has reduced them according to their natural form: and the bones should be joined by a good joint.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	Then it is necessary that you put on plaster and tighten it, if a member does not happen to have an aposteme.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	That if it should happen to have an aposteme: then let him dismiss himself for a few days, until the heat has seized it, and then return to your cure.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	But tighten it so that it is like this.
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	It is necessary that you wrap him up tightly on the fracture, that is to say, tie him: and leave twice as much of it, or three times: and let remain from it what is superfluous.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	Then wrap the leg, until the foot has grown back at the root.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	And introduce a long thread between the pelvis and the leg near the knee towards the bottom, and make the ends of the thread come from the upper part of the two members.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	Then tighten the leg and the pelvis so that what is superfluous comes out of the loop.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	Then put on top of the pelvis in the place of the fracture the stars, and put from them one star on the bone of the leg.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	Then fill with dry leaves between the leg and the pelvis with soft leaves so that the tension is even.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	Then begin with the strong tension from the middle on three twists, or four.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	And the more you lengthen it with a rope from the place of the fracture, your tension will be smaller and softer, and gentler.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	Then turn to both ends of the thread that you introduced between the pelvis and the leg.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	Tie it with the three stars that are above.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	Then turn the two ends of the thread towards the bottom, until you reach the toe of the foot.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	And tie both ends of the thread as well as the ends of the stars from the other side: so that the ligament does not move from its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	Then dismiss the tension on it while it remains like that so that there does not happen to a member corrosion, or an apostema, or an inflation, and similar things to it.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	That if anything should happen from it.
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	Therefore, with respect to his solution, and adjust that which happened from there completely, as we have said many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	But if a fragment of bone pricks the bone: then it is necessary, like that, if you can, to smooth out.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	And if not, find on top of it, and move it: and take care with that which preceded it, until it heals.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	And when this fracture is contracted in the hips, besides adding stars to it, as we have said in the leg and arm.
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	However, in restoring it so that the broken one does not cause a limp.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	And if restored alone, besides being applied to the other leg, then it is necessary that he who has it limps always.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	And you should know that the hip is contracted in fifty days, or added a little, or shortened a little: all this is according to the diversity of complexions, and the remains of dispositions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	Regarding the restoration of the fracture of the knuckle of the knee joint.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	You should know that the knuckle of the knee is rarely fractured, but it often occurs through wear and tear.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	But if it has occurred to him a fracture, then there is no doubt that it is either a crack or a hole in its parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	And it is like the wound and without the wound.
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	And he stands above all that with respect to sense.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	And the restoration of it is so that it equalizes what has been broken from its parts with the fingers, until it coheres, and joins together according to what is possible from adjustment and convenience, and manufacture.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	Then put a plaster of rice flour, or flour that has been crushed and mixed with albumen: and put over it a round star, if you can bear it: and tightly tighten the upper part to it with respect to that.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	Then consider all the dispositions that we have described in the remaining fractures: such as blisters, heat, and their like: so that you oppose any accident to it when it coheres with it, until it heals.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	Of restoring broken bones of the leg.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	Know that there are two bones of the leg, one is thick and called the leg bone; and the other is fine and called the fibula.
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	And it happens to both species of fracture that occurs in the two bones of the arm: and for this one is made the restoration thereof as is the restoration of the arm equally, and the operation is one.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	That if both bones break at the same time, the leg becomes bent in all parts.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	And if only the fine bone breaks, then the leg bends forward.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	And if only the thick bone is broken, it twists downward: and that is of those which do not hide from you.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	Then administer the extension, and the equalization, and the binding of the joints by means of bandages equally.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	However, if the fracture of the leg is a bad fracture, it has many complications: so that there be less extension, and milder alleviation to thee.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	And in the leg itself is some operation on the arm; and it is, as when you make the joints equal, and do all your work, then take two strips of pine wood, which are employed in the making of splints which are laid under tables: and they are made from the palm leaves: and choose out of them those that have a little thickness, and there be none of the small ones: and make the length thereof according to the length of the leg from the knee down below.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	Then wrap up on a single cloth of two folds, making an overlap on each side according to its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	And place one end of the leg from one side, and the other end from the other side: and let them be from the knee down to the foot.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	Then bind the two strips on three sides from the two ends and the middle.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	Since when tightness is forbidden, the leg leans to the right and to the left, and remains in good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	And also let a wooden splint be made according to the length of the leg, and let it be placed therein so that it may preserve itself from motion.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	Indeed, it is very important that you make that when the fracture is a proper fracture.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	Then consider the leg every day, and with great care try to prevent it from becoming infected, or inflated, or otherwise.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	If then any of these things happen, then oppose it with him as much as is necessary, until he recovers his health, if God wills.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	Regarding the fracture of the bones of the foot and toes:
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII:
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	The heel bone does not have a deep fracture.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	However, when the fracture of the bones of the foot does occur, and when the toes also have a small fracture, it only occurs in many cases of abrasion.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	If a fracture occurs in the bones of the foot and you see those bones slip over one another from side to side, then place the injured foot on the ground as if walking.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	Then stand still, and place your foot on that which will elevate the bones: then press or trample it, and make it equal by applying pressure until they are all back in their places.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	Then place a plaster on top of it, and put a board underneath: and place under the foot a thin panel with two flat ends.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	Then tighten it with a tight bandage when you have wrapped it and left it alone.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	When then after three or four days, then loosen the bandages.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	For you will find that the bones are even, or if any of them are fractured or displaced.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	The operation then is as follows: as you see it.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	If any of the toes are fractured, then restore them, and make them equal according to what you have told me about the restoration of toe bones.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	Then place your finger with a wooden splint according to the length of your finger, and make it about as wide: then place under the foot the same panel that you have told me about, and tighten it tightly when you walk.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	If it is broken from the bones, then two, or three, or more, then put a star on top of all the fingers of its size, rolled up in a cloth: and tighten the table in the lower foot; and stand over one head of the table outside the vent of the foot, so that he holds by good retention.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	And it is fitting that you do not forget, but you consider all that I have said to you in the remaining fractures from the accidents which we have spoken of: and oppose all accident with him that it is necessary.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	On the fracture of the woman's femur, and of the spine, and of the man's pelvis.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX: On the fracture of the femur in women
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	When the femur is broken in a woman, then make her sit square.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	Then lean her back slightly, and hold her by the rear.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	Then fill the woman' with the hand of the obstorger, until she is filled: and let her be in the female part like a sphere.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	Then shake the woman, and raise her back slowly.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	For that hand moves, until it is before the door of the woman like a sphere, and the broken jaw returns.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	Then put a little ball on her back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	When, therefore, she wants to urinate, the hand moves with ease, and then urinates: and reduces it according to the way that you put it in at first: and then turns back to her little ball.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	Let it do this for seven days, or about, for the jaw is restored: for it is not recovered by that time, let it be mended with a needle.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	And if you want to, take an awl, and tighten it on the hole of a twig, and insert the whole awl into the woman'
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	Then blow into the twig with force, until it bends the awl inside the woman: for the fracture returns.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	Then fill it with the hand of the obstorger, and let it stand for a few days, according to what we have said, until it is healed.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	And when the os Pectini [i.e., the pelvis] of a man or woman is broken, then administer to it restoration and that which we have said concerning the os Anchae [i.e., the hip bone].
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	And let not the rectum be hidden in those who are broken close to it, for these are few, especially if there is some study or use.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	And understand my book well, for the fracture itself signifies to you many things concerning the straightening of its own restoration and the narrowing of its own [bone's] self: therefore understand.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	But when the os Pectinis [i.e., the pelvis] of a man is broken, take the throat of an goose; and insert the penis into it.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	Then put a bandage over it, and wrap it up, and leave it for three days or so, and let it heal, if God wills.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	As for the restoration of broken bones, when they are with a wound.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	It belongs to him who has suffered a fracture with a wound, especially if it is large, such as the os coxae or supporting bones, or similar to it, as you see fit, and stop bleeding immediately: if you have evidence of bleeding, as we have said above.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	If the wound spurts blood, then you should cut it off, as you would grind up powder on top of it: if there is not present to you anything else.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	Then begin to restore the fracture on that very day: and do not put off doing so, unless there is a swelling.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	But if a swelling becomes hot, then dismiss the restoration of it until the ninth day, until the swelling subsides.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	And do not approach it on the third or fourth day at all, for you would bring upon it bad accidents.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	But if the broken bone is prominent above the skin detected: then you should seek to reduce it and make it level with your own hands with ease and a small extension.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	If, however, the extension is not prepared and his own skin is equal to your hands: then reduce him with this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And this instrument is made of iron, whose length is the quantity of seven fingers, or eight; and its width is according to the amount of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	And for this it is necessary for the doctor to take three, or four according to the amount that he needs for healing any kind of fracture.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	And it should be round: and it should have a small thickness so that it does not double up on itself when pressed against the body during surgery: and its sharp ends should have a margin on their edges.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	And let it be above his thickness from one half of it to the bottom.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	It is necessary in this operation, that the sharp end of it be placed on the edge of the prominent bone: and push it with a single force until the bone is reduced and reaches a certain equilibrium.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	So consider to equalize the ends of the fracture in opposite directions.
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	If its ends are thin and do not accept the instrument well, then you should strike against one of its ends until the instrument has strength.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	But if you cannot reduce them with the above mentioned instrument at all, then strike against it with a chisel that we have mentioned: or saw it with one of any kind of saw that is possible for you to get hold of.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then smooth out what remains in the bone from roughness and small bark.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	When therefore the bone is reduced and finds a painful, annoying pain after its reduction, then you should know that the bone has not returned to its own place.
Fac ergo illud.	So do this.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	For you will have a great impediment of infirmity, when your restoration is complete that bone which you have healed.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then dip the cloth in black vinegar.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	If it is summer.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not place the wound on a bone, nor put anything to sit with the oil: so that it does not cause rot and decay in itself.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then apply the poultice at the time of your meal from the healing of the bone.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And remove the wound bandage: so that you will not fall with the forceps into the second hole of the wound according to the quantity of the wound.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And take all caution, do not tie the wound when it is broken.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	For many times have done this ignorant doctors: and they caused to happen on their sick or death, or corruption, or decay, that is, harm.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And your bandage be soft, gentle, varied of the bandages of broken bones.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	That if the wound is bad, or is a large wound, and you are waiting for some bad accident that we have described, and hanging pain in the place: then it is not appropriate that you put the poultice on.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	And make them incisions of dry cloth in the place of the poultice, and tie it up with them.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	When, however, it is after one day, or two days, and you see the wound begin to come into pus, that it generates in it: then take off from above the wound the cloth that you put on with wine.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then apply vinegar, and oils with which we usually treat wounds: such as the four-part oil, and similar to it.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	And it will be good for you, so that you loosen the ligature.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And consider the wound every day morning and evening, until it has hardened, and healed.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	And it is necessary that the limb be prepared so, that pus that comes out of it goes down with ease.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	That if the days that are passing over wounds, and it does not harden, nor does the pus come out of it: then you know that there are small bones in it.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	Why it is necessary to inquire about the fracture with the trial.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	How many of those false joints are separated, remove them, and pull out themselves.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And which of those false joints are not separated, and prick the limb, and cause pain to it, seek to injure it, and remove it in any way possible for you that thing.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	That if it happens to a wound to burst, or to open, that is, to suppurate, or some other species of corruption and putrefaction: then it is necessary that you oppose each of them with what is appropriate to him from the cure, whose preceded description in his own chapter.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And from that in which it is necessary that my speech should stand, and to which you make present mind when a bone is broken, and protrudes over the limb, such as the hip bone, and auxiliary, and similar to those of the large limbs, it is, that you do not suspect attraction of it, for many times from that happens death, indeed, leave it until it putrefies.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	Perhaps, however, it falls by itself after twenty days, or thirty.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then, therefore, cure the fracture, if it is with you: and otherwise, leave it.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	On the Cure of Fractures in the Neck.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	This Nerve Treatment has often happened in the neck for the cure of a fracture.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Especially, that which is near to joints: and it is nourished from that figure of the limb.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And perhaps it prevents the limb from its natural function.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Consider, therefore, if that nerve is young: administer to it medicines which have a constricting action, such as aloe, and olive oil, and myrrh, and oak bark, and acacia, and similar ones.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	So, taking some of these certain things, or all of them: and bind them with a bitter wine, or with an egg white, or with vinegar: and place them on the nerve in a poultice, and tightly bind them with a good constriction.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	And free him from prison, and do not separate him from his wife on many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Then free her, and take another, until the nausea is gone.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or put a lead weight on her chest uneasily.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	Lead is a property that removes whatever is feared from the body.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the nausea is already well-established and firm, and urgently needs to be removed: then find on its upper part, and strike with a sharp instrument: or cut it off with something like a razor, until it stops: and take care of her, until she recovers.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	The cure, when it is restored, and there remains a member after that in a subtle way, not in accordance with its nature.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When the bone fracture is restored, and there remains a member after that in a subtle and weak way: then it is not done except for many reasons.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	Of which one is that many solutions of the ligament and its ligation are not done according to what should be: or because of the excess of the tightness of the ligaments, until it is prevented from running into the member: or because of the multitude of emollients in the non-time of their hour: or because of the scarcity of blood in the body, and its weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	And the cure for it is to feed the sick and make the body relaxed, until the blood increases in it.
Et administra balneum.	And apply the bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And introduce joy and happiness to him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then put a piece on the member: to draw the piece towards it so that it receives a lot of food.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And apply his emollients to him with warm water, until he runs the food, and returns to his natural shape.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	The cure for broken bones when they are restored when they are twisted.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.De curando fractis supero, et
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When the cure for a fracture that has been restored after its healing, and the prominence of the broken bone or nausea: and feed it in the form of the member, however, the member is not prevented from its natural function: then you should not listen to what he imagines, that the member should be broken again.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	There were also many stupid doctors and healers who did this on our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	And indeed this operation is very terrible, leading to death or a great fear, as if it were mortal.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the lameness and numbness are recent: then it should be dressed with warm water in which have been boiled softening herbs, such as the leaves of althaea, and its root, and mallow, and similar things.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And let there be made to him a plaster with a softening plaster, like that of dandelion roots ground up in water.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Or let the root of althaea be cooked in mucus and stirred with chicken fat or oil of sesame: and let it be applied with it.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Or let fig leaves be taken, and dried with colubrain clay, and similar things that are called by the name of medicines which diminish congestion.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	And when the numbness has resolved with persistent friction, old, and soft, which is made with wet hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	And let movement of the member be administered to all parts at all times.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	But if the crookedness has already come before, and it is strong, and has gone into a stone, and there is a need to treat it with an iron: then let it be cut off above the bone, and the continuity of the bone be made to heal, and what is superfluous from the numbness or the bone with fine incisions: and let ease be given to it with care and diligence.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	On the subject of dislocation
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the departure of someone who is joined from their place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Why it is prevented from its own movement, and is supported in its figure.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And does cause to happen on the painful pains, and severe injuries.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	But when it happens that a dislocation has happened to someone, then let him hurry to have it restored: and do not delay it at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	If it should delay, the place should be opened and the dislocation reduced with force.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore, so that it may not make a noise, nor should it be extended at the time of opening it.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	Since it often causes a spasm, and hurts with its pain.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	True, when that happens, then you should, in case of the wound, care to drain off the blood.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then let it be discharged, until it has rested the opening.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the member should be massaged with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then reduce it with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And care for all members, so that the member may recover to its own place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I have already arranged the chapters of dislocation, also according to that which preceded in fracture, from the upper part of the body to the lower part of it.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	§ Of the care of dislocation of the Mandible inferior.
Caput XXV.	Head
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	The two Mandibles are slightly dislocated unless it is rare.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the dislocation of the jaw is made according to one of two ways.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or else they move away from their places with a small removal, and become slightly softer.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated with a whole, complete dislocation, until they become softer towards the breast, so that a salve drains out, and it cannot hold fast, nor can it shut its mouth, and its tongue is drawn out with a word.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When, however, the dislocation of it is small, then it returns to itself in many positions with a little removal.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If, however, the dislocation is complete and whole: then it should be reduced quickly, and there should not be any delay: and it is, so that it holds fast by means of the cap, at the end of the jaw of dislocation, from the inside, if the dislocation is on one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or insert two fingers together, if the dislocation is from both sides.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the remaining fingers of his hand are outside, with which he is even.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And say to the sick person that he should clean his jaws and make them healthy so that he can chew on all sides.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the doctor should even out the jaw, and push it back into place until it returns to its own place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If it is difficult to reduce it, especially if both jaws are affected: then administer a vapor with warm water and oil until the reduction becomes easy: and do not delay the reduction of the jaws at all, as we have said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they are reduced and evened out, and the mouth is closed, and do not relax: then place over them a few cloth pads, with a piece of wax that has been made from wax: and oil it with rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then bind it easily with soft ligaments.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the patient lie on his back: and let his head stand between two cloth pads so that he does not move to one side or the other: and do not force him to chew anything: but let him eat what he wants, and administer it to him easily. Let him drink a little warm water, and let him swallow it easily: then let him go to the toilet, and wash his mouth with water.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He should not be troubled during the operation of his mouth while he eats and drinks, and when he swallows, until his jaw has set and healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If it is difficult to reduce the two jaws when they come out of place in an hour, and do not return to their own place: then many times fever and constant bloating will occur: and perhaps the stomach will be loose, and perhaps pure cholera will occur.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you see this then you should know that it is a sign of death, and many times that person will die within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	The reduction of dislocation of the fork (furca) and the extreme of the humerus.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXI.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The furcula does not dislocate from the side due to the intrinsic continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it dislocates sometimes towards the outside: and that is what is sensed.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is, so that it lies on its back on the ground, and extends its arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then the cover takes the place with your palm through strong cover, for she will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then put on her a plaster, and wool, and squeeze it.
