Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The extremities of the one who follows the bed, and continue with it, do not dislocate, except rarely.
Quod si dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	That if it dislocates on a certain day: then it should be reduced and made even as we have said, and that you should be prepared.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then put on her a plaster, and wool, and tighten it up.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And instruct the sick person to remain in a peaceful and calm state until she heals.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with this same cure the extremity of the humerus is reduced when it separates from its place as well.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	On the reduction of the dislocation of the humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You should know that the humerus does not dislocate, unless through three modes.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One is that it dislocates towards the side tickling towards the lower part.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	Second is that it dislocates towards the side of the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it dislocates towards the upper part of the humerus: and that happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And does not dislocate towards the back due to the spatula.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it does not dislocate towards the front due to the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	It certainly often dislocates and exits towards the lower part tickling: especially in those who have little flesh there.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Since it exits quickly in them, and enters quickly as well.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those who have much flesh, the opposite is true: that is to say, since it exits with difficulty, and enters with difficulty as well.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happened to some men that they were struck, or fell down; and the humerus was dislocated warm, and it is thought because of this, since he has already been dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	It is necessary therefore that you experience that, until you are certain about it, and then proceed to its treatment.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And the dislocation is known when it is directed towards the lower side in relation to the shoulder blade: and distinguish between a dislocated shoulder and a healthy shoulder.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find a great difference between them, and an injury in the head of the humerus, and under the little finger at the touch of the head of the humerus as if it were itself: and it cannot be reduced by the sick hand to its socket, nor can it move in all its movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And likewise, if it is dislocated towards the chest, or upwards: then there is a clear touch, and it does not hide.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And of this kind of dislocation the reduction is easy when he is young, or a sick boy.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is, as he raises his own hand towards the top.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then put your fingers under its little finger, and raise the joint with force towards the top to its place: and the minister will raise his hand, and extend it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then let him put it down, for himself he will soon recover.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	If he does not recover with the above-mentioned thing, and there are many days from when the dislocation happened: then it is necessary that the sick man bath in warm water, and an emollient application is administered which softens and eases, such as if cooked leaves of the plant known as sweet marjoram, and foenugraecum, and melilotum in water, and is applied.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the sick man will lie on his back: and let a sphere and wool be placed under its little finger, which is equal between softening and tightening.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the doctor will place his heel on the sphere, and raise the head of the humerus with force, and draw the sick man's hand towards him by the lower side.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And let another nurse hold the head so that it does not move downward: for himself he will soon return to consciousness.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you want to bring him back, do it this way: and he will come to himself as he is longer ill, and stand at the side, and let his shoulder under a towel of the nurse; and lift up the towel on him to the top, until he is sick lying in air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another nurse should take the hand of the patient at the bottom of his leg.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	But if the sick person is light: then he should be suspended with something else, so that he does not move: for he will return immediately with dislocation.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And he is also reduced by another way: and it is that he is fixed on the ground a long wood, whose head is round figure: like a glove of the mortar: which is neither thick nor thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then let him be placed under the patient after he is laid on the head of the wood with soft cloth: and let the sick person stand by the length of the wood.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then let his hand be extended at the bottom on one side, and let his body be extended from the other side with strength: for the junction returns to its place with speed.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	That if his reduction is difficult by all that we have said, then use this cure: and it is that you take a piece of wood whose length is the quantity of two arms, and its width is the quantity of four fingers, and its thickness is the quantity of two fingers; and let the head be round, so that it eases his entrance into the deep title, in this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then let them bind on the round head with soft cloth so as not to hurt the wood for the sick person.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then let it be placed under the title of the nurse, so that his hand or arm extends on the wood to the bottom: and let the wood be tied over a support and the arm and the end of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then let the arm be placed on a step by the width, and let his hand be extended at the bottom, and let the rest of the body be suspended from one side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	The wound should be closed immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	For once the entrance is complete in whatever way possible, then you should place under it a sphere of the same quantity made of wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then place the prepared plaster made of powdery resin with olibanum and albumen all over the shoulder as it turns upside down.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tie the tourniquet under it as it is lowered: and let the ligaments be attached over the plaster upside down: and let his hands be joined to his neck, and let them remain so for seven days without moving them.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it should be placed an impoverished diet for the member to heal: because it heals faster.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then after seven or five days let him exercise with movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If then it remains firm and does not become soft, then it is healed indeed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If then the wound comes out a lot due to moisture that occurs with it or due to some other cause: then you should administer cauterization to it with three holes, as has been mentioned in the chapter on cauterization.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If all this is done, and the ligament is not firm after seven days, and the plaster and tourniquet are not secure on it, and it does not stand up by itself, and cannot raise its arm above its head: then you should know that the nerves serving the shoulder are either cut, or stretched, or softened: and you should know that the wound never heals in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	But the dislocation that occurs toward the chest and the nipple, or toward the back, occurs with a push and an extension with the arms: until it stops, and cauterization is administered to it with remaining ligaments and care, until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If something like this happens after healing, and a lag in movement occurs in the member, then let the invalid take frequent baths until that weight is softened, and return to its natural state first.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	On the treatment of dislocations of the cubitus.
Caput XXVIII.	De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	You should know that the dislocated cubitus joint moves with difficulty and returns to its position with difficulty as well; it dislocates particularly in the forward and backward directions.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation is not hidden from you; for it falls by sight, and by touch, and dislocates in whatever form.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join a dislocated cubitus with a healthy one, that will be apparent to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	For the joint is stiffened, and it cannot bend the arm, nor can it touch its shoulder.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you should know that you should immediately reduce a dislocation before it becomes cold.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if the dislocation has become cold, its reduction is difficult; and it may not recover at all, especially when it is towards the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	It is worse in every form of dislocation, and more painful; and often dies with it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And its restoration is such that it extends its hand with two hands; and the arm is spread out, and the thumb of each hand pushes against the cubitus joint from below, or from the base of the palm, until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or the dislocation is towards the front; then it returns in such a way that it doubles its hand with its own hand, until it hits against the base of its palm the dislocated cubitus joint.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	If the dislocation does not submit to reduction, then you should administer a severe and vigorous extension; and it is as if two ministers extend an arm: and they hold him back from moving during extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm turns in all directions after it has been wrapped with a long double cloth, or a broad ligament.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the doctor touches the joint with his hand, he should rub it with oil so that it moves with ease in the lubrication of the joint.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then, with a sharp push, pull the wound open until it is re-opened.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after reducing [the wound], let it be placed on top of it a plaster, in which is sitting the stitch, and drying with alba [white substance]; and let it be tied with stricture going down.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And let the arm be suspended from the neck by the nurse: and let it be left for a few days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then, let it be unbound.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If then the wound is firmly held in place, then dissolve the ligaments from her, and let her go.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see that the wound is not well tied up, then repeat the plaster, and the ligament, and let her go for a few days, until it is tied up.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then, unbind her.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If then there happens to her any weight after reducing the wound, and she is in motion: then administer humidification in a bath, and a subtle friction, and a compression, until it is healed up, or put on top of the wound an ointment, that is, natem arietis pinguem.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then let it be tied up, and let her go on top of it for a day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then take away from her, and introduce into the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When then she sweats, then bind up the wound with a moderate friction.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then repeat on top of her one time, and twice, and third time with the entrance into the bath, until she becomes relaxed.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if there is a wound, put on top of her manure that is wet, heated with butter, and tie over the wound.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Perform this several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	She is then healed, and returns to her own disposition.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	The cure for the dislocation of Al-Mahasım.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXVII.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The dislocation of Mahasım causes great pain, that is, the wound between the arm and the hand.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And reducing the dislocation of him is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	Opposite to the joints are ligatured.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	However, it is necessary that the speed be in the reduction of dislocation at the time when it dislocates, before the apotome is measured: or happen in him an apothem hot.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of dislocation is that you put the Mahassem hand of the weak on a table and extends it minister his hand: and puts the doctor his palm on the eminence of the joint, and pushes it, until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	However, it is necessary that you consider if the palm has already gone to the belly of the hand: then put the injured back of his hand on a table during extension and reduction: and if dislocation is going to the back of the hand, then the position of the hand should be intrusively on the table, that is, the inner part of the hand should be placed on the table, so that the doctor's palm rests on it on the eminence of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If he returns immediately, then it is good: and if not, then bind it with an plaster while the apothem stands: and let go of him, and do not return to it.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	For if he does not bear it, and you cannot reduce it after the days have passed, then the joint remains according to its tortuosity: and does not hurt the weak one anything, unless the hand is softened, and cannot grip anything: then you should know that nerves are cut off, or rubbed.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	There is no skill in it, except to bind it with a plaster close to the risk of it.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps does not bring anything.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	So if Mahassem does not return, then put on him the plaster which we described.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then it is bound, and let go after five days: then it is unbound and let go, and exercises the hand.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	But if his movement is prevented, and happens to him something of gravity: then make it soft with warm water, and sometimes with friction, until it softens.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	On the treatment of dislocations of the fingers.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When one of the fingers is dislocated all the way, or one of them to the back of the palm, or it is inside: then extend that finger and push the dislocation with your thumb until it comes back.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the end of the finger, and suspend it toward the side where it is dislocated, and let it be for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend it, and extend it, until it gets straight again on its own day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When it is night, bind it according to that story: and do not cease to make it well on the day: and exercise it with movement: and bind it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Make it for a few days, until it gets well.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And do the same with it if it is dislocated toward the bottom of the hand: and bind it to the side, and do your work with it, until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And do the same with it when it is dislocated to the other parts.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	On the treatment of dislocations of the spine of the dorsal side.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When this happens to anyone of the spine, or many of the vertebrae are removed from their places: then there is no cure for it, because death approaches quickly.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And a sign of that is, that he leaves the toilet with a will, and cannot hold himself: and often they become weak from him, or two limbs, or two arms, or one of them: or one of his spine is removed from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For many times it is dislocated, since the removal of them to the four sides happens often times.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	That which is dislocated to the back is called a hunchback.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	But the cure for it is this, that you should consider then, if a hunchback happens to be from childhood: then there is no cure for it, and there is no healing from it at all.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	In those cases that occur by accident, or by percussion, or similar things, the ancient authorities have already set forth in a lengthy discourse the ways of treating them.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	This does not return with profit.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I have indeed already abbreviated it from that, which little excuses its length by reason of its nearness to my purpose: and in my exposition of it as I did exhibit it, and fashioned the instrument after their manner, showing it, and exhibiting it itself.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say, therefore, that in the case of a deformity occurring in the anterior part, there is neither art nor cure from it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And likewise in that which is made on both sides.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And do not cure them unless that which happens in the back proper, with what I tell you: and is, so that it extends itself on the face of a sick person on an equal platform close to the wall: and spreads itself under it a damp cloth, that it may not harm his chest.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then place a straight piece of wood firmly fixed in the earth at the end of the foot, about the head thereof: and another piece of wood about the feet on the other side of the foot: and let the servant hold the piece of wood, and set it not firm in the earth.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	Then let another servant hold the other.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then let the nurse bend over his head, and with a soft bandage hold fast to the part below his chin, making it firm: and let her extend the end of the bandage towards the piece of wood which is by his head: and bind it there.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then let another bandage be stretched above his shoulders, and above his knees, and at the small of his back.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather all the bandages together, and bind them to the other piece of wood which is by his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then let all the servants extend to the piece of wood the bandages, and let them not move two pieces of wood from their places in which they are fixed: however, let them not be firm, as we have said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the physician should set his hand upon the spine with strength, until he has taken it off; or upon a board.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he should attach his feet to the board with strength, until he has taken them off.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	But if he does not recover by this treatment, then take a board whose length is about three arms.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And make a cut in the wall which we have mentioned, that is near to the sick man, a place in which to insert the end of the board.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the board upon the spine.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And let the physician set his feet on the other end of the board.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And fasten it securely, until the spine is straining, and return to its place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then if you wish, operate with a saw which is turned with your hand: and it is like this, that you should fix two pieces of wood on the ground at the head of the back which are the length of an arm: and at the head of the two pieces of wood.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And make the length which is between all the wood a palm: and there has already been made in every place an opening, in which the saw runs: and it is made fast all the wood to the ground very firmly, so that it does not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And introduce the round wood: and there is a saw which turns about in two openings of the two pieces of wood.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at its end there is an opening, in which the wood is fixed, the length of which is a palm with that by which it turns: and there is also similar opening in the other two pieces of wood.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then tighten the ligaments which you have tightened in the spine of the saw which is at its head: and the ligaments which you have tightened in his legs in the saw which is at his feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then stand by every saw which makes it turn with his hand by means of a lever, with which it turns: and the physician should adjust the spine, according to what we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of a tourniquet, which follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then, after the spondylius has returned and the place has been made even, then you should put on an dried plaster with albumen.
Deinde stuppam.	Then the stump.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then place above the plaster a plate of wood, whose width is three fingers wide, or about that.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length so much as it takes up space for the gibbosity, and on the healthy side of the spondylius.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then tie with a bandage which we have said.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And use the sick one with delicate nutrition until it heals.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	That if anything remains of a prominence in the place at the end of the healing: then it is necessary that the medicines which soften and loosen be given, with the giving of the plate which we described at a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And now is given in that plate of lead.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And when it happens that a prominence occurs at the rear of the spondylius of the back: and it is believed by means of that dislocation, and it is the opening which has already been made.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Why it should not be assumed that it will do so with this medicine: perhaps however that will happen death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	On the treatment of dislocated anchae.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You should know that the dislocation of an anchae, and of a shoulder, does not occur unless there is only a little dislocation: and does not occur to them what occurs to the other joints from slight distance and pressure.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And the joint of an anchae dislocates according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	Because it dislocates towards the front, and towards the back.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And most often it dislocates towards the inside: and a little towards the front, and towards the back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the treatment of its dislocation to the inside is: because when you join the thigh of a healthy nurse with an unhealthy one, it is longer: and is the knee of the sick more prominent than that of a healthy one, so that the sick man cannot double his foot behind him: and there is a place which follows the buttocks, so that the head of the hip has already reached that place.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And his sign where dislocation has occurred is external, which are his opposite conditions to these conditions.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the sign of him where dislocation has occurred to the front, because it widens the healthy leg according to the complement: however, it does not duplicate the same without pain that is in the knee: and if he tries to walk, he cannot overcome it to the front: and he holds back his urine, and he wipes himself with his heel, and during walking he steps on his heel.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	And the sign of him where dislocation has occurred to the back, that he does not widen his leg, and cannot duplicate the same until he doubles his knee: and it is shorter the other leg; and the knee is softened, and the head of the femur is at the place of it.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction of this dislocation of the eyes is that you consider then, if the dislocation has been fresh, which has now healed with the one who has it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you administer the reduction of it, and remains according to its disposition: then is not in it at all cure.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore it should not be assumed that he is perfect.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	But in that one whose dislocation is recent, and is out of the four species of dislocation: then approach to this, so that you move the joint, and extend it inwardly and outwardly, and move it with the right and left hand: for perhaps it will recover, and does not need any other cure.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	But if this way does not recover, then you should prepare a strong instrument, and extend the leg of him from the lower part: or with his hands, or with a ligature that is tied over the leg above the knee: and another instrument extends his hand from above: so that he inserts his hands under the skin.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then bind with a soft ligament over the root of the pelvis, and hold the end of the other ligament.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And let his extension be from the front part of the groin to the thigh, or from the back to the spine.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And let their whole extension be one way, until he who is ill with his body is lifted up from the earth and remains suspended.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	For this is the type of extension, which is a common species of the four species.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If therefore the dislocation returns with him which I have spoken of, it is good; and if not, then it is necessary that every species of what I say about the cure of itself.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In reduction however, when his own dislocation is towards the inside, it is necessary that the sick man should lie down on his healthy side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then let him put a bandage over the root of the hip, in that which is between the head of the hip and the place which is under the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the ligature from the side of the groin to the higher part of the body, to the side of the fork.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then another strong servant should take his arm, and he should reduce the large place of the ill hip, and extend it towards the outside with a swift extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	For it has already returned to its place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this species is easier than the other species of cure, so that this limb is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	If however he excuses himself from you, and does not obey you at all with this species of cure: then it is necessary that two nurses should bind the feet together with a strong ligature, soft, over the two heels, and over the two knees: and let the length of each from its comparison be four fingers' quantity: and let the length of the sick man's leg be increased by two quantities of two fingers.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then let the sick man be suspended over the head of the ligature, so that he is in the house: and let his length from the earth be a quantity of two arms' length.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command a strong man to strike the head of the hip: and let another be suspended with the sick man: and let another push the hip with strength, for the extension returns to its place with velocity.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	In reduction therefore of his own, when there is a dislocation to the outside, it should be so that the sick person lies on his back, according as we said in having gibbosity.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And let the ligaments be tied over the cross of his own body, the sick one, and over his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two beams are to be placed, one at the feet of him, and another at the head of him.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then a beam is to be placed in the middle of the foot, well fixed: over which wet cloths are to be spread so as not to hurt the sick one; and let the beam be placed between his thighs, so that it does not draw towards the lower parts by the extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then all the ministers are to extend on their side, and the doctor is to make the reduction with his own hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If therefore he obeys to the reduction, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, let him be placed on that board, and pressed as we said in the case of gibbosity, equally.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	However, it is necessary that the sick one should lie on his sound side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is to the front, then it should be so that the thigh of the sick one is quickly extended; and this is according to our above description on lying on the back; and the doctor places his right hand palm on the knee of the sick one.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he is to be pulled by the hand with the other, and with that pulling place him extended towards the lower parts on the side of the leg.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	And if the dislocation is to the rear: then it should not be so that the sick one is extended towards the lower parts, and is raised up on the ground; but rather let him be placed on a hard thing, as we said also in case of his lying on two broad things; and let him be on his face, and the ligaments extended: according to what we have just said.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And let there be applied pressure with the board also on the place to which the joint is dislocated, when the reduction is completed according as it should be.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of his recovery shall not be hidden from you: and it is so, that you spread out two legs of the sick: and when you see them equal, and the sick one straightens his leg, and stretches himself without excuse: then you know that now the limb has returned, according to what is due: then you join the two hips together, and put on a splint, and fasten it with ties, that is, with a belt: so that he does not move widely in any part: and let the sick one rest for three days, or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then you shall loosen the ligaments, and the splint, and bring the leg together with the other: then if you see them equal in position, then know that the dislocation is now fixed: so let go of the sick one to walk.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see any softening: then go back, and put on the splint, and tighten it according to your first direction: and let go of him also for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then you shall loosen it and let him walk a little on each side for a few days, until he is comforted well.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	The Dislocation of the Knee.
Caput XXXIII.	CHAPTER XIII.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	THE KNEE IS DISLOCATED IN THREE WAYS.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	IS DISLOCATES TO THE OUTSIDE, TO THE INSIDE, AND TO THE BOTTOM, THAT IS TO SAY TO THE BACK.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	AND IT DOES NOT DISLOCATE TO THE FRONT.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	And the sign of his dislocation is, that you command the sick one to apply his leg to his hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	But if he does not attach himself to the hip: then know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	AND THE RESTORATION OF ALL KINDS OF DISLOCATION IS THIS, THAT YOU LET THE SICK ONE SIT UPRIGHT, SO THAT HE EXTENDS HIS LEG IF HE CAN OVER IT, AND ADHERE TO YOUR BACK FACING FORWARD: and put his foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then you shall attach the knee of him with your palms, and make them straight between your fingers over his knee.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply with your palm two sides of his genitals with strength.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another minister extends his foot, until he returns to his place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	And the sign of the return is that which adheres the thigh to the hip in gentleness, not laboriously.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then apply plaster upon him, and let the thigh adhere to the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind them together with bandages for three days, or four.
Deinde solue ea.	Then dissolve them.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And the sick person should not walk, but he will be healed in a few days.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	But if his return is not satisfactory to you, then apply an extension with strong ligatures, of which the account of the cure of ankylosis was given, until he returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	The Cure of Dislocation of the Calcaneus.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The Calcaneus is sometimes moved with a small movement, and sometimes dislocated according to the complement.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	And the dislocation of it is made either towards the inside or towards the outside.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	And the sign of the dislocation of it is that you see the Calcaneus swollen, proceeding to the part to which it is dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	But the cure of the dislocation is easy; and it is that, when extended with ease with the hands, and made to return, until it returns.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	In the cure of it when it is dislocated according to the complement, you should make the sick person sit upright; and hold him firmly from behind by a strong minister at the middle part of his back,
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold with your right hand with your palm his foot from the upper part of it, and with your left hand from the lower part of the foot near the heel.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then draw the foot towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with the two fingers of your left hand.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend with the left, and push the chest of the foot towards the hip with the right without labor.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Make it twice as strong, as we have described.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then push the chest of the foot to the ankle in a third degree, and you should tear the tendon.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	But if he returns in a first degree or in a second according to this mode and you see the foot even, it is good; and if not, then repeat the operation on himself because he will return again.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	But if you are forbidden to reduce him with it that we have spoken of then: then let him lie on his back on the ground and fix a board firmly on the ground so that he falls between his thighs: but you have already wrapped up the wound with a cloth in order not to hurt the patient.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then let the servant take the leg of the patient: then let the other serve extend the foot or with his hands or with a cord that binds above the ankle of the foot.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then let all the servants stand opposed to the extension of their patient and let one nurse stand between the two thighs holding it back so that the body does not attract towards the lower parts at the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then let the doctor adjust the dislocation with his hands and let the other servant hold the sound leg from below.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For the dislocation returns with velocity.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	But when the dislocation returns and you declare to him that the return of it is healthy then put a plaster and a support, and tighten it with strings firmly, and tie the foot with a cord to the leg.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And it is necessary so that you should not be afraid or worry about the nerves that are above the heel in the back because they do not have a binding cord over them and hurt them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then let him go for two days or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	But if the ligament becomes softer then tighten it on him: but let him go free after three days or four and forbid the patient from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	But if he tries to walk before that space, there is no security except that the dislocation should be dissolved on him and the corruption should take place and not receive after that cure.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If it should happen that he has a hot apoplexy: then you should give him sedatives, as we have narrated in another place from the cure, and an emetic, until it is removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	Regarding dislocation of the toes of the foot and treatment.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It is necessary that it should be adjusted which is out of place with a little extension without work: and this is not difficult, indeed, it is easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If however the dislocation is in some of the knuckles of the back of the foot: then you should make the invalid put his foot on an equal place of the ground, or on a board: and it stands as if it were walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then you stand, and put your foot on that which protrudes from the joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then trample on it with your foot with force, until it returns, and does not appear to be in a raised position in place.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then put under the instep of his foot a board which takes the entire foot, which has two heads.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then tighten him with a strap for three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then solve him, and let him rest from walking for many days, until it is tightened and secured by reduction.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	Regarding the types of dislocation with a sprain or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When this happens to him, and he is inclined to cure himself and restore himself, often death succeeds: and therefore it is not necessary that you should be hasty in the cure of him, which is of this kind, unless he is prudent in the art of the long use, merciful, compassionate, slow, not daring, and not presumptuous: and that he uses medicine which sedates the hot apostemata only: and leaves the invalid to divine judgment.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you have hope or expect salvation from destruction with kindness of disease, and in which there seems to be some hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Let us then immediately reduce him at the start of the thing, before the apoplexy of heat occurs.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	But if the limb returns, as we have said, then administer the remedy that quiets the apoplexy: and take care of the bruise with it as it suits him from the dried ointment.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If the dislocation is with a fracture and they occur in separated bones of the jaw, then let us immediately remove them, and make a hole in that place as we have said for simple illnesses because it preceded in those places.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And let your care be according to your virtue, and keep yourself from the entrance into a state of fear: because my prophecy has preceded you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For that is better for you with your Creator, and more lasting to your glory, and healthier to your body with them at that time.
